DIV1.P:
SELECT PLAYS: CONTAINING,
1. WILD OATS. By Mr. O'KEEFE.
2. LIONEL and CLARISSA. By Mr. BICKER∣STAFF.
3. LOVE IN A VILLAGE. By the same.
4. THE SUSPICIOUS HUSBAND. By Dr. HOADLEY.
PHILADELPHIA: PUBLISHED BY MATHEW CAREY, M, DCC, XCVI.
WILD OATS: OR, THE STROLLING GENTLEMEN. A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS, AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, Covent Garden.
BY JOHN O'KEEFE, ESQ.
DUBLIN: PRINTED FOR THE BOOKSELLERS. M.DCC.LXCIII.

DIV1.HEAD: WILD OATS: OR, THE STROLLING GENTLEMEN.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: Scene a Parlour in LADY AMARANTH's.
Enter SIR GEORGE THUNDER and JOHN DORY.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEORGE.
SP.P: I Don't know whose house we've got into here, John, but I think when he knows me, we may hope for some refreshment. Zounds, I'm as dry as touch-wood; and to sail at the rate of ten knots an hour, over stubble and farrow, from my own house, but half a league on this side of Gosport, and not to catch these deserters that received the King's bounty, and run from their ships.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: You've ill luck.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Mine, you swab!

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P:
Ah, you've money and gold;—but grace and good fortune have shook hands with you these nineteen years, for that rogue's trick you play'd Miss
Amelia, by deceiving her with a sham marriage, when you passed yourself for Captain Seymor, then putting to sea, leaving her to break her heart, then marrying another lady.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: But was I not forc'd to that by my father?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Ay, because she had a great fortune—her death was a judgment upon you,

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Why, you impudent dog-fish—upbraid me for running into false bay, when you was my pilot, wasn't you—even got me the mock clergyman that perform'd the sham marriage with Amelia?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: (Aside) You think so, but I took care to bring a real clergyman.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: But is this a time or place for your lec∣tures?—at home, abroad, at sea and land, will you still badger me? Mention my Wild Oats again, and —you scoundrel, since the night my bed-curtains took fire, when you were my boatswain aboard the Eagle, you've got me quite into leading strings—you snatch'd me up on deck, toss'd me into the sea to save me from being burnt, and I was almost drown'd.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: You would, but for me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Yes, you dragg'd me out by the ear like a water dog. Last week, because you saw the tenth bottle uncorked, you rushed in among my friends, and ran away with me, and the next morning Captain O'Shanaghan sends me a challenge, for quitting my chair when he was toast-master—so to save me from the head ach, you'd like to have got my brains blown out.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Oh, very well—be burnt in your bed, and tumble into the water, like a tight fellow as you are, and promise yourself with sloe juice, see if John cares a piece of mouldy biscuit about it. But I thought you had laid yourself up in ordinary, retired to live quiet upon your estate, and had done with sea affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: John, a man should forget his own con∣venience for his country's good.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: But I wish you hadn't made me your valet-de-chambre—no sooner wa I got on shore, after five years dashing upon rocks, shoals, and breakers, then you set me upon a hard trotting cart-horse, that toss'd me up and down like an old bm-boat in the Bay of Biscay—and here's nothing to drink at all. Because at home you keep open house▪ you think every body else does the same. Holloa! holloa!—I'll never cease piping till it calls a drop to my whistle. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Yes, as John Dory remarks, I fear my trip through life will be attended with heavy squalls and foul weathers—When my conduct to poor Amelia comes athwart my mind, it's a hurricane for all that day; and when I turn in at night the ballad of Wil∣liam and Mary's ghost (sings) —Oh, zounds, the dis∣mals are coming upon me, and I can't get a cheering glass to—Holloa!

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Friend, what would'st thou have?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Have? why I would have grog.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Neither man nor woman of that name abi∣deth here.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! Man nor woman—then if you'll bring me Mr. Brandy and Mrs. Water, we'll couple them, and the first child probably will be Mas∣ter Grog.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Thou dot speak in parables, which I under∣stand not.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Sheer off with your sanctified poop, and send the gentleman of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: The owner of this mansion is a maiden, and she approacheth.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Do I behold—it is—how dost thou do, unce?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Is it possible you can be my niece, Lady Amaranth Thunder?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: I'm the daughter of thy deceased bro∣ther Loftus, called Earl Thunder, but no Lady—my name is Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: But zounds, how is all this?—unexpect∣edly find you in a strange house, of which old Sly tells me you're mistress, turn'd quaker, and disown your title.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Thou knowest the relation to whose care my father left me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Well, I know our cousin, old Dovehouse, was a quaker, but didn't suspect he would have made you one.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Being now gathered to his father's, he did bequeath unto me his worldly goods, and amongst them this mansion, and the lands around it.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: So thou becomest and continue one of the faithful. I'm executor of his will, and by it cannot give thee possession of these goods but upon these con∣ditions.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Tell me of your thee's and thou's, qua∣ker's wills, and mansions—I say, girl, though on the death of your father, my eldest brother, Loftus Earl Thunder, from your being a female, his title devolves to his next brother, Robert; though as a woman you can't be an Earl, nor as a woman you can't make laws for your sex nor for our sex; yet, as the daughter of a peer, you are, and by heavens shall be called, Lady Amaranth Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Thou makest too much noise, friend.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Dam'me, call me friend, and I'll bump your block-head against the capstern.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Yea, this is a man of danger—I will leave Mary to abide it.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: S'fire my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Title is vanity.

SP.SPEAKER: ZACH.
SP.P: Shall thy cook this day dress certain birds of the air called woodcocks, and ribs of the oxen likewise?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: All—my uncle sojourneth with me per∣adventure, and my meal shall be a feast, friend Zacha∣riah.

SP.SPEAKER: ZACH.
SP.P: My tongue shall say so, friend Mary.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Sir George Thunder bids thee remem∣ber to call thy mistress Lady Amaranth. (strikes him.)

SP.SPEAKER: ZACH,
SP.P: Verily, George.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: George, sirrah!—Tho' a younger bro∣ther, the honour of Knighthood was my reward for placing the glorious British flag over that of a daring enemy—therefore address me—

SP.SPEAKER: ZACH.
SP.P: Yea, good George.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: George and Mary—here's levelling— here's abolition of title with a vengeance! S'blood, in this house they think no more of an English knight than if he was a French duke.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Kinsman, be patient; thou and thy son Henry, whom I have not beheld these twelve years, shall be welcome to my dwelling. Where now abi∣deth you?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: At the Naval Academy at Portsmouth.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: May I see the young man?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What, to make a quaker of him? No, no—but hold—as she is a wealthy heiress, her marry∣ing my son Harry will keep up and preserve the title in our family (aside). Would thou be really glad to see him. Thou shalt Mary—John Dory—Ah, here's my valet-de-chambre.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Avast, old man of war; you must instantly convoy my son from Portsmouth.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Then I must first convoy him to Portsmouth, for he happens to be out of dock already.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What wind now?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: You must know, on our quitting harbour—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P:
Damn your sea-jaw, you marvellous
dolphin, give me the contents of your log-book in plain English.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Why then, the young 'Squire has cut and run.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Got leave to come to you, and the master did not find out before yesterday, that instead of mak∣ing for home he had sheer'd off towards London, di∣rectly sent notice to you, and Sam has trac'd us all the way here to bring you the news.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What a boy of mine quit his guns—I'll grapple him—come John.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Order the carriage for mine uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: No, thank'ye, my Lady, let your equi∣page keep up your own dignity—I've horses here, but won't knock them up—next village is the channel for the stage. My Lady, I'll bring the dog to you by the bowsprit, weigh anchor, croud sail, and after him.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: The man of noise doth not tarry—then my spirit is glad.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Let Sarah prepare chambers for my kinsman, and hire the maiden for me that thou didst mention.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I will, for this damsel is passing fair, and hath found grace in mine eyes. Mary, as thou art yet a stranger in this land, and just taken possession of this estate, the law of society doth command thee to be on terms of amity with thy wealthy neighbours.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Yea, but while I entertain the rich, the hearts of the poor shall also rejoice. I myself will now go forth into the adjacent hamlet, and invite all that cometh to good cheer.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Yea; and I will distribute among the poor good books.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: And meat and drink too, friend Ephraim, in the fulness of plenty—they shall join in thanks∣giving for those gifts of which I'm unworthy. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: I say, Dick Buskin, harkee, my lad.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: What keeps Rover?

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: I'm sure I don't know: as you desired I paid for our breakfast—but the devil's in that fellow, every inn we stop at he will always hang behind, chat∣tering with the bar-maid or the chamber-maid.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Or any, or no maid—but he's a worthy lad, and I love him better, I think, than my own bro∣ther, had I one.

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: Oh, but Dick, mind my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Stop, Midg, tho' 'twas my orders, when I set out on this scamp with the players, the better to conceal my quality, for you before people to treat me as your companion, yet you at the same time should have had discretion enough to remember when we are alone, that I am your master, and son to Sir George Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: Sir, I ask your pardon; but by making yourself my equal, I've got so us'd to familiarity, that I find it curs'd hard to shake it off.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Well, Sir, pray mind that familiarity is all over, my frolic is out, I now throw off the player, and shall return directly. My father must by this time have heard of my departure from the academy at Portsmouth; and tho' I was deluded away by my rage for acting, 'twas bad of me to give the gay old fellow any cause of uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: And, Sir, shall you and I never act another scene together?—shall I never again play Sir Harry Wildair, for my own benefit, nor ever again have the pleasure of caneing your honour in the character of Alderman Smuggler?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: In future act the part of a smart coat and hat brusher, or I shall have the pleasure of caneing you in the character of one that gives mighty blows. You were a good servant, but sirrah, I find by letting you crack your jokes and sit in my company, you're grown quite a rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I was a modest well-behaved lad, but evil communications corrupt good manners.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Run back, and tell Rover to make haste. To bring you down, I'll clap a livery on you—wear that, to find another master.

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I don't mind wearing a livery, but when one has so long had a halbert, its damn'd hard to be again put into the rank.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Well, if my father but forgives me, this three months excursion with the players has shewed me some life, and a devilish deal of fun—for one cir∣cumstance I shall ever remember it with pleasure— it's bringing me acquainted with Jack Rover—how long he stays—Jack (calls). In this forlorn stroller I have discovered qualities that honour human nature, and accomplishments that might grace a prince. My poor friend has often lent me his money, though he supposed me a poor needy devil, that could never be able to repay him. He shan't know who I am till it's in my power to serve him; only the rogue always marr'd the grand design of my frolic—I had no chance among the pretty women where he was; he had the knack of winning their hearts by his gaiety. Tho' so devilish pleasant in his quotations, which on the moment he dashes in a parody whimsically oppo∣site to every occasion as it happens, I hope he won't find the purse I've hid in his pocket before we part. I dread the moment—but it's come.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: (without) The brisk lightning I!

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P:
Aye, there's the rattle—hurried on by the impetuous flow of his own volatile spirits, his life is a rapid stream of extravagant whim; and while the serious voice of humanity prompts his heart to the best actions, his features shine in laugh and levity—
Enter ROVER. Studying Bays, Jack?

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: I'm the bold Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I'm—if he knew but all (aside) —keep one standing in the road.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Beg your pardon, my dear Dick, all the fault of—plague on't, that a man can't sleep and break∣fast at an inn, then return to his bed-chamber for his gloves, but there he must find chamber-maids thump∣ing feathers and knocking pillows about, and keep one, when one has affairs and business—upon my soul, these girls' conduct to us is intolerable, the very thought brings blood into my face, and when ever they attempt to serve and provoke me so—Dam'me but I will—An't I right Dick?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: All in the wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: No matter, that's the universal play all round the wrekin. But you're so conceited, because, by this company we're going to join at Winchester, you're engaged for high tragedy.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: And you for Ranger's plumes, and Fop∣pington.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Our first play is Lear—I was devilish im∣perfect in Edgar t'other night at Lymington; I must look it over (takes a book) "Away! the foul fiend follows me"—Holloa! stop a moment, we shall have the whole country after us.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: What now?

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: That rosy fac'd chambermaid put me in such a passion, that by heavens I walk'd out of the house and forgot to pay the bill.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Never mind, Rover, it's paid.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Paid! why neither you nor Midg had money enough.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I tell you 'tis paid.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: You paid—oh, very well: every honest fellow should be a stock purse. Let's push on—ten miles to Winchester—we shall be there by eleven.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Our trunks at the inn are book'd for the Winchester coach.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Our hero, Tom Stately, stept into the chaise with his tragedy-phiz, ha, ha, ha!—rides Botti∣kin between our Thalia and Melpomene—but I prefer walking to the car of Thespis. What do you wait for now?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Which is the way?

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Here.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Then I go there (points opposite.)

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: My dear boy, on this spot, and at this moment, we must part—

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Part!

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Rover, you wish me well.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Well, and suppose so—part.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Yes, part!

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: What mystery and grand—what are you at; do you forget, you, Midg, and I, are engaged to Truncheon the manager, and that the bills are up with our names to play to night at Winchester?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Jack, you and I hope often to meet on the stage, in assumed characters, if it's your wish we should ever meet again in our real ones of sincere friends, without asking whither I go, or my reasons for leaving you, when I walk up this road, do you turn down that.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Joke.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I'm serious—good bye.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: If you repent your engagement with Truncheon, I'll break off too, and go with you where∣ever—

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Attempt to follow me, and even our ac∣quaintance ends.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Don't think of my reasons, only that it must be.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Have I done any thing to Dick Buskin? leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I'm as much concern'd as you.—Good bye.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER
SP.P: I can't even bid adieu!—I won't either— if any cause could be given—farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Bless my poor fellow. Adieu.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Well good—oh, damnation!—

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, a VILLAGE with a COTTAGE and GARDEN.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: WELL, Master Ephraim, I may depend on thee, as you quakers never break your word.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I have spoken to Mary, and she, at my re∣quest, consenteth to take thy daughter Jane for her handmaid.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: That's hearty—I intended to make a pre∣sent to the person that does me such a piece of ser∣vice, but I shan't afront you with it.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I am meek and humble, and must take affronts.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Then, here's a guinea, Master Ephraim.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I expected not this; but there's no harm in a guinea.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: So, I shall get my children off my hands. My son Sim is robbing me day and night, giving away my corn and what not among the poor; my daughter Jane—when girls have nought to do, this mischief love creeps into their minds, and then, hey, they're for kicking up their heels.—Sim, son Sim!

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Yes, feyther.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM
SP.P: Call your sister?

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Jane, feyther wants you.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Did you call me?

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: I often told you both, but its now settled— you must go into the world and work for your bread.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Feyther, whatever you think right must be so; and I am content.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: And I'm sure, feyther, I'm willing to do any thing you would have me.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: There's ingratitude for you!—when my wife, your mother, died, I brought you up from the shell, and now that you're fledg'd, you want to fly off and forsake me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Why, no, I'm willing to live with you all my days.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: And I'm sure, feyther, if its your desire, I'll never part from you.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Here's an unnatural pair—what, you want to hang upon me like a couple of leeches, aye, to strip my branches, and leave me a wither'd hawthorn. See who's yonder? (Exit Sim.) Jane, Ephraim Smooth has hired you for Lady Amaranth.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: La, then I shall live in the great house.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Her Ladyship has sent s all presents of good books, here, to read a chapter in; it gives a man patience when he is in a passion. (gives her a book.)

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Thank her good Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: My being incumbered with you both is the cause why old Banks here won't give me his sister.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: That's a pity; if we must have a step∣mother, madam Amelia would make us a very good one—but I wonder how she should refuse you, feyther, for I'm sure she thinks you a very portly man, in your scarlet coat and new scratch.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: However, if Banks still refuses, I have him in my power, I'll turn them out of their cottage yonder, and the bailiff shall procure them a lodging. Here he comes.— Enter BANKS from the Cottage. Well, neighbour Banks, once for all, am I to marry your sister?

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: That she best knows.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: She says she won't.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Then I dare say she won't; for tho' a woman, I never knew her to prevaricate.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Then she won't have me. Fine things that you and she, who's little better than paupers, dare to be damn'd saucy.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Why, I confess we are poor, but while that's the worst our enemies can say of us, we are content. Exit into Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Damn it, I wish I had a fair occasion to quarrel with him, I'd make him content with a devil to him—I'd knock him down, send him to gaol, and —but—I'll be up with him.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Oh, feyther, here's one Mr. Lamp, a ring∣leader of the shew-folks, came from Andover, to act in our villages—he wants a barn to play in, if you'll hire him yours.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Surely, boy, I'll never refuse money; but least he should engage the great room at the inn, run and tell him—stop, I'll go myself, a short cut through the garden—

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Why, you, or any neighbour is welcome to walk in it, or partake of any thing it produces, but making it a common thoroughfare is—

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Here, son, kick down that gate.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Does the lad hear?

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Why, yes, yes.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Does the fool understand.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Dong't I'm but yet young, but if under∣standing teaches me how to wrong my neighbours, I hope I may never live to years of discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: What, you cur, do you disobey your fey∣ther?—burst open the garden gate, as I command you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Feyther, he that made both you and the garden gate, commands me not to injure the un∣fortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Here's an ungracious rogue—then I must do it myself.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Hold, neighbour—small as the spot is, its now my only possession, and the man shall first take my life, who sets its foot in it against my will.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM,
SP.P: I'm in such a passion—

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Feyther, if you're in a passion, read the book you gave me.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Plague on the wench—but you hussy, I'll— and you unlucky bud.

DIV2.STAGE: Exeunt Sim and Jane, Gammon goes and stands at the door of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Zounds, here's a pelting shower, and no shelter—poor Tom's a cold, I'm wet through; here's a good promising house. Going to Gammon's house, Gammon prevents his entrance.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Hold my lad, can't let folks in till I know who they are: there's a public house not above half a mile on.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Step in here, young man, my fire is small, but it shall cheer you with a hearty welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: The poor cotager and the substantial farmer. (Kneels) Hear nature, dear goddess, hear; if ever you design to make his corn-field fertile, change your purpose: that from the blighted ears no grains may fall to fat his stubble goose. And when to town he drives his hogs (so like himself) o let him feel the soaking rain, then he may curse his crimes, to taste and know how sharper than the serpent's tooth is his! —Dam'me, but I'm spouting in the rain all this time.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Ah, neighbour, you'll soon scratch a beggar's head, if you harbour every ma vagrant; this may be one of the footpads that it seems have got about the country, but I'll have an execution and seize on thy goods this day, my honest neighbour. Eh—the sun strikes out—quite clear'd up.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: La! Feyther, if there isn't coming down the village—

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Oh thou hussy.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Bless me, Feyther, no time for anger now— Here's Lady Amaranth's chariot—la it stops!

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Her Ladyship is coming out, and walks this way. She may wish to rest herself in my house—Jane we must always make rich folks welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: I'll run in and get all the things to rights; but Feyther your cravat and wig is all—

DIV2.STAGE: Adjusts Gammon, and then exit into the house.

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Well, master Gammon, as you desired me, I am come to serve this copy of a writ, and arrest Master Banks, Where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Yes! now I'm determin'd on't—waunts, stand aside, I'll speak to you anon.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Friend Jane, whom I have taken to be my handmaid, is thy daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: So her mother said, arn't please your Lady∣ship.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Ephraim Smooth acquainted me thou'rt a wealthy yeman. I am come to thy hamlet, to behold with mine eyes the distresses of my poor tenants—I wish to relieve their wants.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Right, your Ladyship, for charity hides a deal of sin. How good of you to think of the poor: that's so like me. I'm always contriving how to re∣lieve my neighbours—you must lay Banks in prison to night. aside to Twitch.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: And if it please you, will your Ladyship enter our humble dwelling, and rest your Ladyship?

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Do my Lady—to receive so great a Lady from her chariot is an honour I dreamt not of—for the hungry and weary foot travellers my doors are always open, and my morsel ready. Knock, and when he comes out, touch him. aside to Twitch.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Thou art benevolent, and I will enter thy doors with satisfaction.

DIV2.STAGE: Exeunt all but Twitch into Gammon's house.

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Eh, where's the writ? Knocks at Bank's door.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Master Twich, what's your busimess with me?

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Only a little business here against you.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Me?

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Farmer Gammon has brought a thirty pound bank note of hand of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: I did not think his malice could have stretched so far. I thought the love he possessed for my sister might—Why, it's true, master Twitch—to lend our indigent cottagers small sums, when they were unable to pay their rent, I got a lawyer Quick to pro∣cure me the money, and hoped their industry would have put it in my power to take up the note before now: however I'll go round and try what they can do, and call on you and settle it.

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: No, no, that won't do; you must go with me.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: [From the cottage.] Old gentleman, come quick, or I'll draw another bottle of your currant wine.

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: You'd better not make no noise, and go with me.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Oh, you're here—rain over—quite fair. I'll take a sniff of the open air too—Eh! what's the mat∣ter?

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: What's that to you?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: What's that to me!—Why you're very un∣mannerly.

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Here's a rescue.

SP.SPEAKER: BANK.
SP.P: Nay, my dear Sir, I'd wish you not to bring yourself into trouble about me.

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Now, since you don't know what's civil, if the debt an't paid, to jail you go.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: My kind hospitable good old woman to jail —what's the sum, you scoundrel?

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Better words, or I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Stop—after me, good or bad, except to tell what's your demand upon this gentleman, and I'll give you the greatest beating, you ever had since you com∣menced rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Why, master, I dont want to quarrel with you, because—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: You'll get nothing by it—Do you know, you villain, that I am this moment the greatest man living?

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Who, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I am the bold Thunder, Sirrah—know that I carry my prize of gold in my coat pocket, tho' dam' me if I know how it came there. (aside, takes the purse out) There's twenty pictures of his Majesty: there∣fore, in the King's name, I free his legal subject, and now who am I?

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Ten pieces short, my master: but if you're a housekeeper, I'll take this and your bail.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P:
Then for bail you must have a housekeeper —what's to be done?
Enter GAMMON. Oh, here's old hospitality—I know your a house∣keeper, though your fire-side was too warm for me. Look here, some rapacious griping rascal has had this worthy gentleman arrested—now a certain good-for-nothing rattling fellow has paid twenty guineas of the sum—you pass your word for the other nine, we'll run back into the old gentleman's house, and over his cur∣rant wine our first toast shall be, Liberty to the honest debtor, and confusion to the hard-hearted creditor.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: I shan't.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: No—what's your name?

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Gammon.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Then dam'me, you're the Hampshire hog.— S'death, what shall we do to extricate?—Damn the money.

DIV2.STAGE: Entr LADY AMARANTH from the House.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: What tumult's this?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: A lady—Ma'am, your most obedient humble servant—a quaker too—they're generally kind and humane, and that face is a prologue to a play of a thousand good acts—may-be she'd help us here (aside) Ma'am, you must know that I know this gentleman: —I mean, he got a little behind hand, from bad crops, as every honest well-principled man may, and from rain lodging in his corn, and his cattle from murrain and rot—rot the murrain, you understand—and then in steps I with my—in short, Madam, I'm one of the most out of the way story-tellers in the world, when myself is the hero of the tale.

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH.
SP.P: Mr. Banks has been arrested for thirty pounds, and this gentleman has paid twenty guineas of the sum.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: My litigious neighbour to expose me thus!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: The young man and maiden within have pictured thee as a man of irreproachable morals, tho' unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Madam, he's an honest fellow, I've known him above forty years—he's the best hand at stirring a fire—if you was to taste his currant wine.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Madam, I never aspired to an invincible rank in life, yet hitherto pride and prudence kept me above the reach of pity—but obligation from a stranger—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: He really a stranger, and attempt to free thee. Friend, thoa hast usurped a right which here alone belongeth to me: as I enjoy the blessing which these lands produce, I own also the heart-de∣lighting privilege of dispensing those blessings to the wretched. Thou madest thyself my worldly banker, and no cash of mine in thy hands, but here I balance my account (takes a te from a pocket book).

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Madam, my master pays me, nor dare I take money from any other hand, without injuring his honour, or disobeying his command.

LG.L: Run, run, Orlando, carve on every tree,
The fair, the chaste, the inexpressive she. Exit

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: (to Twitch) But Sir, I insist you'll return him his money—Stop (going).

SP.SPEAKER: TWICTH.
SP.P: Aye, stop (olds Banks).

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Where dwelleth he?

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: I fancy, Ma'am, where he can. I under∣stand, from his discourse, that he is on his way to join a company of actors in the next town,

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: A profane stage player with such a gentle generous heart, yet so whimsically wild, like the unconscious rose, modestly shrinking from the recollec∣tion of its own grace and sweetness.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Now, my Ladyship, I'm fit to attend your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: This maiden may find out for me whither he goth (aside). Call on my steward, and thy legal demands shall be satisfied. To Twitch, who exits.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Here coachman, drive up my Lady's chariot nearer our door (alling off).

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Friend, be chearful, thine and thy sister's sorrows shall be but as an April shower.

DIV2.STAGE: Exit. Banks into his house, Lady A. and Jane.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Hilloa, friend, when does the coach set out for London?

SP.SPEAKER: WAIT.
SP.P: In about an hour, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Has the Winchester coach set out for London?

SP.SPEAKER: WAIT.
SP.P: No, Sir. Exit. Waiter.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: That's lucky, my trunk is here still—then I will not, since I've lost the fellowship of my friend Dick Buckskin, I'll travel no more. I'll try a London audience—who knows but I may get an engagement. This celestial lady quaker must be rich, and how ridi∣culous for such a poor dog as I am, even to think of her how Dick would laugh at me if he knew—I dare say by this she has released my kind host from the gripe—I should like to be certain though.

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: You'll dine here, Sir—I'm honest Bob Johnson—kept the sun these twenty years—excellent dinner on table at two.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Yet my love indeed is appetite; I'm as hungry as the sea, I can digest as much.

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: Hungry as the sea—then you won't do for my shilling ordinary. Sir, there's a very good or∣dinary at the Saracen's Head at the end of the town. Should'nt have thought indeed, of hungry foot-tra∣vellers to eat like—Coming, Sir! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P:
Ill not join this company at Winchester—no, I'll not stay in the country, hopeless eer to expect a look, except of scorn, from this lady. I wonder if she's sound out that I'm a player—I'll take a touch at the London theatre, the public there are candid and
gnerous, and before my merit can have time to raise enemies, I'll save money, and a fig for the sultan and sophy.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Aye, that's he.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: But if I fail, by heavens I'll overwhelm the manager, his empire, and himself, in one prodigious ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Ruin! O Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: What can you expect else, when you follow the young men—I've dogg'd you all the way·

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Well, was'nt I sent?

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: O, yes, you were sent—very likely—who sent you?

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: I won't tell it's my lady, because she bid me not (aside).

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: I'll keep you from shame—A find life I should have in the parish, rare fleering, if a sister of mine should stand some Sunday at church in a white sheet— and to all their flouts what could I say?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Thus, I say—My sister's wrong'd, my sister blows a bella born as high and noble as the attorney; do her justice, or by the gods, I'll lay a scene of blood shall make this haymow horrible to beadles. Say that, young Chamont.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Ecod, I believe it's full moon. You go home to your place, and mind your business. To Jane.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: My lady will be so glad I found him—I don't wonder at it, he's a fine spoken man.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Dang it, will you stand grinning here at the wild bucks.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Will you be quiet: the gentleman might wish to send her Ladyship a compliment. Ar'n't please you, Sir, if it is even a kiss between you and me, it shall go safe; for tho' you should give it to me, bro∣ther Sim can take it my lady.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: La, will you go? (puts her off).

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: To a nannery, go—to a nunnery, go, go—I'm cursedly out of spirits—but hang sorrow, I may as well divert myself—'tis meat and drink for me to see a clown—Shepherd, was't ever at court.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Then thou art damned.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Yes, like an ill-roasted egg, all on one side. Ah, little hospitality.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Eh, where's the shewman that wants my barn?—Ah, son Sim.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Is he your son, young Clodpole—take him to your wheat-stacks, and there teach him manners.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Oh, thou art the fellow that would boult out of the dirty roads into people's houses—Sim's schooling is mightily thrown away, if he has not more manners than thou.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Why, feyther, it is one of the players: he acted Tom Fool in King Larry, t'other night at Ly∣mington—I thought, I know'd him, by the face, thof he had a straw hat and a blanket about'n.—Ha, how comical that was you said.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Pellicock sat upon Jellicock-hill—pillo loc—loc.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Why feyther, that's it, he's at it again— feyther, laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, boy, I believe he's no better than he should be; the moment I saw him, says I to myself, he's a rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: There thou spoke truth to thyself for once in thy life.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: I'm glad you confess it; but her ladyship shall have all the vagrants whipt out of the country.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Vagrants, wretch —despite overwhelm thee! —only squint, and by heaven I'll beat thy blown-up body, 'till it rebound like a tennis ball.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Beat my feyther—no, no—thou must first beat me (pulls off his coat),

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Though love cool, friendship fall off, brother's divide, subjects rebel; oh, never let the sacred bond be crack'd betwixt son and father. Thou art an honest reptile (to Sim). I never a father's protection knew —never had a father to protect.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Ecod, he's not acting now.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter LANDLORD, with book, pen, and ink.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Landlord, is this Mr. Lamp here?

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: I've just opened a bottle for him in the other parlour. Exit. Gam.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM
SP.P: (to Rover) Gis's thy hand—I like thee, I don't know how 'tis, I think I could lose my life for him— but mus'nt let feyther be lick'd neither. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I'll make my entrance on the London stage boards in Bays: yes, I shall have no competitor against me. Egad, it's very hard, that a gentleman and an author, can't come to teach them, but he must break his noise, and all that. So the players are gone to dinner (to Landlord).

SP.SPEAKER: COACH.
SP.P: Any passengers for the fly?

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: No such people frequent the sun, I assure you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Sun, moon, and stars, now mind the eclipse, Mr. Johnson.

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: I heard nothing of it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: WAIT.
SP.P: Sir, two gentlemen in the parlour wish to speak with you (to Rover).

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I attend them with all respect and duty.

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: Sir, you go in the stage; as we book the passengers, what name?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I'm the bold Thunder. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: (writing) Mr. Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: I want two places in the stage coach, because I and another gentleman are going a journey.

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: Just two vacant—what name?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Avast, I go upon deck, but let me see who is my master's messmates in the cabin. (reads) Capt. M'Clallough, Counsellor Flahergan, Miss Gosing, Mr. Thunder—what's this, speak man—is there any person of that name going?

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: Book'd him this moment.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: If our voyage should be at an end before we begin; if this Mr. Thunder should be my master's son—what sort of a gentleman is he?

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: An odd sort of a gentleman—I suspect he's one of the players.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: True, Sam said 'twas some of the player's people forced him from Portsmouth school—it most be the 'Squire—shew me where he's moor'd, my old purser.

SP.SPEAKER: TRAP.
SP.P: This same old Gammon seems a surly spark.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: No-matter, his barn will hold full thirty pounds, and if we can but engage this young fellow, this Rover, he'll cram it every night he plays—he's certainly a very good actor. Now, Trap, you must enquire out a good carpenter, and be brisk about the building. I think we shall have smart business, as we stand so well for women too—Oh, here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: TRAP.
SP.P: Knap him on any terms.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Gentlemen, your most obedient—the waiter told me—

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: Pray sit down, good Sir. Sir, to our bet∣ter acquaintance (drinks).

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Hav'n't a doubt, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: Only suffer me to put up your name to play with us six nights, and twelve guineas are yours.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I thank you: I must confess your offer is liberal, but my friends have flattered me into a sort of opinion, that encourages me to take a touch at the capital.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: Oh, my dear Sir, a London theatre is very dangerous ground.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Why I may fail, and Gods may groan, and ladies cry, the aukward creature; but should I top my part thus, shall not gods applaud, and ladies sigh, the charming fellow, and managers take me by the hand, and treasurers smile upon me, as they count the shining guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: But suppose—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Aye, suppose the contrary, I have a certain friend here in my coat pocket (fls for it) —Zounds, where is it—Oh, the devil, I gave it to discharge my kind host. Going to London, and not master of five shillings (aside). Well, Sir, if you'll make it twenty pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: Well, be it so.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Sir, I engage with you; call a rehearsal when and where you please, and I'll attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: Sir, I'll step for the cast book, and you shall choose your characters.

SP.SPEAKER: TRAP.
SP.P: And I'll write the play-bill directly.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Since I must remain here some time, and hav'n't the most distant hope of ever speaking to this goddess again, I wish I had enquired her name, that I might know how to keep out of her way.

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: There's the gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Very well. (Exit. Land.) What cheer, mas∣ter 'Squire?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: What cheer, eh, my hearty.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: The very face of his father—And ar'n't you asham'd of yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Why, yes, I am sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Do you know, if I had you at the gang-way I'd give you a neater dozen than ever you got from your schoolmaster's cat-o-nine-tails.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: You woud'n't sure?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: I would sure.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Indeed, pleasant enough. Who is this genius?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: I've dispatch'd a shallop to tell Lady Ama∣ranth you're here.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: You hav'n't?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: I have.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Now who the devil's this Lady Amaranth?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: I expect her chariot every moment, and when it comes, you'll get into it, and I'll set you down genteely at her house, then I'll have obeyed my or∣ders, and hope your father will be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: My father—who is he, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Pha, leave off your fun, and prepare to ask his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!—my worthy friend, you're quite wrong in this affair—upon my word, I'm not the per∣son you take me for (going).

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: You don't go, tho' you've got your name down in the stage-coach book.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Mr. Thunder—stage-coach book—this must be some curious mistake—ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Oh, my lad, your father, Sir George, will soon change your note.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Will he?—he must first give me one. Sir George—then my father's a Knight, it seems—very good, faith—ha, ha, ha. I'm not the gentleman you think, upon my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: I ought not to think you any gentleman, for giving your honour in a false word.

SP.SPEAKER: WAIT.
SP.P: Her Ladyship's carriage is at the door, and I fancy, Sir, it's you the coachman wants (to John).

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Yes, it's me. (Exit Waiter). I attend your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: The choice is made, and I've my Ran∣ger's dress in my trunk, Cousin of Buckingham, thou sage grave man.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Since you will buckle fortune on my back, to bear the burthen whether I will or no, I must have patience to endure the load; but if black scan∣dal, or foul fac'd—

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Black, foul-fac'd—dam'me, my face was as fair as yours before I went to sea.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Your mere enforcement shall acquaintance me.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Man, don't stand preaching parson Palmer, come to the chariot.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Aye, to the chariot bear me—Bucephalus among the billows. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: THO' thou hast settled that distressed gentleman's debts, let his sister come unto me, and remit a quarter's rent to all my tenants.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: As thou biddest it, I have discharged from the pound, the widow's cattle; but shall I let the law∣suit drop against the farmer's son, who did shoot the pheasant?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Yea; but instantly turn from my service the gamekeeper's man, that did kill the fawn while it was eating from his hand—we should hate guile, tho' we love venison.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Since the death of old Dovehouse (who, tho' one of the faithful, was an active man) this part of the country is infested with covetous men, called rob∣bers; and I have, in thy name, said unto the people, whoever apprehendeth one of these I will reward, yea with thirty pieces of gold, (knocking without.) That beating of one brass against another at thy door, pro∣claimeth the approach of vanity, whose heart swelleth at an empty sound. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P:
But my heart is possessed with the idea of that wandering youth, whose benevolence induced him to part with, perhaps his all, to free the unhappy debtor. His person is amiable, his addresses (ac∣cording
to the worldly modes) formed to please and to delight—but he's poor—is that a crime?—perhaps meanly born—but one good action is an illstrious pe∣digree. I feel I love him, and in that word are birth, same, and riches.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Oh, Madam, my Lady, an't please you.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Did'st thou find the young man, that I may return him the money he paid for my tenant?

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: I found him, Ma'am, and I found him, and he talked of what he said.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: What did he say?

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: He said, Ma'am, and says he—I'll be hang'd, Ma'am, if he didn't talk about ruin, now I think of that—but if he hadn't gone to London in the stage coach.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Is he gone?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Oh, my Lady, mayhap John Dory is not the man to be sent after young Gentlemen that scam∣per from school, and run about the country a play act∣ing. Pray walk up stairs, Master Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Hast thou brought my kinsman hither?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Well then, I ha'n't—will you only walk up if you please, Master Harry?

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Will you walk up, if you please, Master Harry?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Friendship requireth, yet I'm not dis∣posed to communicate with company.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Oh, bless me, Ma'am, if it isn't—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV,
SP.P: 'Tis I, Hamlet the Dane—thus far into the bowels of the land we march'd on—John, the bloody devouring bear—

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: He call'd me bl in the coach.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: This Lady Amaranth—by heavens, the very angel quaker.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: The generous youth, my cousin Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: He's for you, make the most of him.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE:
SP.P: Oh, how happy my Lady is—he looks so charming now he's fine.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Harkee—she's as rich as an India-man, and I tell you, your father wishes you would grapple her by the heart. There's an engagement between these two vessels, but little Cupid's the only man that's to take'em in tow, so come. (to Jane.)

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Ma'am, a'n't I to wait on you?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: No, my lass you're to wait on me.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Wait on you!—lack-a-day, am I?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: By this, Sir George is come to the inn. Without letting the younker know, I'll bring him here, and surprise both father and son with a joyful meeting (aside). Now court her, you mad devil (to Rover). Come, now usher me down like a lady, (to Jane).

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Yes, there's love between them, I see it in their eyes—bless the dear couple—this way, Mr. Sailor Gentleman. Exeunt Jane and John.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: (aside) By heavens, a most delectable woman.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Cousin, when I saw thee in the village free the sheep from the wolf, why did'st not tell me thou wer't son to my uncle, Sir George?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Because, my Lady, I did not know it my∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Why wou'd'st thou vex thy father, and quit thy school?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: A truant disposition—good my Lady brought me from Whittemberg.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Thy father designs thee for his dange∣rous profession—but is thy inclination turned to the voice of trumpets and sounds of mighty slaughter?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P:
Why, Ma'am, as for old Boreas, my dad, when the blast of war blows in his ears, he's a tyger in his fierce resentment; but for me I think it a pity
—so it is—that villainous saltpetre should be digg'd-out of the bowels of the harmless earth, which many a good tall fellow hath destroy'd, with wound and guns and drums—Heaven save the mark.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Indeed thou art tall, my cousin, and grown of comely stature—our families have long been separated.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: They have, since Adam I believe (aside) —then Lady, let that sweet bud of love now ripen to a beauteous flower.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Love!

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Excellent wench—perdition catch my soul but I do love thee: and when I love thee not—Chaos is come again.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Thou art of a happy disposition▪

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: If I were now to die, it were to be happy! Let our senses dance in concert to the joyful minutes; and this, and this, the only discord make (embracing).

DIV2.STAGE: Enter JANE, with cake and wine.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Ma'am, an't please you, Mr. Zachariah bid me—

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Why you fancy yourself Cardinal Wolsey in this family

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: No, Sir, I'm not Cardinal Woolsey, I'm only my Lady's maid here.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: A bowl of cream for your Catholic Ma∣jesty.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Cream! no, Sir;—that's wine and water.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: You get no water—take the wine, great po∣tentate (Gives Lady A. a glass, and drinks).

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Madam, my father begs leave—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Go, go, thou sallow Pomona. Exit. Jane.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Eh! zouns, my manager!

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P:
I hope her Ladyship hav'n't found out 'twas I had Banks arrested (aside.) Wou'd your Ladyship give leave for this honest man and comrades to act a
few plays in this town, 'cause I have let 'em my barn —'twill be some little help to me, my Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: My Lady, I understand these affairs; leave me to settle them.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: True, these are delusions; as a woman I understand not—but by my cousin's advice I will abide —ask his consent?

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: So, I must pay my respects to the young 'Squire (aside). An't please your honour, if a poor man like me (bows) dare offer his humble duty.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Can'st thou bow to a vagrant, eh, little hos∣pitality! Exit. Gam.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: Please your honour, if I may presume to hope, you'll be graciously pleased to take our little squadron under your honour's protection.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: What say'st thou, Henry?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Aye, where's Henry?—true—that's me— strange I should always forget my name, and not half an hour ago I was christened (aside). Hark ye, do you play yourself, fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, and I've just now engaged a new actor one Mr. Rover—such an actor!

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: If such is your best actor, you sha'nt have my permission—my dear Madam, the damndest fellow in the world—get along out of the town, or dam'me, I'll have you all, man, woman, and child, rag and fiddle-stick, clap'd into the whirligig.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Good man, abide not here.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: What, you scoundrel—now if this new actr you brag of, that crack of your company, was any thing like a gentleman.—

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: Why, since it isn't—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: It is, my dear friend, if I was really the poor strolling dog you thought me, I should tread your four boards, and crow the cock of your barn-door fowl —but as Fate has ordain'd, I'm a gentleman, and son to Sir—what the devil's my father's name (aside) You must be content to murder Shakespear, without making me an accomplice.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P:
But, my most gentle Sir, I and my trea∣surer Trap, have trumpeted your fame ten miles round
the country—the bills are posted, the candles bought, the stage built, the fiddlers engag'd—all on the tip-toe of expectation—we should have to-morrow night an overflow—ay, thirty pounds, dear worthy Sir; you would not go to ruin a whole community and their fam∣lies, that now depend on the exertion of your brillant talents?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I never was uniform but in one maxim, that is, though I do but little good, to hurt nobody but myself.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Since thou hast promised, much as I prize the adherence to the customs in which I was brought up, thou shalt not sully thy honour, by a breach of thy word; for truth is more shining than beaten gold—play, if it can bring good to these people.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: This falleth out well; for I have bidden all the gentry round unto my house warming, and these pleasantries may afford them innocent and chear∣ful entertainment.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: True, my Lady, your guests an't Quakers, though you are; and when we ask people to our house we study to please them, not ourselves; but if you do furbish up a play or two, the Muses shan't honour that churlish fellow's barn.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Barn! no, that gallery shall be thy theatre; and inspite of the grave doctrine of Ephraim Smooth, my friends and I will behold and rejoice in thy pranks, my pleasant cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: My kind, my charming Lady! —Hey!— brighten up bully Lamp, carpenters, taylors, mana∣gers, distribute your box tickets for my Lady's gal∣lery—come, gentle cousin, the actors are at hand, and by their shew you shall know all that you are like to know. Exit Lamp. Exeunt Lady and Rover.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, AN APARTMENT IN AN INN.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P:
Though I went back to Portsmouth Aca∣demy with a contrite heart to continue my studies, yet from my father's angry letter, I dread the woful storm at our first meeting. I fancy the people at the inn
don't recollect me: it reminds me of my pleasant friend poor Jack Rover; I wonder where he is now.

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: And brings to my mind a certain strolling acquaintance of mine, poor Dick Buskin.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Then I desire, Sir, you'll turn Dick Bus∣kin out of your head.

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: Can't Sir; the dear, good-natur'd, wicked son of—I beg your honour's pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Midg, you must, soon as I am drest, stp out and enquire whose house my father is at—I didn't think he had any acquaintance in this part of the coun∣try; sound what humour he is in, and how the land lies, before I venture into his presence.

SP.SPEAKER: WAIT.
SP.P: Sir, the room is ready for you to dress Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I shall only throw off my boots, and you'll shake a little powder in my hair,

SP.SPEAKER: MIDG.
SP.P: Then, hey puff, I shoulder my curling-irons.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: I can hear nothing of these deserters— by my first intelligence, they'll not venture up to London; they must be still lurking about the country; Landlord, have any suspicious looking person put in at your house?

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: Yes Sir, now and then.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What did you do with them?

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: Why, Sir, when a man calls for liquor, that I think has got no money, I make him pay before-hand.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Damn your liquor, you self-interested porpoise, chattering about your own private affairs, when public good, or fear of general calamity, should be the only compass. These fellows I am in pursuit of, run from their ships; and if our navy is unmanned, what becomes of you and your house, you dunghill cormorant?

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: This is a very abusive sort of a gentleman, but he has a full pocket, or he wou'd not be so saucy (aside). Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: This rscal, I believe, does not know m Sir George Thunder—wind, still variable, blows my affairs athwart each other—Do not know what's become of my runagate son Harry—and when my Lady niece, squeezing up the plumage of our illustrious family in her little mean Quaker's bonnet—I must to town after—'blood, when I catch my son Harry— Oh, here's John Dory.
Have you taken the places in the London coach for me?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN,
SP.P: Ha!—Hey, your honour, is that yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: No, I'm besides myself—where's my son?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: What's o'clock?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Why do you talk of clocks or time-pieces?—all glass's, reckoning and log-line, are run wild with me.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: If it's two, your son is this moment walking with Lady Amaranth in her garden.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: With Lady Amaranth?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: If half after, they're cast anchor, to est themselves among the poses; if three, they're got up again; if four, they're picking a bit of cramm'd fowl; and if half after, they're picking their teeth, and crack∣ing walnuts over a bottle of calcavella.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: My son!—my dear friend, where did you find him?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: I found him where he was, and I left him where he is.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What!—and he come to Lady Ama∣ranth's?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: No, I brought him there from this house in her carriage—I won't tell him Master Harry went among the players, or he'd never forgive him (aside) —Oh, such a merry, civil, crazy, crack-brain'd—the very picture of your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What, he's in high spirits—ha, ha, ha! the dog—I hope he had discretion enough tho', to throw a little gravity over his mad humour, before his prudent cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: He threw himself upon his knees before her, and that did quite as well.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Made love to her already!—ha, ha, ha!—oh, the impudent, cunning villain—what, and may be he—

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Indeed he did give her a smack.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Indeed, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Oh, he threw his arms about her as eager, as I wou'd to catch a falling decanter of Madeira.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Huzza, victoria!—here will be a junc∣ture of two bouncing estates—but confound the money! —John, you shall have a bowl for a jolly-boat to swim in. Roll in a puncheon of rum, a hogshead of sugar, shake an orchard of oranges, and let the landlord drain his fish-pond yonder—a bumper, a bumper, &c. (sings.)

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Then, my good master, Sir George, I'll order a bowl, since you're in the humour for it.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: And so the wild rogue is this instant rat∣tling up her prim Ladyship? Eh? is'n't this he? Left her already.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I must have left my cane in this room— Eh, my father?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: (Looking at his watch.) Just half after four: why Harry, you've made great haste in crack∣ing your walnuts.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Yes; he has heard of my frolics with the players (aside). Dear father, if you'll but forgive me—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Why indeed, you have acted very bad.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Sir, it should be considered I was but a novice.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: However, I shall think of nothing now but your benefit.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Very odd his approving of— (aside) I thank you, Sir; but if it's agreeable to you, I have done with Benefits.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: If I was not the best of fathers, you might indeed hope none from me; but no matter if you can but get the Fair Quaker.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Or the Humours of the Navy, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What! how dare you reflect on the Hu∣mours of the Navy? The Navy has very good hu∣mours, or I'd never see your dog's face again, you vil∣lain. But I'm cool—eh, boy, a snug easy chariot.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I'll order it; desire my father's carriage to draw up.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Mine, you rogue, I've none: I mean Lady Amaranth's.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, Lady Amaranth's chariot.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What are you at? I meant that you left this house in.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Sir, I left this house on foot.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What, with John Dory?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: No, Sir, with Jack Rover.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Why John has been a rover to be sure; but now he's settled: I've made him my valet-de-chambre.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Made him your valet! why Sir, where did you meet with him?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Zounds! I meet him abroad, and meet him on shore—in the cabin and steerage—gallery and forecastle—He sail'd round the world with me.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Strange this: I understood he had been in the East Indies, but he never told me he knew you; but indeed, he only knew me by the name of Dick Buskin.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Then how came he to bring you to Lady Amaranth's?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Bring me where?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Answer me: an't you now come from her Ladyship?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Ha, this is a lie of John's to enhance his own services. Then you have not been there.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I don't know where you mean, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Yes, it's all a brag of John's; but I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: The rum and sugar is ready; but as for the fish-pond—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: I'll kick you into it, you thirsty old grampus.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Will you? Then I'll make a comical roasted orange.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: How dare you say you brought my son to Lady Amaranth's.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: And who says I did'n't?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: He that best knows only, Dick Buskin here.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Then Mr. Buckskin mus'n't shoot off great guns for his amusement.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: There, what do you say to that?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I say, 'tis false.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: False!—shiver my hulk, Mr. Buckskin, if you were a lyon's skin I'd curry your hide for this. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: No, no—John's honest—I see through it now—the puppy has seen her; perhaps he has the impudence not to like her—and so blow up this confu∣sion and perplexity only to break off a marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: What does he mean—I'll assure you—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Damn your assurance, you ungrateful, disobedient—but I'll not part with you till I confront you with Lady Amaranth herself, face to face: and if I prove you have been deceiving me, I'll launch you into the wide ocean of life, without a rudder, compass, grog, or tobacco. Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P:
THE fanciful flights of my pleasant cousin enchant my senses; this book he gave me to read con∣taineth good morals. The man Shakespear, that did write it, they call immortal; he must indeed have been filled with divine spirit. I understand, from my cousin, the origin of plays were religious mysteries;
that, freed from the superstition of early, and grossness of latter times, the stage is now become the vehicle of delight and morality;—if so, to hear a good play is taking the wholsome draught of precept from a gol∣den cup, emboss'd with gems: yet giving my counte∣nance to have one in my house, and even to act in it myself, prove the ascendancy my dear Harry has over my heart. Ephraim Smooth is much scandalized at these doings.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: This mansion is now become the tabernacle of Baal.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Then abide not in it.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: 'Tis full of the wicked ones.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Stay not among the wicked ones.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I must shut my ears (loud laugh).

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: And thy mouth also, good Ephraim: I have bidden my cousin Harry to my house, and will not set bounds to thy mirth, to gratify thy spleen, and shew my own inhospitality.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Why dost thou suffer him to put into the hands of thy servants books of tragedies, and books of comedies, preludes, and interludes—yea, all lues; my spirit doth wax wrath. I say unto thee, a play∣house is a school for the old dragon, and a play-book the primer of Beelzebub.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: This is one; mark. (reads) "Not the King's crown, nor the deputed sword, the marshal's truncheon, nor the judge's robe, becometh them with one half so good a grace as mercy doth. Oh! think on that, and mercy then will breathe within your lives like men new made." Doth Belzebub speak such words?

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Thy kinsman hath made all thy servants actors.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: To act well is good service.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Here cometh the damsel for whom my heart yearneth.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Oh, Ma'am! his honour, the Sqire, says the play's to be As You Like It.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I like it not.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: He's given me my character; I am to be Miss Audrey, and brother Sim's to be William of the Forest, as it were; but how am I to get my part by heart?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: By often reading it.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Well, I don't know but that's as good as any other.—I must study my part—the Gods give us joy. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Thy maidens skip like young kids.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Then do thou go skip along with them.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Mary, thou should'st be obey'd in thine own house, and I will do thy bidden.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Ah, thou hypocrite, to obey is easy, when the heart commands.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Oh, my charming cousin, how agree you and Rosalind? Are you almost perfect? What, old Clytus! why you're like any angry fiend broke in amongst the laughing gods; come, come, I'll have nothing here but quips, and cranks, and wreathed smiles.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: He says we must not have this amuse∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: But I have a voice potential, double as the Duke's, and I say we must.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Nay.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Yea, by Jupiter I swear—Aye, (fiddle without)

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: The man of sin rubbeth the hair of the horse to the bowels of the cat.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: Now, if agreeable to your Ladyship, we'll go over your song.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: I'm content.

DIV2.STAGE: Lamp begins to play, Ephraim pushes his elbow, which puts him out of tune—plays again—Eph. joggs as before.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: What, Sir, do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Now do, my good friend, be quiet—Come begin.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Friend, this is a land of liberty, and I've as much right to move my elbows, as thou hast thine. (Rover pushes him) Why dost thou do so friend?

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Friend, this is a land of liberty, and I have as much right to move my elbows as thou hast to move thine (pushes him off). A fanatical puppy.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: But, Harry, do you people of fashion act these follies themselves?

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: Aye, and scramble for the top parts as eager as for stars, ribbands, place, or pension: Lamp, decorate the seats out smart and theatrical, and drill the servants that I have given the small parts Exit Lamp.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: I wish'd for some entertainment, in which people now take delight, to please those I have invited, but will convert those follies into a charitable purpose: tickets of this play shall be delivered to my friends gratis, but money to their amount I will, from my own purse (after rewarding the assistants) distri∣bute among the indigent of the village; thus, while we amuse our friends, and perhaps please ourselves, we shall make the poor happy.

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: An angel!—if Sir George does'n't soon arrive to blow me, I may, I think, marry her angelic Ladyship—but will that be honest?—she's nobly born —tho' I suspect I had ancestors too, if I knew who they were. I entered this house the poorest wight in England, and what must she imagine when I'm dis∣covered? That I'm a scoundrel; and consequently, though I should possess her hand and fortune, instead of loving she'll despise me (sits.) I want a friend now to consult with—deceive her I will not—poor Dick Buskin wants money more than myself, yet this is a measure I'm sure he'd scorn. No no, I must not.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Now I hope my passionate father will be convinced that this is the first time I was ever under this roof, What beau is here?—astonishing! my old strolling friend (sits down unperceived).

SP.SPEAKER: ROVER.
SP.P: I don't know what to do.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Nor what to say.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Dick Buskin, ha, ha, ha,—my dear fellow —think of the devil, and—I was just thinking of you, —'pon my soul, Dick, I am happy to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: But, Jack, how the devil have you found me out?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Found you, I'm sure I wonder how the deuce you found me out—oh, the news of my intended play has brought you.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: He does not as yet know who I am, so I'll carry it on. (aside.) Then you have broke your engagement with Truncheon, at Winchester?—figur∣ing away in your stage-cloaths too, really.—Tell me what you are here, Jack?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Will you be quiet with your Jacking, I'm now 'Squire Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I've been press'd into this service by an old man of war, who found me at the inn, and insisted I'm son to Sir George Thunder. In that character, I flatter myself, I have won the heart of the charming lady of this house.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Now the mystery is out— (aside) —then it's my friend Jack has been brought here for me.— Do you know the young gentleman they take you for?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Not I; but I flatter myself he is honoured in his representative.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Upon my soul, Jack, you're a tight fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Now I can put some pounds in your pocket —you shall be employed—we're getting up As You Like It—let's see in the cast, have I a part for you— egad, I'll take Touchstone from Lamp, you shall have it, my boy—I'd resign Orlando to you, with any other Rosalind, but the lady of the mansion plays it herself.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: The very lady my father intended for me. (aside) Do you love her, Jack?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: To distraction—but I'll not have her.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: No—why?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: She thinks me a gentleman, and I'll not convince her I'm a rascal; I'll go on with our play, as the produce is appropriated to a good purpose, then lay down my 'Squireship, bid adieu to my heavenly Rosalind, and exit for ever from her house, poor Jack Rover.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: The generous fellow I ever thought him, and he shan't lose by it—if I could make him believe (aside) —Well, this is the most whimsical affair— you've anticipated me—you'll scarce believe that I'm come here purposely to pass myself for this young Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I am.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: (without) Harry, where are you?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Who's that?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I'll try it—my father will be cursedly vext—no matter. (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Somebody called Harry—zounds, if the real Simon Pure, that is, should be arrived, I'm in a pure way.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Be quiet, that's my confederate, he's to personate the father, Sir George, he started the scheme —having heard that an union was intended, and Sir George immediately expected, our plan is, if I can, before his arrival, flourish myself into the lady's good graces, and whip her up, as she's an heiress.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: So, you have turn'd fortune hunter. Then 't'was for this plan you parted from me on the road, standing like a figure-post, you walk up this way, and I'll walk down this—why, Dick, I did not know you was so great a rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: I did not know my fort lay that way, till convinc'd by this experienced stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: He must be a damn'd impudent old scoun∣drel—who is he, do I know him?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Why, no, I hope not. (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I'll step down stairs, and have the honor of kicking him.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Stop, I wou'd'n't have him hurt, neither.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: What's his name?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: His name is Abrawang.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Abrawang, Abrawang—I never heard of him—but, Dick, why did you let him persuade you into this affair?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Why, faith, I would have been off it, but when once he takes a project into his head, the devil can't drive it out of him.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Yes, but the constables may drive him into Winchester goal.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Your opinion of our intended exploit has made me ashamed of myself—Harkee, Jack, do you punish and frighten my adviser, do you still keep up your character of young 'Squire Thunder—you can easily do that, as he, no more than myself, has never seen the 'Squire.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: But, by heavens, I'll not be such a damned rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Yes, but Jack, if you can marry her, her fortune is a snug thing; besides, if you love each other, I tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Hang her fortune—my love's more noble than the world, prizes not quantity of dirty lands— Oh, Dick, she's the most lovely—think of her conde∣scension—why she consented to play in our play, and you shall see her, you rogue, you shall.

LG.L: Her worth being mounted on the wind,
Through all the world bears Rosalind. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, this is the drollest adven∣ture—Rover little suspects that I am the identical 'Squire Thunder that he personates—I'll lend him my character a little longer—yes, this offer is a most ex∣cellent opportunity of making my poor friend's fortune, without injuring any body. If possible, he shall have her, I can't regret the loss of charms I never knew, and for an estate, my father is competent to all my wishes. Lady Amaranth, by marrying Jack Rover, will gain a man of honour, which she might lose in an Earl—it may teaze my father a little at first, but he's a good old fellow in the main, and when I think he comes to know my motive!—Eh, this must be she—an elegant woman, faith—now for a spanking lie, to continue her in the belief that Jack is the man she thinks him.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Who art thou, friend?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY,
SP.P: Madam, I've scarce time to warn you against the danger you're in, of being imposed upon by your uncle, Sir George,

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: He has heard of your Ladyship's parti∣ality for his son, but is so incensed at the irregularity of his conduct, he intends, if possible, to disinherit him, and to present me hither, to pass me on you for him, designing to treat the poor young gentleman himself as an impostor, in hopes you'll banish him from your heart and house.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: I thank thee, friend, for thy caution —is Sir George such a parent—what's thy name?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Richard Buskin, Ma'am, the stage is my profession—in the 'Squire's late excursion we contracted an intimacy, and I saw so many good qualites in him, that I could not think of being the instrument of his ruin, nor deprive your Ladyship of so good a husband as I am certain he will make you.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Then Sir George intends to disown him.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY
SP.P: Yes Ma'am, I've this moment told the young gentleman of it; he's determined, for a jest, to return the compliment, by seeming to treat Sir George himself as an impostor.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, t'will be a just retaliation, and indeed what my uncle deserveth, for his cruel in∣tentions both to his son and me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: (without) What has he run away again?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: That's mine uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Yes, here's my father, and my standing out that I'm not his son, will raise him into the heat of a battle, ha, ha, ha, (aside) Here he is, Madam, now mind how he'll dub me a 'Squire.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P:
Well my Lady, was'nt it as my wild rogue set you, all tho' calcavell as capers, you've been cutting in the garden. You see here I have brought him into line of battle again—you villain, why do you drop a stern there, throw a salute shot, buss her bob-stays,
bring to, and come down straight as a mast, you dog.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Uncle, who is this?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Who is he—egad, that's an odd question, to the fellow that has been cracking your walnuts.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: He's bad at his lesson.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Certainly, when he ran from school— why don't you speak, you lubber, you are cursed mo∣dest—before I came, 'twas all down among the po∣sies; here, my Lady, take from a father's hand, Harry Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: That is what I may not.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: There, I thought you would disgust her, you flat fish.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: (Takes Rover's hand.) Here, take from my hand Harry Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Oh, this is your sham Sir George,— (Apart to Harry)

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Yes, I've been telling the Lady, and still seem to humour him.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I shan't though; how do you Abrawang?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Abrawang!

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: You look like a good actor; aye, that's very well indeed. Never, never lose sight of your cha∣racter; you know Sir George is a noisy, turbulent, wicked old knave; bravo! Pout your under lip, purse your brows:—Very well; but damn it, Abrawang, you should have put a little red on your nose—mind a rule, never play an old man without a red nose.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: I'm in such a fury.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Well we know that.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Who is this?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Some puppy unknown.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: And you don't know this gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Excellent well! he's a fishmonger.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Ah, What!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Yes; father and son are determin'd not to know each other.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P:
Come, Dick, give the Lady a specimen of
