your talent, Motleys, your only wear, ha, ha, ha, a fool I met, a fool in the forest. Here comes Audry.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: La! warrent, what features!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: 'Sblood! what's this?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: A homely thing, Sir, but she's my own.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Your's, you most audacious!—What this slut?

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: I thank the Gods for my slutishness.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: (To Rover,) You know this youth.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: My friend, Horatio; I wear him in my heart, yea, in my heart of hearts, as I do this— (kisses her.)

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Such freedom with my niece, before my face. Do you know that Lady? Do you know my son, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Be quiet; Jaffier has discovered the plot, and you can't deceive the senate.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Yes, my conscience would not let me carry it through.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Aye, his conscience hanging about the neck of his heart, says good Launcelot and good Gobbo, or as aforesaid good Launcelot Gobbo, take to thy heels and run away.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Why, my Lady, explain—scoundrel and puppy unknown.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Ma'am, I forgot to tell you our old neigh∣bour Banks and his sister wants you.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: I come—Uncle, I've heard thy father was kind to theee; return that kindness to thy child— if the lamb in wanton play doth fall amongst the waters, the shepherd taketh him out, instead of plunging him in deeper till he dieth—though thy hairs now be grey, I'm told once was flaxen; in short, he's too old in folly, who cannot excuse youth. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: I'm an old fool! well, that's damn'd civil of you, Madam Niece; and I'm a grey shepherd, with his lambs in the ditch; but as for you, Mr. Goat, I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: My dear Abrawang, give up the game; her Ladyship in seeming to take you for her uncle, has been only humming you—What, the devil, don't you think the divine creature knows her own true-born uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Certainly, to be sure she knows me.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Will you have done?—Zounds, man, my honored father was here himself this day—her ladyship knows his person.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Your honored father, and who the devil's your honor'd self?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Now, by my father's son, that's myself it shall be sun, or moon, or Cheshire-cheese—I budge still crop and cropp'd.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What do you bawl out to me about Che∣shire-cheese.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: And I say; as the saying is, your friend has told me all; but to convince you of my forgiveness, in our play, as you're rough and tough, I cast your character the Wrestler—I'll do Orlando, kick up your heels before the whole court.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: I'll—why, dam'me, I'll—and you, you undutiful chick of an old pelican (Lifts up his cane.)

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: What are you at here, cudgelling people about?—But, Mr. Buckskin, I've a word to say to you in private.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Buckskin, take that (strikes him.)

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Why dam'me, Mr. Abrawang, you're a most obstinate drum, and very—

DIV2.STAGE: Enter LAMP, TRAP, JANE, and SERVANT MAID.

SP.SPEAKER: LAMP.
SP.P: All the world's a stage, and all men and women—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: The men are rogues, and the women hussies. (Beats them off, and strikes Rover)

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: A blow, Essex, a blow, an old rascally im∣postor; stigmatize me with a blow—I must not put up with it.—Zounds! I shall be tweak'd by the nose all round the country. If I can get the country lad to steal me a pair of pistols, strike me, so may this arm dash him to the earth like a dead dog, despite, pride, shame, and the name of villain light on me, if I don't bring you Mr. Abrawang. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Madam, I would have paid the rent of my little cottage; but I dare say it was without your Ladyship's consent that your Steward has turned me out, and put my neigbour in possession.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: My Steward oppress the poor! I did not know it indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: The pangs of adversity I could bear; but the innocent partner of my misfortunes, my unhappy sister—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: I did desire Ephraim to send for thy sister; did she dwell with thee, and both now without a home? let her come to mine.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: The hand of misery hath struck me beneath your notice.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Thou dost mistake; to need my assistance is the highest claim to my attention—let me see her. (Exit Banks.) I could chide myself that these pastimes have turned mine eyes from the house of woe. Ah, think ye proud and happy affluent, how many in your dancing moments pine in want, drink their salt tears —their morsel the bread of misery, and shrinking from the cold blast, into their cheerless hovels! Enter BANKS introducing AMELIA. Thou art welcome: I feel myself interested in thy concern.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: I judge thou wert not always unhappy, tell me thy condition, then I shall better know how to serve thee: is thy brother thy sole kindred?

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: I had a husband and a son.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Widow, if it is real, not images, thou wouldest forget—impart to me thy story, 'tis rumour'd in the village thy brother was a clergyman, tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Madam, he was; but he has lost his early patron, and he's now poor and unbeneficed.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: But thy husband.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P:
By this brother's advice now (twenty years
since) I was prevailed on to listen to the addresses of a young sea officer, for my brother had been chaplain in the navy; but, to our surprize and mortification, we discovered, by the honesty of a sailor, in whom we put confidence, that the Captain's design was only to decoy me into a seeming marriage; our humble friend intreated of us to put the deceit on his master, by concealing from him that my brother was not in orders; he, flattered with the hopes of procuring me an establishment, gave into supposed imposition, and performed the ceremony.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Duplicity, even with a good intent, is ill.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Madam, the event has justified your censure, for my husband, not knowing himself really bound by any legal tie, abandoned me—I followed him to the Indies; distracted, till seeing him, I left my infant at one of our settlements; but after a fruitless search, on my return, I found the friend, to whose care I committed my child, was compelled to retire from the ravages of war, but where I could not hear—rent with agonizing pangs, without a child or husband, I again saw England, and my brother, who wounded himself with remorse for being the cause of my misfortunes, secluded himself from all joys of social life, and invited me to partake the comforts of solitude in that asylum, from whence we have both just now been driven.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: My pity can do thee no good, yet must I pity thee; but resignation to what must be, may restore peace; if my means can procure thee comfort, they are at thy pleasure—come let thy griefs subside—in∣stead of thy cottage, accept thou and thy brother every convenience that my mansion can afford.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Madam, I can only thank you with (weeps)

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: My thanks are here—come thou shalt be chearfully—I will introduce thee to my sprightly cousin Harry, and his father, my humorous uncle— we have delights going forward that may amuse thee.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Kind Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Come, uncle, though a quaker, thou see'st I'm merry—the sweetest joy of wealth and power is to cheer one another's drooping heart, and wipe from the palid cheek the tear of sorrow!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter three Men, dressed as Sailors.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st SALOR.
SP.P: WELL, lads, what's to be done?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d SAIL.
SP.P: We've long been upon our shifts, and after all our tricks, twists, and turns, as London was too hot for us, a trip to Portsmouth was a hit.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st SAIL.
SP.P: Aye, but since the cash we touched upon, pretending to be able bodied seamen, is now come to the last shilling, and as we deserted, means of fresh supply must be thought on to take us to London.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d SAIL.
SP.P: Aye, now to recruit the pocket, with∣out hazarding the neck.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st SAIL.
SP.P: By an advertisement posted on the stocks yonder, there are collectors on this road, thirty guineas offered by the quaker lady, owner of the estas round here—I wish we could knap any straggler to bring before her, a quaker will only require yea for an oath, we might pick up this thirty guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d SAIL.
SP.P: Yes, but we must take care, if we fall into the hands of this gentleman that's in pursuit of us—'Sdeath, is not that his man, the old boatswain?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st SAIL.
SP.P: Don't run, I think we three are a match for him.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d SAIL.
SP.P: Let's keep up our characters of sailors, we may get something out of him; a pitiful story makes such an impression on the soft heart of a true tar, that he'll open his hard hand and drop you his last guinea—if we can but make him believe we were pressed, we have him, only mind me.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: To rattle my lanthorn, Sir George's tem∣per now always blows a hurricane.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d SAIL.
SP.P: What cheer?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Ha, boy.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st SAIL.
SP.P: Bob up with your speaking trumpet.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d SAIL.
SP.P:
D'ye see, brother, this is the thing— Enter SIR GEORGE behind, unseen. We three hands, just come home after a long voyage,
were pressed in the river, and without letting us see our friends brought round to Portsmouth, and then we entered freely—'cause why, we had no choice— then we run—we hear some gentleman's in chace of us, and as the shots are all out, we'll surrender.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Surrender—then you have no shots left, indeed—let's see (feeling his pocket) I hav'n't the load∣ing of a gun about me now, and this same Monsieur Poverty is a bitter enemy.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: (aside) 'Tis the deserters I'm after.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Meet me in an hour's time in the little wood yonder, I'll raise the wind to blow you into a safe lattitude—Keep out to sea, my masters the rock you'll cetainly split upon.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d SAIL.
SP.P: This is the first time we ever saw you, but we'll steer by your chart, for I never knew one seaman betray another. Exit Men.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Then they have been pressed— I can't blame them so much for running away.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Yes, Sir George would certainly hang them.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: You lie; they shall eat beef and drink the King's health—run and tell them so—stop, I'll tell them myself.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Now you are yourself, and a kind gentleman, as you used to be.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Since these idle rogues are inclined to return to their duty, they shan't want sea stores; take this money—but I'll meet them myself, and advise them as I would my own children. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Which way did this Mr. Abrawang take?— Dick Buskin, I think, has no suspicion of my intention, and since Sim has, without making an alarm, pro∣cured these pistols, such a cholerick spark will fight. I dare say. If I fall, or even survive this affair, I'll leave the field of love and the fair prize to the young gentleman I've personated, for I'm determined to see Lady Amaranth no more—Oh, here comes Abrawang.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Now to relieve these sea gulls—they must be hovering about this place.—Ha, puppy unknown!

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: You're the very man I was seeking for— you're not ignorant, Mr. Abrawang?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Mr. What?—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: You'll not resign your title—oh, very well, I'll indulge you—Sir George Thunder, you honored me with a blow.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Did'n't hurt you.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, Sir, but let me proceed like a gen∣tleman; as it's my pride to reject even favors, no man shall offer me an injury.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Eh!

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: In rank we're equal.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Are we, faith?—the English of all this is, we're to fight.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Sir, you have mark'd in me an indelible stain, only to be wash'd out by my blood.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Why I've only one objection to fight∣ing you.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: What's that, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: That you're too brave a lad to be kill'd.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Brave! no, Sir; at present I wear the stigma of a coward.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Zounds, I like a bit of fighting— hav'nt had a morsel a long time—don't know when I smelt gunpowder, but to bring down a woodcock.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Take your ground.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: I'm ready—but are we to thrust with bull-rushes, like two frogs, or like two squirrels, pelt one another with nut-shells, for I don't see any other weapons here.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Oh, yes, Sir, here are the weapons.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Well, this is bold work for a privateer to give battle to a King's ship.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Try your charge, Sir, and take your ground.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P:
I woud'n't wish to sink, burn or destroy what I thought was built for good service, but dam'me if I don't bring wing to you, to teach you better
manners; so take care, or I'll put some red on your nose.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter three Men, without seeing Rover.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st SAIL.
SP.P: Ah, here's the honest fellow has brought us some cash.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d SAIL.
SP.P: We're betray'd, it's the very gentleman that's in pursuit of of us, and this promise was only a decoy to throw us into his power—the pistol! (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Good charge (trying the charge, the men rush forward, and one of them smacks the pistols from him.)

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Ha, boys!

SP.SPEAKER: 2nd SAIL.
SP.P: You'd have our lives, and we'll have yours. (Rover runs to his assistance, and knocks the pistol out of his hand—they run off.)

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Rascals! (pursues them.)

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: (takes up the pistol.) My brave lad I'll — (going,)

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: No, you shan't. (stops him.)

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: The rogues will—

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Never mind the rogues. (a pistol fired without.)

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: S'blood, must I see my preserver perish? struggling.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: I'm your preserver, and I will perish, but I'll bring you out of harm's way,

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Tho' he'd fight me himself—

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: We all know you'd fight the very devil.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: He sav'd my life.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: I'll save your life— (whips him up) —hawl up, my noble little jolly-boat.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Boy, go on with the inventory.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: How unlucky, feyther, to lay hold on me, when I wanted to practice my part.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: This proceeding is too severe—to lay an execution on my wretched trifling goods, when I thought—

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: Aye, you've gone up to the big house with your complaint—her Ladyship's steward, to be sure, has made me give back your cottage and farm, but your goods I seized for my rent.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Leave me but a few necessaries; by my own labour, and the goodness of my neighbours, I may soon redeem what the law has put in your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: The affair is now in my lawyer's hands, and plaintiff and defendant chattering about it is all smoke.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: Feyther, don't be so cruel to Mr. Banks.

SP.SPEAKER: GAM.
SP.P: I'll mark what I may want for myself—stay you and see that not a pin's point be removed. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: (tearing the paper) Dam'me, if I'll be a watch dog to bite the poor, that I won't. Mr. Banks, as my feyther intends to put up your goods to auction, if you could but get a friend to buy the choice of them for you again; sister Jane has got steward to advance her a quarter's wages, and when I've gone to sell corn for feyther, I've made a market penny now and then —it is'n't much, but every little helps. (offers a leather purse)

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: I thank you, my good natured boy, but keep your money.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: I remember, about eight year ago you sav'd me from being drown'd at Black Poole—if you'll not take this, I'll fling it into Black Poole directly.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: My kind lad, I'll not hurt your feelings, by opposing your liberality. (takes the purse)

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: He, he, he!—He's given my heart such pleasure, as I never felt, nor I'm sure my feyther before me.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: But, Sim, whatever may be his opinion of worldly prudence, still remember he's your parent.

SP.SPEAKER: SIM.
SP.P: I will—One elbow chair, one claw table. (crying out) Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: The confusion into which Lady Amaranth's family is thrown, by the sudden departure and ap∣prehended danger of her young cousin, must have prevented her Ladyship from giving that attention to our affairs that I'm sure was her inclination—if I can but prevail on my brother to accept of her protection —Heavens, what's this?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: (panting, as out of breath.) What a race— I've got clear of those blood-hounds at last; if Abra∣wang had but followed and back'd me, we'd have tickled their catastrophe, but three to one is odds, so safe's the word. Who's house is this I've run into— the friendly cottage of my hospitable old gentleman— are you at home? (calls) I had a hard struggle for it, murder was certainly their intent—it was well for me I was born without brains—I'm quite weak and faint.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: (comes forward.) Sir, a'n't you well?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Madam, I ask your pardon—yes, Madam, very well, I thank you, now exceedingly well—got into a kind of rumpus with some worthy gentlemen— not gentlemen, but simple farmers, who mistook me, I fancy, for a sheath of barley, for they had me down, and their flails flew merrily about my ears, but I got up, and when I could no longer fight like a mastiff, I run like a greyhound—but, dear Madam, pray excuse me—this is very rude, faith.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: You seem disturb'd, will you take any re∣freshment?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Madam, you're very good—only a glass of some currant wine, if you please; I think it stands somewhere thereabouts. (Ame. fetches a bottle and glass) Madam, I've the honor of drinking your health.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: I hope you're not hurt, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P:
A little better, but very faint still; I had a sample of this before, and lik'd it so much that Ma'am won't you take another? (she declines.) Ma'am if you'd
been fighting as I have, you'd be glad of a drop (drinks again.) Now I'm as well as any man in Illyria—got a few hard knocks, tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: You'd better repose a little, you seem'd much disordered coming in.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Why Madam you must know that it was—

SP.SPEAKER: OFF.
SP.P: Come Ma'am, Mr. Gammon wants this chair to make up the half dozen above.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: What's all this?

SP.SPEAKER: OFF.
SP.P: Why, the furniture's seiz'd on execution, and a man must do his duty.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Then scoundrel know, that a man's first duty is civility and tenderness to a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Heaven's where's my brother, this gentle∣man will bring himself into trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: OFF.
SP.P: Master, d'ye see, I'm representative for his honor the High Sheriff.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Every High Sheriff should be a gentleman, and when he's represented by a rascal, he's dishonored; damn it, I might as well live about Covent Garden, and every night get beating the watch, for here among groves and meadows, I'm always squabling with constables.

SP.SPEAKER: OFF.
SP.P: Come, come, I must— (sits down.)

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: As you say Sir, last Wednesday so it was, Sir, your most obedient humble servant, pray, Sir, have you ever been astonished?

SP.SPEAKER: OFF.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Because Sir, I intend to astonish you, (Takes a stick off a table and heats him.) Now Sir, are you astonished?

SP.SPEAKER: OFF.
SP.P: Yes, but see if I don't suit you with an action.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Right—suit the action to the word, and the word to the action. See if the gentleman be not af∣frighted, damme, but I'll make thee an example.

SP.SPEAKER: OFF.
SP.P: A fine example when goods are seized by the law.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Thou worm and maggot of the law, hop me over every kennel house, or you shall hop without my custom.

SP.SPEAKER: OFF.
SP.P: I don't value your custom.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I have astonish'd, now I'll amaze you.

SP.SPEAKER: OFF.
SP.P: No Sir, I won't be amazed, but see if I don't.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Hop! [Exit Officer threatening] Madam these sort of gentry, are but bad company for a lady, so I'll just see him to the door—Ma'am I'm your most humble servant. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: I feel a strange kind of curiosity to know who this young gentleman is. I find my hear interested, I can't account for it; he must know the house by the freedom he took: but then his gaiety, (without familiar rudeness) elegance of manners and good breeding, seem to make him at home every where— my brother I think must know him.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Amelia, did you see the young gentleman that was here?—some ruffians have bound and dragg'd him from the door, on the allegation of three men who means to swear he has robbed them, and have taken him to Lady Amaranth's.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: How! he did enter in confusion as if pur∣sued, but I'll stake my life on his innocence, I'll speak to her Ladyship, and in spite of calumny he shall have justice; he wou'dn't let me be insulted, because he saw me an unprotected woman, without a husband or a son and shall he want an advocate brother? come—

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P:
I believe there is no soul in the house but myself; my Lady has sent all the folks round the country, to search after the young 'Squire; she'll cer∣tainly break her heart if any thing happens to him. I dont wonder, for sure he's a dear sweet gentleman. His going has spoiled our play, and I had almost got
my part by heart, but must, must go and do up the room for Mr. Banks's sister, whom my Lady has in∣vited here—

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: The man John Dory hath carried the man George here in his arms, and he locked him up; co∣ming in they did look, like a blue lobster with a shrimp in its claw. Here is the damsel I love alone.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: They say when folks look in the glass, they see the black gentleman. [Looks in a glass.] La, there he is!

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Thou art employed in vanity. [Look's over her shoulder.]

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Well, who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: It's natural for woman to love man.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Yea, but not such ugly men as you are, why did you come in to frighten me? when you know there's nobody here but ourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I'm glad of that; I'm the elm, and thou'rt the honey-suckle, let thine arms entwine me.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: What a rogue is here, but yonder comes my Lady. Ill shew him off in his true colours. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: EHH.
SP.P: Cla me round.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: I will, if you will pull off your hat and make me a low bow.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I cannot bend my body, nor take off my beaver.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Then you're very impudent, go along.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: To win thy favor. [moves his hat.]

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Well, now read me a speech out of that fine play book.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Read a play book! abo-mi-nation! but wilt thou kiss me?

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: I Kiss a man! abomination, but you may take my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH,
SP.P: Oh, 'tis a comfort to the lip of the faithful. [Kisses her hand.]

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: How! (aps him on the shoulder) Ah, thou sly and deceitful hypocrite!

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Verily Mary I was buffetted by Satan in the shape of a damsel.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Begone,

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: My spirit is sad tho' I move so nimbly,

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: But oh, heavens! no tidings of my dear∣est Harry, Jane, let them renew their search.

SP.SPEAKER: JANE.
SP.P: Here's Madam Amelia—but I'll make brother Sim look for the young 'Squire. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: AME,
SP.P: Oh, Madam might I implore your influence with—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Thou art ill accomodated here, but I hope thou wilt excuse it, my mind is a sea of trouble, my peace is shipwrecked! Oh, had'st thou seen my Cousin Harry! all who know him must be anxious for his safety! how unlucky, this servant to prevent Sir George from giving him that assistance, which pater∣nal cares and indeed gratitude demanded, for 'twas filial affection bade him to pursue those wicked men, callous to every feeling of humanity—they may—yes my Henry in the opening bud of manliness is nipp'd!

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Heave a-head. [John without.]

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Rascal, whip me up like a pound of tea, dance about like a young bear! make me quit the preserver of my life, yes, puppy unknown will think me a paltroon, and that I was afraid to follow and second him.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: You may as well turn into your hammock, for out to night you shall not go. (Sees Amelia) Mercy of heaven is'n't it—only look.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: 'Tis my Amelia.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Reef your foresail first, you crack'd her heart by sheering off, and now you'll overset her by bringing to.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Are you at length return'd to me, my Sey∣mour?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Seymour!—her mind's disturbed—this is mine uncle, Sir George Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: No, no, my Lady, she knows what she's saying, well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Niece, I have been a villain to this lady, I confess; but, my dear Amelia, providence has done you justice in part; for from the first month I quitted you, I have never entered one happy hour on my journals—hearing that you foundered, and con∣sidering myself the cause, the worm of remorse has knaw'd my timbers.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: You're not still offended with me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Me—can you forgive me my offence, and condescend to take my hand as an atonement?

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Your hand—do you forget we're already married?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Aye, there was my rascality.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: You may say that.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: That marriage, my dear, I'm ashamed to own it—but it was—

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: As good as if done by the chaplain of the Eagle.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, you impudent crimp, you pandar, you bad adviser—I'll strike my false colours, I'll acknowledge the chaplain you provided was—

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: A good man, and a greater honor to his black, than your honor has been to your blue cloth; by the word of a seaman, here he is himself.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Your brother!

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Capt. Seymour! have I found you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: My dear Banks, I'll make every repa∣ration—Amelia shall really be my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: That, Sir, my sister is already; for when I performed the marriage ceremony, which you took only as a cloak of your deception, I was actually in orders.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN,.
SP.P:
Now who's the crimp and the pandar?— I never told you this, because I thought a man's own
reflections were the best punishment for betraying an innocent woman.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: (to John.) You shall be a post captain for this, sink me, if you shan't.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Madam, my inmost soul partaketh of thy gladness and joy for thy reformation: (to Sir Geo.) but thy prior marriage to this lady annuls the subsequent, and my cousin Harry is not now thine heir.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: So much the better, he's an unnatural cub—but, Amelia, I flatter myself I have an heir— my infant boy.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Ha, husband, you had, but—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Gone—well, well, I see I have been a miserable scoundrel—I'll adopt that brave kind lad, that wou'd'n't let any body kill me but himself, he shall have my estate, that's my own acqusition—my lady marrying him—Puppy Unknown's a fine fel∣low! Amelia, only for him, you'd never have found your husband.—Captain Seymour is Sir George Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: BANKS.
SP.P: Are you Sir George Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: LAND.
SP.P: Please you, Madam, they have got a foot-pad in custody.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I'm come to sit in judgment, for there is a bad man in thy house, Mary—bring him before me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Before you, old Squintabus! perhaps you don't know I'm a magistrate.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I'll examine him.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: You be damn'd; I'll examine him my∣self—tow him in here, I'll give him a passport to Winchester bilbows.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: (kneels to Sir Geo.) Oh, Sir, as you hope for mercy, extend it to this youth, and even should he be guilty, which from our knowledge of his benevolent and noble nature, I think next to an impossibility, let the services he has rendered us plead for him—he protected your forsaken wife, and her unhappy brother, in the hour of want and sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What, Amelia plead for a robber!— consider my love, Justice is above bias or partiality; if my son violated the laws of his country. I'd deli∣ver him up as a public victim to disgrace and punish∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Oh, my impartial uncle! Had thy country any laws to punish him, who instead of pal∣try gold, would rob the artless virgin of her dearest treasure, in the rigid judge, I should now behold the trembling criminal.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter TWITCH, with two men, and ROVER bound.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Speak thou—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Hold thy clapper, thou—you wretched person, who are the prosecutors.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Call in—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Will nobody stop his mouth (John car∣ries him up the stage.) Where are the prosecutors?

SP.SPEAKER: TWITCH,
SP.P: There, tell his worship the justice.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st MAN.
SP.P: A justice—oh, the devil!—I thought we should have nothing but quakers to deal with (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Come, how did this fellow rob you?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st MAN.
SP.P: Why, your honour, I swear—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Oh, ho!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st MAN.
SP.P: Zounds, we're in the wrong, this is the very—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Clap down the hatches, secure these sharks.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I'm glad to find you here, Abrawang, as I believe you have some knowledge of these gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Heaven's, my cousin Harry!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: The Devil! is'n't that my spear and shield?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: My young master, what have you been at ere, (unbinds him,) this rope may be wanted yet.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: My dear fellow are you safe?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Yes, Dick, I was brought here very safe, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: A confederate in custody has made a con∣fession of their villainy, that they concerted this plan to accuse him of a robbery, first for revenge, then in hopes to share the reward for apprehending him; he also owns they are not sailors but depredators on the public.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: What, could you find no jacket to disgrace by your wearing than that of an English Seamen— a character, whose bravery is even the admiration of his enemies, and genuine honesty of heart, the glory of human nature? Keep them safe.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Aye, I knew the rope would be wanted, (drives them off.)

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Not knowing that the Justice of Peace whom they brought the lad before, is the very man they attacked, ha, ha, ha! the rogues have fallen into their own snare.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: What now you're a Justice of Peace?—well said, Abrawang.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Then, Sir George you know him too?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Know him! to be sure I do.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Still Sir George—what then you will not resign your Knighthood! Madam, I'm happy to see you again. Ah, how do you do, my kind host? (to Banks)

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: I rejoice at thy safety, be reconcil'd to him. (To Sir George)

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Reconcil'd! if I don't love, respect and honor him, I should be unworthy of the life he rescued —but who is he?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Sir, he is—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Dick, I thank you for your good wishes, but I'm still determined not to impose on this Lady. Madam, as I first told that well-meaning tar, when he forc'd me to your house, I'm not the son of Sir George Thunder.

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Then I wish you was the son of an Admiral, and I your father.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: You refuse the lady—to punish you, I have a mind to take her myself, my dear Cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Stop Dick, if I who adore her won't, you shall not; no, no, Madam, never mind what the fellow says, he's as poor as myself, is'n't he Abrawang?

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Then my dear Rover, since you are so obstinately interrested, I'll no longer teize my father, whom you here see, and in your strolling friend, his very truant Harry that ran from Portsmoth Academy, and joined you and fellow Comedians.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Dear cousin forgive me, if thro' my zeal for the happiness of my friend, I endeavoured to pro∣mote your's, by giving you a husband, more worthy than myself.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Am I to believe, Madam, is your uncle Sir George Thunder in the room?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: He is.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: 'Tis you in reality; what I've had the im∣pudence to assume, and have perplex'd your father with my ridiculous effrontery. I told you (to John) I was not the person you took me for, but you must bring your damn'd chariot—I am asham'd and mor∣tified—Madam, I take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: Thou art welcome to go.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Sir George, as the father of my friend, I can∣not lift my hand against you, but I hope, Sir, you'll apoligize to me apart.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Aye, with pleasure, my noble splinter. Now tell me from what dock you were launch'd, my heart of oak?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: I heard in England, Sir; but from my earliest knowledge, till within a few years I've been in the East Indies.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: Beyond seas—well, and how?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV
SP.P: It seems I was committed an infant to the care of a lady, who was herself obliged by the gentle Hyder Ally to strike her toilet, and decamp without beat of drum, leaving me a chubby little fellow, squatted on a carpet; a serjant's wife alone returned, and snatched me off triumphant, thro' fire, smoke, cannon, cries, and carnage.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: (To Amelia) Dost thou mark?

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Sir, can you recollect the name of the town where—

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Yes Madam, the town was Negapatam.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: I thank you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: An officer, who had much rather act Hotspur on the stage, than in the field, brought me up behind the scenes at Calcutta theatre; I was enroll'd on the boards, acted myself into the favour of a colonel, pro∣mised a pair of colours; but impatient to find my parents, hid myself in the steerage of a homeward∣bound ship, assumed the name of Rover, from the un∣certainty of my sate, and have murdered more Poets, than Rajahs, stopped on English ground unincumbered with rupees or pagodas.—Ha, ha, ha, wouldst'st thou have come home so, little Ephraim?

SP.SPEAKER: EPH.
SP.P: I would bring myself home with some money.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Excuse my curiosity, Sir—what was the lady's name in whose care you was left?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Oh, Madam, she was the lady of a Major Linstock, but I heard my mother's name was Seymour.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR. GEO.
SP.P: Why, Amelia!

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: My son!

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: It is my Charles. (embraces him)

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: Tol de rol!— (dances a hornpipe step) —Tho' I never heard it before, my heart told me he was a chip of the old block. Your father (to Rover, and points to Sir Geo.)

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Can it—

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Yes, my son, Sir George Thunder here is Captain Seymour, in search of whom you may have heard I quitted England.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Heavens, then have I attempted to raise my hands against a parent's life.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: My brave boy—then have I a son with spirit to fight me as a sailor, yet defend me as a father.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Uncle, you'll recollect 'twas I first in∣troduced this son to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR GEO.
SP.P: And I hope you'll next introduce a grandson to me, young Slyboots.—Harry, you have lost your fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: HARRY.
SP.P: Yes, Sir—but I've gained a brother, whose friendship, before I knew him to be such, I prized before the first fortune in England.

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: My dearest Rosalind.

SP.SPEAKER: AME.
SP.P: Then, you will take our Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY A.
SP.P: Yea; but only on conditions, thou be∣stow thy fortune on his friend and brother—mine is sufficient for us both, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: ROV.
SP.P: Angelic creature! to think of my generous friend. But now for As You Like It; where's Lamp and Trap! I shall ever love a play; a spark from Shakespeare's muse of fire, was the star that guided me through my desolate and bewildered maze of life, and brought me to these unexpected blessings.

LG.L: To merit friends so good, so sweet a wife,
The tender husband be my part for life.
My Wild Oats sown, let candid Thespian laws
Decree that glorious harvest—your applause.

DIV1.P: LIONEL and CLARISSA: OR, THE SCHOOL FOR FATHERS. A COMIC OPERA. WRITTEN BY MR. BICKERSTAFF. MARKED WITH THE VARIATIONS IN THE MANAGER'S BOOK AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
PHILADELPHIA. PRINTED BY W. W. WOODWARD, FOR MATHEW CAREY, No. 8, Market-street. 1794.
{inverted ⁂}THE Reader is desired to observe, that the Passages omitted in the representation at the Thea∣tre, are here preserved, and mark∣ed with inverted commas; as in line 1 to 15, page 14.

DIV1.HEAD: Advertisement.
DIV1.P: HAVING, for some years, et with very great suc∣cess in my productions of the musical kind; when I wrote the following Opera, it was with unusual care and attention; and it was the general opinion of all my friends, some of whom rank among the best judges, that of all my trifles, Lionel and Clarissa was the most pardon∣able: a decision in its favour, which I was the prouder of, because, to the best of my knowledge, through the whole, I had not borrowed an expression, a sentiment, or a character, from any dramatic writer extant.

When Mr. GARRICK thought of performing this piece at Drury-lane theatre, he had a new singer to bring out, and every thing possible for her advantage was to be done; this necessarily occasioned some new songs and airs to be introduced; and other singers, with voices of a different compass from those who originally acted the parts, occa∣sioned still more; by which means the greatest part of the music unavoidably became new. This is the chief, and indeed the only alteration made in the Opera: and even to that, I should in many places have been forced, much against my will, had it not given a fresh opportunity to Mr. Dibden to display his admirable talents as a musical composer. And I will be bold to say, that his airs, se∣rious and comic, in this Opera, will appear to no disad∣vantage by being heard with those of some of the greatest masters.
The SCHOOL FOR FATHERS is added to the title, because the plot in evidently double; and that of Lionel and Clarissa alluded to but one part of it, as the readers and spectators will easily perceive.

POSTSCRIPT.P: P. S. The SONGS varying from those performed at Drury-lane, are inserted at the end.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, A Chamber in Colonel Oldboy's House: Colonel Oldboy at breakfast, reading a newspaper; at a little distance sits Jenkins; and on the opposite side, Diana, playing upon a harpsichord. A Girl attending.

LG.L: AH how delightful the morning,

L.HI: How sweet are the prospects it yields!
The gardens, the groves, and the fields.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Well said, Dy; thank you, Dy. This, master Jen∣kins, is the way I make my daughter entertain me every morning at breakfast. Come here and kiss me, you slut; come here and kiss me, you baggage.

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Lord, papa, you call one such names—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: A fine girl, master Jenkins, a devilish fine girl! she has got my eye to a twinkle. There's fire for you!— spirit!—I design to marry her to a Duke; how much money do you think a Duke would expect with such a wench?

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Why, Colonel, with submission, I think there is no occasion to go out of our own country here; we have never a Duke in it, I believe; but we have many an ho∣nest gentleman, who, in my opinion, might deserve the young lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: So you would have me marry Dy to a country Squire, eh! How say you to this, Dy? Would not you rather be married to a Duke?

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: So my husband's a rake, papa, I don't care what he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: A rake! you damned confounded little baggage; why, you would not wish to marry a rake, would you? So her husband is a rake, she does not care what he is!— Ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Well, but listen to me, papa—When you go out with your gun, do you take any pleasure in shooting the poor tame ducks and chickens in your yard? No, the partridge, the pheasant, the woodcock, are the game; there is some sport in bringing them down, because they are wild; and it is just the same with an husband or a lover. I would not waste powder and shot to wound one of your sober pretty behaved gentlemen; but to hit a libertine, extravagant, madcap fellow, to take him upon the wing—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Do you hear her, master Jenkins? Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Well, but good Colonel, what do you say to my worthy and honorable patron here, Sir John Flowerdale? He has an estate of eight thousand pounds a year as well, paid rents as any in the kingdom, and but one only daugh∣ter to enjoy it; and yet he is willing, you see, to give this daughter to your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Pray, Mr. Jenkins, how does Miss Clarissa and our university friend, Mr. Lionel? That is the only grave young man I ever liked, and the only handsome one I ever was acquainted with, that did not make love to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Ay, master Jenkins, who is this Lionel? They say he is a damned witty, knowing fellow; and egad I think him well enough for one brought up in a college.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P:
His father was a general officer, a particular friend of Sir John's, who, like many more brave men that live and die in defending their country, left little else than honour behind him▪ Sir John sent this young man, at his own expence, to Oxford; where, while his son lived, they were upon the same footing: and since our young gentleman's death, which you know unfortunately hap∣pened about two years ago, he has continued him there. During the vacation he is come to pay us a visit, and Sir John intends that he shall shortly take orders for a very
considerable benefice in the gift of the family, the pre∣sent incumbent of which is an aged man.

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: The last time I was at your house, he was teach∣ing Miss Clarissa mathematics and philosophy. Lord! what a strange brain I have! If I was to sit down to dis∣tract myself with such studies—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Go, hussey, let some of your brother's rascals in∣form their master that he has been long enough at his toilet; here is a message from Sir John Flowerdale— You a brain for mathematics, indeed! we shall have women wanting to head our regiments to-morrow or next day.

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Well, papa, and suppose we did. I believe, in a battle of the sexes, you men would hardly get the bet∣ter of us.

LG.L: To rob them of strength, when wise nature thought fit
By women to still do her duty,
Instead of a sword, she endues them with wit,
And gave them a shield in ther beauty.
Sound, sound then the trumpet, both sexes to arms!
Our tyrants at once and protectors!
We quickly shall see, whether courage or charms
Decide for the Helens or Hectors. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Well, master Jenkins! don't you think now that a nobleman, a Duke, an Earl, or a Marquis, might be con∣tent to share his title—I say, you understand me—with a sweetener of thirty or forty thousand pounds, to pay off mortgages? Besides, there's a prospect of my whole estate; for, I dare swear her brother will never have any children.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: I should be concerned at that, Colonel, when there are two such fortunes to descend to his heirs, as yours and Sir John Flowerdale's.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P:
Why, look you, master Jenkins, Sir John Flower∣dale is an honest gentleman; our families are nearly re∣lated; we have been neighbours time out of mind; and if he and I have an odd dispute now and then, it is not for
want of a cordial esteem at bottom. He is going to marry his daughter to my son; she is a beautiful girl, an elegant girl, a sensible girl, a worthy girl, and—a word in your ear—damn me, it I an't very sorry for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Sorry! Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Ay—between ourselves, master Jenkins, my son won't do.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: How do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I tell you, master Jenkins, he won't do—he is not the thing, a prig—At sixteen years old, or thereabouts, he was a bold sprightly boy, as you should see in a thou∣sand; could drink his pint of port, or his bottle of claret —now he mixes all his wine with water.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Oh! if that be his only fault, Colonel, he will neer make the worse husband, I'll answer for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You know my wife is a woman of quality—I was prevailed upon to send him to be brought up by her brother Lord Jsamy, who had no children of his own, and promised to leave him an estate—He has got the estate indeed, but the fellow has taken his Lordship's name for it. Now, master Jenkins, I would be glad to know how the name of Jessamy is better than that of Oldboy?

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Well! but, Colonel, it is allowed on all hands, that his Lordship has given your son an excellent educa∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Psha! he sent him to the university, and to travel, for sooth; but, what of that? I was abroad, and at the university myself, and never a rush the better for either. I quarrelled with his Lordship about six years before his death, and so had not an opportunity of seeing how the youth went on; if I had, master Jenkins, I would no more have suffered him to be made such a monkey of— He has been in my house but three days, and it is all turned topsey-turvey by him and his rascally servants— then his chamber is like a perfumer's shop, with wash-balls, pastes, and pomatum—and do you know he had the impudence to tell me yesterday at my own table, that I did not know how to behave myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Pray, Colonel, how does my Lady Mary?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: What, my wife? In the old way, master Jenkins; always complaining; ever something the matter with her head, or her back, or her legs—but we have had the devil to pay lately—she and I did not speak to one ano∣ther for three weeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: How so, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: A little affair of jealousy—You most know, my game-keeper's daughter has had a child, and the plaguy baggage takes it into her head to lay it to me—Upon my soul, it is a fine fat chubby infant, as ever I set my eyes on; I have sent it to nurse; and, between you and me, I believe I shall leave it a fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Ah, Colonel, you will never give over.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You know my Lady has a pretty vein of poetry; she writ me an heroic epistle upon it, where she calls me her dear false Damon; so I let her cry a little, promised to do so no more, and now we are as good friends as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Well, Colonel, I must take my leave; I have de∣livered my message, and Sir John may expect the pleasure of your company to dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Ay, ay, we'll come—pox o' ceremony among friends. But won't you stay to see my son; I have sent to him, and suppose he will be here as soon as his valet-de-chambre will give him leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: There's no occasion, good sir; present my hum∣ble respects, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Well, but, zounds, Jenkins, you must not go till you drink something—let you and I have a bottle of hock—

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Not for the world, Colonel; I never touch any thing strong in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Never touch any thing strong! Why, one bottle won't hurt you, man—this is old, and as mild as milk.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Well, but, Colonel, pray excuse me.

LG.L: To tell you the truth,
In the days of my youth,
As mirth and nature bid,
I lik'd a glass,
And I lov'd a lass.
And I did as younkers did.
But now I am old,
With grief be it told,
I must those freaks forbear;
At sixty-three,
'Twixt you and me,
A man grows worse for wear. Exit.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Jessamy, and Lady Mary Oldboy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Shut the door, why don't you shut the door there? Have you a mind I should catch my death?— This house is absolutely the cave of Aeous; one had as good live on the eddystone, or in a wind-mill.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: I thought they told your Ladyship that there was a messenger here from Sir John Flowerdale?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Well, sir, and so there was; but he had not pa∣tience to wait upon your curling-irons. Mr. Jenkins was here, Sir John Flowerdale's steward, who has lived in the family these forty years.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: And pray, sir, might not Sir John Flowerdale have come himself? If he had been acquainted with the rules of good breeding, he would have known that I ought to have been visited.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Upon my word, Colonel, this is a solecism.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: 'Sblood, my Lady, its none. Sir John Flowerdale came but last night from my sister's seat in the West, and is a little out of order. But I suppose he thinks he ought to appear before him with his daughter in one hand, and his rent-roll in the other, and cry, Sir, pray do me the favour to accept them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Nay, but, Mr. Oldboy, permit me to say—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: He need not give himself so many affected airs; I think it's very well if he gets such a girl for going for— she's one of the handsomest and richest in this country, and more than he deserves.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P:
That's an exceeding fine china jar your Ladyship has got in the next room; I saw the fellow of it the other day at Williams's, and will send to my agent to purchase it; it is the true matchless old blue and white. Lady Betty Barebones has a couple that she gave an hundred guineas for, on board an Indiaman; but she reckons them
at a hundred and twenty-five, on account of half a dozen plates, four Nankin beakers, and a couple of shading mandarins, that the custom-house officers took from under her petticoats.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Did you ever hear the like of this! He's chatter∣ing about old china, while I am talking to him of a fine girl. I tell you what, Mr. Jessamy, since that's the name you choose to be called by, I have a good mind to knock you down.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Knock me down, Colonel! What do you mean? I must tell you, sir, this is a language to which I have not been accustomed; and if you think proper to conti∣nue to repeat it, I shall be under a necessity of quitting your house?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Quitting my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Yes, sir, incontinently.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Why, sir, am not I your father, sir? and have I not a right to talk to you as I like? I will, sirrah. But, perhaps I mayn't be your father, and I hope not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Heavens and earth, Mr. Oldboy!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: What's the matter, madam! I mean, madam, that he might have been changed at nurse, madam; and I believe he was.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Huh! huh! huh!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Do you laugh at me, you saucy jackanapes!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Who's there—somebody bring me a chair. Really, Mr. Oldboy, you throw my weakly frame into such repeated convulsions—but I see your aim; you want to lay me in my grave, and you will very soon have that satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I can't bear the sight of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Open that window, give me air, or I shall faint.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Hold, hold, let me tie a handkerchief about my neck first. This cursed sharp north wind—Antoine, bring down my muff.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Ay, do, and his great-coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Margaret, some hartsharn. My dear Mr. Oldboy, why will you fly out in this way, when you know how it shocks my tender nerves?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: 'Sblood, madam, its enough to make a man mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Hartshorn! Hartshorn!

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Colonel!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Do you hear the puppy?

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Will you give me leave to ask you one question?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: I don't know whether I will or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: I should be glad to know, that's all, what single circumstance in my conduct, carriage, or figure, you can possibly find fault with—Perhaps I may be brought to re∣form—Pr'ythee, let me hear from your own mouth then, seriously what it is you do like, and what it is you do not like.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Hum!

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Be ingenuous, speak and spare not.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: You would know?

LG.L: Zounds, sir! then I'll tell you without any jest,
The thing of all things which I hate and detest;
A coxcomb, a fop,
A dainty milk-sop;
Who, essenc'd and dizen'd from bottom to top,
Looks just like a doll for a milliner's shop.
A thing full of prate,
And pride and conceit;
All fashion, no weight;
Who shrugs and takes snuff,
And carries a muff;
A minikin,
Finiking,
French powder puff:
And now, sir, I fancy I've told you enough Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: What's the matter with the Colonel, madam; does your Ladyship know?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P:
Heigho! don't be surprised, my dear; it was the same thing with my late dear brother, Lord Jes∣samy; they never could agree: that good-natured, friendly soul, knowing the delicacy of my constitution, has often said, sister Mary, I pity you. Not but your father has good qualities, and, I assure you, I remember him a
very fine gentleman himself. In the year of the hard frost, one thousand seven hundred and thirty-nine, when he first paid his addresses to me, he was called agreeable Jck Odboy, though I married him without the consent of your noble grandfather.
I think he ought to be proud of me: I believe there's many a Duke, nay Prince, who would esteem themselves happy in having such a son—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Yes, my dear; but your sister was always your father's favourite: He intends to give her a prodi∣gious fortune, and sets his heart upon seeing her a woman of quality.
He should wish to see her look a little like a gen∣tlewoman first. When she was in London last winter, I am told she was taken notice of by a few men. But she wants ar, manner—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: And has not a bit of the genius of our fa∣mily, and I never knew a woman of it, but herself, without. I have tried her. About three years ago, I set her to translate a little French song: I found she had not even an idea of versification; and she put down love and joy for rhyme—so I gave her over.
Why, indeed, she appears to have more of the 'Tatestris than the Sappho about her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady M.
SP.P: Well, my dear, I must go and dress myself, though I protest I am fitter for my bed than my coach — And condescend to the Colonel a little—Do, my dear, if it be only to oblige your mamma. Exit.

Let me consider—I am going to visit a country Baronet here, who would fain prevail upon me to marry his daughter: the old gentleman has heard of my parts and understanding; Miss, of my figure and address — But, suppose I should not like her when I see her?— Why, positively, then I will not have her; the treaty's at an end, and, sans compliment, we break up the congress. But, won't that be cruel, after having suf∣fered her to flatter herself with hopes, and shewing my∣self to her. She's a strange dowdy, I dare believe: however, she brings provision with her for a separate maintenance.
Antoine, appretez la toilette. I am going to spend a cursed day; that I perceive already; I wish it was over, I dread it as much as a general election.

LG.L: When a man of fashion condescends
To herd among his country friends,
They watch his looks, his motions:
One booby gapes, another stares,
And all he says, does, eats, drinks, wears,
Must suit their rustic notions.
But as for this brutish old clown here,
'Sdeath, why did I ever come down here!
The savage will now never quit me:
Then a consort to take,
For my family's sake,
Twix a fair jeopardy, sp me! Exit,

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, a Study in Sir John Flowerdale's House.— Clarissa enters, followed by Jenny.

L.HI: And let me, let me rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: My dear lady, what ails you?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Nothing, Jenny; nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Pardon me madam, there is something ails you, indeed. Lord! what signifies all the grandeur and riches in this world, if they can't procure one content. I am sure it vexes me to the heart, so it does, to see such a dear, sweet, worthy young lady, as you are, pining yourself to death.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Jenny, you are a good girl, and I am very much obliged to you for feeling so much on my account; but in a little time, I hope, I shall be easier.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P:
Why, now, here to day, madam—for certain,
you ought to be merry to-day, when there's a fine gen∣tleman coming to court you, but, if you like any one else better, I am sure, I wish you had him, with all my soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Suppose, Jenny, I was so unfortunate as to like a man without my father's approbation—would you wish me to marry him?

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: I wish you married to any one, madam, that could make you happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Heigho!

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Madam! madam! yonder's Sir John and Mr. Lionel on the terrace. I believe they are coming up here. Poor, dear, Mr. Lionel, he does not seem to be in over great spirits either. To be sure, madam, it's no business of mine; but, I believe, if the truth was known, there are those in the house who would give more than ever I shall be worth, or any the likes of me, to prevent the marriage of a certain person that shall be nameless.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: What do you mean? I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: I hope you are not angry, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Ah! Jenny—

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Lauk, madam! do you think when Mr. Lionel's a clergyman, he'll be obliged to cut off his hair. I'm sure it will be a thousand pities, for it is the sweetest co∣lour, and looks the nicest put up in a queue— and your great pudding-sleeves! Lord! they'll quite spoil his shape, and the fall of his shoulders. Well! madam, if I was a lady of large fortune, I'll be hanged if Mr. Lionel should be a parson, if I could help it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I'm going into my dressing-room—t seems then Mr. Lionel is a great favorite of yours; but pray, Jen∣ny▪ have a care how you talk in this manner to any one else.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Me talk! madam—I thought you knew me bet∣ter; and, my dear lady, keep up your spirits. I'm sure I have dressed you to day as nicely as hands and pins can make you.

LG.L: I'm but a poor servant, 'tis true, ma'am;
But was I a lady like you, ma'am,
In grief would I sit? The dickens a bit;
No, faith, I would search the world through, ma'am,
To find what my liking could hit.
Set in case a young man,
In my fancy there ran,
It might anger my friends and relations;
But if I had regard,
It should go very hard,
Or I'd follow my own inclinations. Exeunt.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir John Flowerdale, and Lionel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Indeed, Lionel, I will not hear of it. What! to run from us all of a sudden, this way; and at such a time, too; the eve of my daughters wedding, as I may call it, when your company must be doubly agreeable, as well as necessary to us? I am sure you have no studies at present that require your attendance at Oxford: I must therefore insist on your putting such thoughts out of your head.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Upon my word, sir, I have been so long from the university, that it is time for me to think of return∣ing. It is true, I have no absolute studies; but really, sir, I shall be obliged to you if you will give me leave to go.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Come, come, my dear Lonel, I have for some time observed a more than ordinary gravity grow∣ing upon you, and I am not to learn the reason of it: I know, to minds serious and well inclined, like yours, the sacred functions you are about to embrace—

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Dear sir, your goodness to me, of every kind, is so great, so unremitted —Your condescension, your friendly attentions—in short, sir, I want words to express my sense of obligations—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
Fie, fie, no more of them. By my last letters, I find, that my old friend the Rector still con∣tinues in good health, considering his advanced years. You may imagine, I am far from desiring the death of
so worthy and pious a man; yet, I must own, at this time, I could wish you were in orders, as you might then perform the ceremony of my daughter's marriage; which would give me a secret satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: No doubt, sir, any office in my power that could be instrumental to the happiness of any in your family, I should perform with pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why, really, Lionel, from the character of her intended husband, I have no room to doubt, but this match will make Clarissa perfectly happy: to be sure the alliance is the most eligible for both families.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: If the gentleman is sensible of his happiness in the alliance, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: The fondness of a father is always suspected of partiality; yet, I believe, I may venture to say, that few young women will be found more unexceptionable than my daughter: her person is agreeable, her temper sweet, her understanding good; and, with the obliga∣tions she has to your instructions—

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: You do my endeavours too much honour, sir; I have been able to add nothing to Miss Flowerdale's ac∣complishments, but a little knowledge in matters of small importance to a mind already so well improved.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I don't think so; a little knowledge, even in those matters, is necessary for a woman, in whom I am far from considering ignorance as a desireable character∣istic. When intelligence is not attended with impertinent affectation, it teaches them to judge with precision, and gives them a degree of solidity necessary for the compa∣nion of a sensible man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Yonder's Mr. Jenkins: I fancy he's looking for you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I see him; he's come back from Colonel Oldboy's; I have a few words to say to him, and will re∣turn to you again in a minute. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: To be a burthen to one's self, to wage continual war with one's own passions; forced to combat, unable to overcome! But see, she appears, whose presence turns all my sufferings into transport, and makes even misery itself delightful.
Perhaps, madam, you are not at leisure now; other∣wise, if you thought proper, we would resume the sub∣ject we were upon yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I am sure, sir, I give you a great deal of trou∣ble.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Madam, you give me no trouble; I should think every hour of my life happily employed in your service; and as this is probably the last time I shall have the satis∣faction of attending you upon the same occasion—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Upon my word, Mr. Lionel, I think myself ex∣tremely obliged to you; and shall ever consider the enjoy∣ment of your friendship—

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: My friendship, madam, can be of little moment to you; but if the most perfect adoration, if the warmest wishes for your felicity, though I should never be witness of it—if these, madam, can have any merit to continue in your remembrance, a man once honoured with a share of your esteem—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Hold, sir—I think I hear somebody.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: If you please, madam, we will turn over this oelestial globe once more—Have you looked at the book I left you yesterday?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Really, sir, I have been so much disturbed in my thoughts for these two or three days past, that I have not been able to look at any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: I am sorry to hear that, madam; I hope there was nothing particular to disturb you. The care Sir John takes to dispose of your hand in a manner suitable to your birth and fortune—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I don't know, sir—I own I am disturbed; I own I am uneasy; there is something weighs upon my heart, which I would fain disclose.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Upon your heart, madam!—did you say your heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I did, sir—I—

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P:
Madam! madam! Here's a coach and six driv∣ing up the avenue: It's Colonel Oldboy's family; and, I believe, the gentleman is in it that's coming to court you.
Lord, I must run and have a peep at him out of the win∣dow. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Madam, I'll take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Why so, sir?—Bless me, Mr. Lionel, what's the matter!—You turn pale.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Pray speak to me, sir—You tremble—Tell me the cause of this sudden change.—How are you?— Where's your disorder?

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Oh fortune! fortune!

LG.L: You ask me in vain.
Of what ills I complain,
Where harbours the torment I find;
In my head, in my heart,
It invades every part,
And subdues both my body and mind.
Each effort I try,
Every med'cine apply,
The pangs of my soul to appease;
But, doom'd to endure,
What I mean for a cure,
Turns poison, and feeds the disease. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: My dear Clarissa—I'am glad I have found you alone.—For Heaven's sake, don't let any one break in upon us—and give me leave to sit down with you a little —I am in such a tremor, such a panic—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Mercy on us, what has happened?

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: You may remember, I told you, that when I was last winter in London, I was followed by an odious fellow, one Haman: I can't say but the wretch pleased me, though he is but a young brother, and not worth sixpence; and—in short, when I was leaving town, I promised to correspond with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Do you think that was prudent?

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P:
Madness! But this is not the worst—for, what do you think?—the creature had the assurance to write to
me about three weeks ago, desiring permission to come down and spend the summer at my father's.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: At your father's!

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Ay, who never saw him, knows nothing of him, and would as soon consent to my marrying a horse joc∣key. He told me a long story of some tale he intended to invent, to make my father receive him as an indifferent person; and some gentlemen in London, he said, would procure him a letter that should give it a face; and he longed to see me so, he said, he could not live without it; and if he could be permitted but to spend a week with me—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Well, and what answer did you make?

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Oh! abused him, and refused to listen to any such thing—But—I vow, I tremble while I tell it you— Just before we left our house, the impudent monster ar∣rived there, attended by a couple of servants, and is now actually coming here with my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Upon my word this is a dreadful thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Dreadful my dear!—I happened to be at the window as he came into the court, and I declare I had like to have fainted away.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Isn't my Lady below?

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Yes, and I must run down to her. You'll have my brother here presently too; he would fain have come in the coach with my mother and me, but my father in∣sisted on his walking with him over the fields.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Well Diana, with regard to your affair—I think you must find some method of immediately informing this gentleman, that you consider the outrage he has com∣mitted against you in the most heinous light, and insist upon his going away directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Why, I believe that will be the best way—but then he'll be begging my pardon, and asking to stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Why, then, you must tell him positively, you won't consent to it; and if he persists in so extravagant a design, tell him you'll never see him again as long as you live.

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Must I tell him so?

LG.L: Ah! pr'ythee, spare me, dearest creature!
How can you prompt me to so much ill-nature?
Kneeling before me,
Should I hear him implore me;
Could I accuse him,
Could I refuse him
The boon he should ask?
Set not a lover the cruel task.
No, believe me, my dear,
Was he now standing here,
In spite of my frights and alarms,
I might rate him, might scold him—
But should still strive to hold him—
And sink at last into his arms. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: How easy to direct the conduct of others, how hard to regulate our own! I can give my friend advice, while I am conscious of the same indiscretion in myself. Yet is it criminal to know the most worthy, most amiable man in the world, and not to be insensible to his merit? But my father, the kindest, best of fathers, will he ap∣prove the choice I have made? Nay, has he not made another choice for me? And, after all, how can I be sure that the man I love, loves me again? He never told me so; but his looks, his actions, his present anxiety, sufficiently declare, what his delicacy, his generosity, will not suffer him to utter.

LG.L: Hope and fear, alternate rising,
Strive for empire o'er my heart;
Every peril now despising,
Now at ev'ry breath I start.
Teach, ye learned sages, teach me,
How to stem this beating tide;
If you've any rules to reach me,
Haste and be the weak one's guide.
Thus, our trials at a distance,
Wisdom, science, promise aid;
But, in need of their assistance,
We attempt to grasp a shade. Exit.

DIV2.STAGE: SCENE, a Side View of Sir Sohn Flowerdale's.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Well, and how does my old friend, Dick Rantum, do? I have not seen him these twelve years: he was an honest worthy fellow, as ever breathed; I remember he kept a girl in London, and was cursedly plagued by his wife's relations.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Sir Richard was always a man of spirit, Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: But as to this business of yours, which he tells me of in his letter—I don't see much in it—An affair with a citizen's daughter—pinked her brother in a duel— is the fellow likely to die?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Why, sir, we hope not; but as the matter is du∣bious, and will probably make some noise, I thought it was better to be for a little time out of the way; when hearing my case, Sir Richard Rantum mentioned you; he said, he was sure you would permit me to remain at your house for a few days, and offered me a recommenda∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: And there's likely to be a brat in the case—And the girl's friends are in business—I'll tell you what will be the consequence then—They will be for going to law with you for a maintenance—but, no matter; I'll take the affair in hand for you—make me your solicitor; and if you are obliged to pay for a single spoonful of pap, I'll be content to father all the children in the Foundling Hospital.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: You are very kind, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: But hold—hark you—you say there's money to be had—suppose you were to marry the wench?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Do you think, sir, that would be so right, after what has happened? Besides, there's a stronger objec∣tion—To tell you the truth, I am honorably in love in another place.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Oh! you are?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Yes, sir, but there are obstacles—A father—In short, sir, the mistress of my heart lives in this very county, which makes even my present situation a little irksome.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: In this county! Zounds! Then I am sure I am acquainted with her; and the first letter of her name is—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Excuse me, sir, I have some particular reasons.—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: But, look—who comes yonder?—Ha! ha! ha! My son, picking his steps like a dancing-master. Pr'y∣thee, Harman, go into the house, and let my wife and daughter know we are come, while I go and have some sport with him: they will introduce you to Sir John Flowerdale.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Then, sir, I'll take the liberty—

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: But, d'ye hear?—I must have a little more dis∣course with you about this girl; perhaps she is a neigh∣bour of mine, and I may be of service to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Well, remember, Colonel, I shall try your friendship.

LG.L: Indulgent powers, if ever
You mark'd a tender vow,
O bend in kind compassion,
And hear a lover now.
For titles, wealth and honours,
While others crowd your shrine;
I ask this only blessing,
Let her I love be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Why, zounds! one would think you had never put your feet to the ground before; you make as much work about walking a quarter of a mile, as if you had gone a pilgrimage to Jerusalem.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Colonel, you have used me extremely ill, to drag me through the dirty roads in this manner; you told me the way was all over a bowling-green; only see what a condition I am in!

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Why, how did I know the roads were dirty? is that my fault? Besides, we mistook the way. Zounds, man, your legs will never be the worse when they are brushed a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Antoine! have you sent La Roque for the shoes and stockings? Give me the glass out of your pocket: not a dust of powder left in my hair, and the frissure as flat as the foretop of an attorney's clerk—get your comb and pomatum; you must borrow some powder; I suppose there's such a thing as a dressing-room in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Ay, and a cellar too, I hope; for I want a glass of wine, cursedly—but, hold! hold! Frank, where are you going? Stay, and pay your devoirs here, if you please; I see there's somebody coming out to welcome us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Colonel, your most obedient, Sir John is walk∣ing with my Lady in the garden, and has commissioned me to receive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Mr. Lionel, I am heartily glad to see you—come here, Frank—this is my son, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Sir, I am exceeding proud to—

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Can't you get the powder then?

SP.SPEAKER: Col.
SP.P: Miss Clary, my little Miss Clary—give me a kiss, my dear—as handsome as an angel, by Heavens—Frank, why don't you come here? This is Miss Flowerdale.

SP.SPEAKER: Dian.
SP.P: Oh, Heavens, Clarissa! Just as I said, that im∣pudent devil is come here with my father. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jes.
SP.P: Hadn't we better go into the house?

LG.L: To be made in such a pickle!
Will you please to lead the way, sir,

L.HI: No, but if you please, you may sir,
Will you not your hand bestow?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.L: Dear Diana, let him go.

L.HI: Cruel must I, can I bear—
None but the brave deserve the fair;
Come ma'am, let me lead you:
Oh, adverse stars! Oh fate severe!
None but the brave deserve the fair.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: SCENE. A Hall in Sir John Flowerdale's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: WELL, but, Mr. Lionel, consider, pray consi∣der, now, how can you be so prodigious un∣discreet as you are, walking about the hall here, while the gentlefolks are within the parlour! Don't you think they'll wonder at your getting up so soon after dinner, and before any of the rest of the company?

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Jenny, don't speak to me: I neither know where I am, nor what I am doing; I am the most wretched and miserable of mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: Poor dear soul, I pity you. Yes, yes, I believe you are miserable enough, indeed; and, I assure you, I have pitied you a great while, and spoke many words in your favour, when you little thought you had such a friend in a corner.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: But, good Jenny, since, by some accident or other, you have been able to discover what I would wil∣lingly hide from all the world, I conjure you, as you re∣gard my interest, as you value your Lady's peace and ho∣nour, never let the most distant hint of it escape you; for it is a secret of that importance—

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: And, perhaps, you think, I can't keep a secret. Ah! Mr. Lionel, it must be hear, see, and say nothing in this world, or one has no business to live in it: Besides, who would not be in love with my Lady? There's ne∣ver a man this day alive, but might be proud of it: for she's the handsomest, sweetest tempere'dest!—And I am sure, one of the best mistresses ever a poor girl had.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: Oh, Jenny, she's an angel.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: And so she is, indeed —Do you know that she gave me her blue and silver sacque to-day, and it is every crum as good as new, and, go things as they will, don't you be fretting and vexing yourself; for I am mortally certain, she would lieverer see a toad than this Jmy. Though I must say, to my thinking, he's a very likely man; and a finer pair of eye-brows, and a more delcate nose, I never saw on a fae.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: By Heavens I shall run mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: And why so? It is not beauty that always takes the fancy: moreover, to let you know, if it was, I don't think im any more to compare to you▪ than a thistle is to a carnation: and so's a sign; for▪ mark my words, my Lady loves you as much as she hates him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
SP.P: What you tell me, Jenny▪ is a thing I neither merit nor expect▪ No, I am unhappy, and let me conti∣nue so—My most presumptuous thoughts shall never carry me to a wish that may effect her quiet, or give her cause to repent.

SP.SPEAKER: Jen.
SP.P: That's very honourable of you, I must needs say! but, for all that▪ liking's liking, and one can't help it; and if it should be my lady's case, it is no fault of yours. I am sure, when she called me into her dressing-room, before she went down to dinner, there she stood, with her eyes brim full of tears; and so I tell a crying, for company—and then she said she could not abide the chap in the parlour; and, at the same time, she bid me take an opportunity to speak to you, and desire you to meet her in the garden this evening, after tea; for she has something to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lion.
