Look you, Tom, not to make any more words of the matter, I have brought the lady here with me, and I'll see you contracted before we part, or you shall delve and plant cucumbers as long as you live.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Have you brought the lady here, sir!— I am sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P:
Why sorry? what then you won't marry her? we'll see that! Pray, master Hawthorn, conduct the fair one in.—Ay, sir, you may fret, and dance
about, trot at the rate of fifteen miles an hour, if you please, but marry, whip me, I'm resolved.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Here is the lady, Sir William.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Come, in madam, but turn your face from him—he would not marry you because he had not seen you: but I'll let him know my choice shall be his, and he shall consent to marry you before he sees you, or not an acre of estate—Pray, sir, walk this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Sir, I cannot help thinking your conduct a little extraordinary; but, since you urge me so closely, I must tell you my affections are engaged.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: How, Tom, how!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: I was determined, sir, to have got the better of my inclination, and never have done a thing which I knew would be disagreeable to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: And pray, sir, who are your affections en∣gaged to? let me know that.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: To a person, sir, whose rank and fortune may be no recommendation to her; but whose charms and accomplishments entitle her to a monarch. I am sorry, sir, it's impossible for me to comply with your commands, and I hope you will not be offended if I quit your presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Not I, not in the least; go about your business.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Sir, I obey.

DIV2.STAGE: Rosetta advances, Young Meadows turns round and sees her.

SP.SPEAKER: 'Ros.
SP.L: When we see a lover languish,
'And his truth and honour prove,
'Ah! how sweet to heal his anguish,
'And repay him love for love!'

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, Tom, will you go away from me now?

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Perhaps, Sr William, your son does not like the lady; and if so, pray don't put a force upon his in∣clination.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: You need not have taken this method, sir, to let me see you are acquainted with my folly, what∣ever my inclinations are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well, but Tom, suppose I give my consent to your marrying this young woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Your consent, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Come, Sir William, we have carried the jest fa enough; I see your son is in a kind of embarrassment, and I don't wonder at it; but this letter, which I re∣ceived from him a few days before I left my father's house, will, I apprehend, expound the riddle. He cannot be surprized that I ran away from a gentleman who expressed so much dislike to me; and what has happened since chance has brought as together in masquerade, there is no occasion for me to inform him of.

SP.SPEAKER: 'Y. Meadows.'
SP.P: What is all this? Pray don't make a jest of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: May I never do an ill turn, Tom, if it is not truth; this is my friend's daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Sr!

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Even s; 'tis very true indeed. In short, you have not been a more whimsical gentleman than I have a gen∣tlewoman; but you see we are designed for one another, 'tis plain.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: I know not, madam, what I either hear or see; a thousand things are crowding on my imagina∣tion; while, like one just awakened from a dream, I doubt which is reality, which delusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Well then, Tom, come into the air a bit, and recover yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Nay, dear sir, have a little patience;— do you give her to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Give her to you! ay, that I do, and my blessing into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
Y. Mead.
SP.L: All I wish, in her obtaining,
Fortune can no more impart;

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.L: Let my eyes, my thoughts explaining,
Speak the feelings of my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Mead.
SP.L: Joy and pleasure never ceasing,

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.L: Love with length of years encreasing.

SP.SPEAKER: Together.
SP.L: Thus my heart and hand surrender,
Here my faith and troth I plight;
Constant still, and kind, and tender,
May our flames burn ever bright.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Give you joy, sir; and your fair lady— And, under favour, I'll salute you too, if there's no fear of jealousy.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: And may I believe this?—Pr'ythee tell me, dear Rosetta.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Step into the house, and I'll tell you every thing —I must intreat the good offices of Sir William and Mr. Hawthorn, immediately; for I am in the utmost uneasi∣ness about my poor friend Lucinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Why, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: I don't know, but 'I have reason to fear I left her just now in very disagreeable circumstances; how∣ever,' I hope, if there's any mischief fallen out between her father and her lover—

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: The music-master! I thought so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: What, is there a lover in the case? May I never do an ill turn, but I am glad, so I am; for we'll make a double wedding; and, by way of celebrating it, take a trip to London, to shew the brides some of the plea∣sures of the town. And, master Hawthorn, you shall be of the party—Come, children, go before us.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Thank you, Sir William; I'll go into the house with you, and to church to see the young folks married; but as to London, I beg to be excused.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR.
DIV1.L: If ever I'm catch'd in those regions of smoke,
That set of confusion and noise,
May I ne'er know the sweets of a slumber unbroke,
Nor the pleasure the country enjoys;
Nay more, let them take me, to punish my sin,
Where, gaping the Cockneys they fleece,
Clap me up with their monsters, cry, Masters walk in,
And shew me for two-pence a piece.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Justice Woodcock, Mrs. Deborah Woodcock, Lucinda, Eustace, Hodge.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Why, brother, do you think I can't hear, or see, or make use of my senses? I tell you I left that fellow locked up in her closet; and, while I have been with you, they have broke open the door, and got him out again.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Well, you hear what they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: I care not what they say: it's you encou∣rage them in their impudence—Hark'e, hussey, will you face me down that I did not lock the fellow up?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Really, aunt, I don't know what you mean; when you talk intelligibly, I'll answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: Seriously, madam, this is carrying the jest a little too far.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: What then, I did not catch you together in her chamber, nor over-heat your design of going off to∣night, nor find the bundies packed up?—

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Why, aunt, you rave.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Brother, as I am a christian woman, she confessed the whole affair to me from first to last; and in this very place was down upon her marrow-bones for half an hour together, to beg I would conceal it from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hodge.
SP.P: Oh Lord! Oh Lord!

P.HI: What, sirrah, would you brazen me too? Take that.

SP.SPEAKER: Hodge.
SP.P: I wish you would keep your hands to yourself; you strike me, because you have been telling his worship stories.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Why, sister, you are tipsey!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: I tipsey, brother?—I—that never touch a drop of any thing strong from year's end to year's end; but now and then a little anniseed-water, when I have got the cholic.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Well, au, you have been complaining of the stomach-ach to-day: and may have taken too powerful a dose of your cordial.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Come, come, I see well enough how it is; this is a lye of her own invention, to make her∣self appear wise: but, you simpleton, did you not know I must find you out?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Sir William Meadows, Hawthorn, Rosetta, and Young Meadows.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Bless me, sir! look who is yonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Cocksones, Jack! honest Jack, are you there?

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: Plague on't, this rencounter is unlucky [aside.] —Sir William, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Your servant again, and again, heartily your servant; may I never do an ill turn, but I am glad to meet you.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Pray, Sir William, are you acquainted with this person?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: What, with Jack Eustace! why he's my kinsman: his mother and I are cousin-germans once removed, and Jack's a very worthy young fellow; may I never do an ill turn if I tell a word of a lye.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Well, but Sir William, let me tell you, you know nothing of the matter; this man is a music-master; a thrummer of wire, and a scraper of cat-gut, and teaches my daughter to sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: What, Jack Eustace a music-master! no, no, I know him better.

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: 'Sdeath,' why should I attempt to carry on this absurd farce any longer?—What that gentleman tells you, is very true, sir; I am no music-master, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: You are not, you own it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: Nay, more, sir, I am, as this lady has represented me, [pointing to Mrs. Deborah] your daughter's lover; whom, with her own consent, I did intend to have car∣ried off this night; but now that Sir William Meadow is here, to tell you who, and what I am; I throw my∣self upon your generosity, from which I expect greater advantages than I could reap from any imposition on your unsuspicious nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Well, brother, 'what have you to say for yourself now?' You have made a precious day's work of it! Had my advice been taken: Oh, I am ashamed of you: but you are a weak man, and it can't be help'd; however, you should let wiser heads direct you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Dear papa, pardon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: Ay, do, sir, forgive her; my cousin Jack will make her a good husband, I'll answer for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Stand out of the way, and let me speak two or three words to his worship.—Come, my dear sir, though you refuse all the world, I am sure you can deny me no∣thing: love is a venial fault—you know what I mean.—Be reconciled to your daughter, I conjure you by the memory of our past affections—What, not a word!

LG.L: Go, naughty man, I can't abide you;
Are then your vows so soon forgot?
Ah! now I see, if I had try'd you,
What would have been my hopeful lot.
But here I charge you—Make them happy;
Bless the fond pair, and crown their bliss:
Come, be a dear good-natur'd pappy,
And I'll reward you with a kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Come, turn out of the house, and be thankful my brother does not hang you, for he could do it, he's a justice of peace;—turn out of the house, I say:—

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Who gave you authority to turn him out of the house?—he shall stay where he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: He shan't marry my niece.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Shan't e? 'but I'll shew you the differ∣ence now,' I say he shall marry her, and what will you do about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: And you will give him your estate too, will you?

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Yes, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Why, I'm sure he's a vagabond.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: I like him the better, I would have him a vagabond.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: Brother, brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Come, come, madam, all's very well; and I see my neighbour is what I always thought him, a man of sense and prudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Will.
SP.P: May I never do an ill turn, but I say so too.

SP.SPEAKER: J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Here, young fellow, take my daughter, and heaven bless you both together;—but hrk'e,— no money till I die; observe that.

SP.SPEAKER: Eust.
SP.P: Sir, in giving me your daughter, you bestow upon me, more than the whole world would be without her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Dear Lucinda, if words could convey the trans∣ports of my heart upon this occasion—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucin.
SP.P: Words are the tools of hypocrites, the pretend∣ers to friendship: only let us resolve to preserve our esteem for each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Meadows.
SP.P: Dear Jack, I little thought we should ever meet in such odd circumstances—but here has been the strangest business between this lady and me—

SP.SPEAKER: Hodge.
SP.P: What then, Mrs. Rosetta, are you turned false-hearted after all; will you marry Thomas the gardener? and did I forsake Madge for this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P:
Oh lord! Hodge, I beg your pardon; I protest
I forgot; but I must reconcile you and Mdge, I think, and give you a wedding-dinner to make you amends.
N—ah.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
J. Woodcock.
SP.P: Why, here's my hand, and we will enjoy ourselves; Heaven bless you bth, children, I say— Sister Deborah, you are a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Deb.
SP.P: You are a fool, brother; and mark my words—But I'll give myself no more trouble about you. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Hawth.
SP.P: Fiddlers, strike up.

LG.L: Hence with cares, complaints, and frowning,
Welcome jollity and joy;
Ev'ry grief in pleasure drowning,
Mirth this happy night employ:
Let's to friendship do our duty,
Laugh and sing some good old strain;
Drink a health to love and beauty—
May they long in triumph reign.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS.
SP.L: Let's to friendship, &c.

DIV1.HEAD: NEW SONG, set by SACCHINI, introduced by Mrs. BILLINGTON, at Covent-Garden, instead of that at page 38.
DIV1.L: Ah! the rural scene no more
Shall hear the tale of love;
The golden reign of truth is o'er,
And daemons haunt the grove.

DIV1.HEAD: BOOKS printed by MATHEW CAREY, And for sale, at his store, No. 118, Market-street, Philadelphia:
DIV1.P: 1. AMERICAN MUSEUM from its commencement in January, 1787, to its termination in December, 1792, in twelve vo∣lumes, price, neatly bound and lettered, nineteen dollars and one fifth.
The opinion of the President of the United States respecting this work, is as follows:

"I believe the American Museum has met with extensive▪ I may say with universal approbation from competent judges; for I am of opinion, that the work is not only eminently calculated to dissemi∣nate political, agricultural, philosophical, and other information— but that it has been uniformly conducted with taste, attention and propriety. If to these important objects be superadded the more immediate design, of rescuing public documents from oblivion—I will venture to pronounce, as my sentiment, That a more useful literary plan has never been undertaken in America, or one more de∣serving of public encouragement.

2. A complete Atlas for the present war; containing,
1. Map of the United Provinces,
2. Map of the French, Dutch, and Austrian Netherlands.
3. Map of France divided into departments.
4. Map of Spain and Portugal.
5. Map of Germany and Switzerland.
6. Map of Italy.
7. Chart of the West-Indies.
(Price Two Dollars.)

3. A short Account of ALGIERS, containing a description of that country, of the manners and customs of the inhabitants, and of their several wars against Spain, France, England, Holland, Ve∣nice, and other powers of Europe; from the usurpation of Barba∣rossa and the invasion of the emperor Charles V. to the present time; with a concise view of the Origin of the Rupture between Algiers and the United States; with a map of Algiers, Fez, Mo∣rocco, Tunis, and Tripoli.—1s10 ½.
4. A short Account of the Malignant Fever, lately prevalent in Philadelphia. To which are added an Account of the Plague in London and at Marseilles.—Price Half a Dollar.
5. The Romp, a Musical Entertainment.—Price 1s.
6. The Farmer, a comic opera.—Price 1s.
7. Don Juan, a pantomimical ballet.—Price 1s.
8. No Song no Supper.—Price 1s.
9. Wild Oats.—Price 1s6.
10. The Misses Magazine.—Price, bound in two volumes, 11s3.
11. A brief examination of the observations of lord Sheffield, on the commerce of the United States.—Price 5-8ths of a dollar.

12. The Constitution of the several States, with the Federal Constitution and the Amendments thereto. N. B. This edition contains the Constitution of Vermont; not in any former one.— Price 5-8ths of a dollar.
13. Mr Fingal, an epic poem. By John Trumbull, Esq. A new edition in 12mo.—Price 3-8ths of a dollar bound.
14. American Jest Book, in two parts, with two very neat en∣gravings.—Price bound, 3-ths of a dollar.
15. The HOLY BIBLE, translated from the Latin Vulgate. —Price in plain binding, 6 dollars—in calf, lettered, 50s2.
16. The Garden of the ul. Price, on fine paper, and bound in calf and lettered, three arters of a dollar—on common paper, plain binding, half a dollar▪
17. The devout Christian's Vade Mecum, being a summary of select and necessary devotions. Price a quarter of a dollar.
18. Think Well O't, or Reflections for every day in the Month. By Bihop Chancellor. Price a quarter of a dollar.
19. Christian Economy, translated from a Greek manuscript found in the island of Patmo, where Saint John wrote the Apo∣calypse. Price a fifth of a dollar.
20. History of Charles Grandison, abridged. Price a sixth of a dollar.
21. Poems by Col. Humphreys. Price a third of a dollar.
22. Select Poems. Price a sixth of a dollar.
23. Blair's Lectures on Rhetoric and Belles Lettres, 2 vols. 8vo. 25s.
24. Burke's Reflections on the French Revolution.—7s6.
25. Buchan's Domestic Medicine. 15s.
26. Letters from an American Farmer, describing certain provin∣cial situations, manners and customs, 5s7 ½.
27. Smith's Letters to Married Women, on nursing and the ma∣nagement of Children. 4s8.
28. Charms of Melody, a choice collection of valuable Songs. 1s10 ½.
29. Duncan's Elements of Logic. 5s7 ½.
30. Beauties of Fielding. 3s.
31. Beautie's of Blair. 3s9.
32. The Ladies' Library. 6s6.

33. Smith's History of New-York, from its first settlement to the year 1782. To which is annexed, a description of the coun∣try, with a short account of the inhabitants, their religious and political state, and the constitution of the Courts of Justice. Price a dollar and a quarter.
34. Elements of Moral Science. By James Beattie, L. L. D. Price three fourths of a dollar.
35. Sermons, by Hugh Blair, D. D. Price two dollars.
THE SUSPICIOUS HUSBAND, A COMEDY BY THE RIGHT REVEREND DR. BENJAMIN HOADLY.
PHILADELPHIA: PRINTED BY WILLIAM SPOTSWOOD M DCC XCI.

DIV1.HEAD: Dramatis Personae.
DIV1.P: SCENE, LONDON.

LG.L: WHILE other culprits brave it to the last;
Nor beg for mercy till the judgment's past:
Poets alone, as conscious of their crimes,
Open their trials with imploring rhymes.
Thus cramm'd with flattery and low submission,
Each trite dull prologue is the bard's petition.
A stale device to calm the critic's fury,
And bribe at once the judges and the jury.
But what avail such poor repeated arts?
The whimp'ring scribbler ne'er can touch your hearts:
Nor ought an ill-tim'd pity to take place—
Fast as they rise, destroy th' increasing race:
The vermin else will run the nation o'er—
By saving one, you breed a million more.
Tho' disappointed authors rail and rage,
At fancy'd parties, and a senseless age,
Yet still has justice triumph'd on the stage.
Thus speaks and thinks the author of to-day,
And saying this, has little more to say.
He asks no friend his partial zeal to show,
Nor fears the groundless censures of a foe;
He knows no friendship can protect the fool,
Nor will an audience be a party's tool.
'Tis inconsistent with a free-born spirit,
To side with folly, or to injure merit.
By your decision he must fall or stand,
Nor, tho' he feels the lash, will blame the hand.
THO' the young smarts, I see, begin to sneer,
And the old sinners cast a wicked leer:
Be not alarm'd, ye fair—you've nought to fear.
No wanton hint, no loose ambiguous sense,
Shall flatter vicious taste at your expence,
Leaving for once these shameless arts in vogue:
We give a Fable for the Epilogue.
AN ass there was, our author bid me say,
Who needs must write—he did—and wrote a play.
The parts were cast to various beasts and fowl:
Their stage a barn;—the manager an owl!
The house was cramm'd at six, with friends and foes;
Rakes, wits, and critics, citizens and beaux.
These characters appear'd in different shapes
Of tigers, foxes, horses, bulls and apes;
With others too, of lower rank and station:—
A perfect abstract of the brute creation!
Each, as he felt, mark'd out the author's faults,
And thus the connoisseurs express'd their thoughts.
The critic curs first snarl'd—the rules are broke!
Time, place, and action sacrific'd to joke!
The goats cry'd out, 'twas formal, dull, and chaste—
Not writ for beasts of gallantry and taste!
The horned-cattle were in piteous taking,
At fornification, rapes and cuckold making!
The tigers swore, he wanted fire and passion.
The apes condemn'd—because it was the fashion!
The generous steeds allow'd him proper merit:
Here mark'd his faults, and there approv'd his spirit.
While brother-bards bray'd forth with usual spleen,
And, as they heard, exploded every scene.
When reynard's thoughts were askd, the shrugging sage,
Fam'd for hypocrisy, and worn with age,
Condemn'd the shameless licence of the stage!
At which the monkey skipp'd from box to box,
And whisper'd round the judgment of the fox:
Abus'd the moderns, talk'd of Rome and Greece!
Bilk'd every box-keeper; and damn'd the piece.
Now every fable has a moral to it—
Be churchman, statesman, any thing—but poet.
In law, or physic, quack in what you will;
Cant, and grimace conceal the want of skill!
Secure in these, his gravity may pass—
But here no artifice can hide the ass.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. Ranger's Chambers in the Temple.
DIV3.P: ONCE more I am got safe to the Temple—let me reflect a little—I have sat up all night. I have my head full of bad wine, and the noise of oaths, dice, and the damned tingling of tavern bells; my spirits jaded, and my eyes sunk into my head: and all this for the conversation of a company of fellows I despise. Their wit lies only in obscenity, their mirth in noise, and their delight in a box and dice. Honest Ranger take my word for it, thou art a mighty silly fellow.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Servant, with a wig dress'd.
DIV3.P: Where have you been, rascal? If I had not had the key in my pocket, I must have waited at the door in this dainty dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I was only below combing out your honor's wig.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: [Pulling off his wig.] Well, give me my cap —why, how like a raking dog do you look, com∣pared to that spruce, sober gentleman—Go, you bat∣tered devil and be made fit to be seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Cod, my master's very merry this morning,

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: And now for the law. Reads.

LG.L: Tell me no more I am deceiv'd,
That Chloe's false and common.
By Heav'n, I all along believ'd
She was a very woman.
As such I lik'd, as such caress'd;
She still was constant when possest:
She could do more for no man.

SP.P: Honest Congreve was a man after my own heart. Enter Servant. Have you been for the money this morning, as I or∣dered you?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: No, sir, you bad me go before you was up— I did not know your honor meant before you went to to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: None of your jokes, I pray, but to business— go to the coffee-house, and enquire if there has been any letter or message left for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I shall, sir. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.

L.HI: You think she's false, I'm sure she's kind,
I take her body, you her mind;

SP.P: Oh, that I had such a soft, deceitful fair to lull my senses to their desired sleep— [Knocking at the door.] Come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Oh, master Simon, is it you? How long have you been in town?

SP.SPEAKER: Simon.
SP.P: Just come, sir, and but for a little time nei∣ther; and yet I have as many messages as if we were to stay the whole year round. Here they are all of them. [Pulls out a number of cards.] And among them one for your honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: [Reads] Clarinda's Compliments to her Cousin Ranger, and should be glad to see him for ever so little a time that can be spared from the more weighty business of the law— Ha! ha! ha! the same merry girl I ever knew her.

SP.SPEAKER: Simon.
SP.P: My lady is never sad, sir, Knocking at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Pry'thee, Simon, open the door. Enter Millener. Well, child—and who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mille.
SP.P: Sir my mistress gives her service to you, and has sent you home the linen you bespoke.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Well Simon, my service to your lady, and let her know I will most certainly wait upon her—I am a little busy, Simon—and so—

SP.SPEAKER: Simon.
SP.P: Ah, you're a wag, Master Ranger, you're a wag—but mum for that! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: I swear my dear, you have the prettiest pair of eyes—the loveliest pouting lips—I never saw you before.

SP.SPEAKER: Mille.
SP.P: No, sir, I was always in the shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Was you so? Well, and what does your mis∣tress say?—The Devil fetch me, child, you looked so prettily, that I could not mind one word you said.

SP.SPEAKER: Mille.
SP.P: Lard, sir, you are such another gentleman! Why, she says she is sorry she could not send them soon∣er. Shall I lay them down?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: No, child. Give'em me! dear little smiling angel— Catches and kisses her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mille.
SP.P: I beg, sir, you would be civil.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Civil! Egad, I think I am very civil.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, Mr. Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Damn your impertinence—Oh, Mr. Ballamy, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mille.
SP.P: What shall I say to my mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Bid her make half a dozen more; but be sure you bring them home yourself. [Exit Millener] Pshah! pox! Mr. Bellamy, how should you like to be served so yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: How can you, Ranger, for a minute's plea∣sure, give an innocent girl the pain of heart I am con∣fident she felt?—There was a modest blush upon her cheek convinces me she was honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: May be so. I was resolved to try, however.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Fy, Ranger,—will you never think?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P:
Yes, but I can't be always thinking. The law is a damnable dry study, Mr. Bellamy, and with∣out something now and then to amuse, and relax, it would be too much for my brain, I promise ye—but I am a mighty sober fellow grown—Here have I been
at it these three hours—but the wenches will never let me alone—

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Three hours! Why, do you usually study in such shoes and stockings?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Rat your inquisitive Eyes. Ex pede Herculem. Egad, you have me! The truth is I am but this mo∣ment returned from the tavern. What, Frankly here too!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My boy Ranger, I am heartily glad to see you. Bellamy, let me embrace you. You are the person I want. I have been at your lodgings, and was direct∣ed hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: It is to him then I am obliged for this visit: but with all my heart—he is the only man, to whom I don't care how much I am obliged.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Your very humble servant, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: You know Ranger, I want no inducement to be with you. But—you look sadly—what—no mer∣ciless jade has—has she?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: No, no, sound as a roach my lad. I only got a little too much liquor last night, which I have not slept off yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Thus, Frankly, it is every day. All the morning his head aches, at noon he begins to clear up, to∣wards evening he is good company, and all night he is carefully providing for the same course the next day.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why, I must own, my ghostly father, I did relapse a little lastnight, just to furnish out a decent confession for the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And he is now doing penance for it. Were you his confessor indeed, you could not well desire more.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Charles, he sets up for a confessor with the worst grace in the world. Here he has been reproving me for being but decently civil to my millener. Plague! because the coldness of his constitution makes him in∣sensible of a fine woman's charms, every body else must be so too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I am no less sensible of their charms than you are; tho' I cannot kiss every woman I meet, or fall in love, as you call it, with every face which has the bloom of youth upon it. I would only have you a lit∣tle more frugal of your pleasures.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My dear friend, this is very pretty talking. But let me tell you, it is in the power of the very first glance from a fine woman utterly to disconcert all your philosophy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: It must be from a fine woman then: and not such as are generally reputed so—and it must be a tho∣rough acquaintance with her too, that will ever make an impression on my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Would I could see it once! for when a man has been all his life hoarding up a stock, without allow∣ing himself common necessaries, it tickles me to the soul to see him lay it all out upon a wrong bottom, and become a bankrupt at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Well, I don't care how soon you see it. For the minute I find a woman capable of friendship, love, and tenderness, with good sense enough to be always easy, and good nature enough to like me, I will im∣mediately put it to the trial, which of us shall have the greatest share of happiness from the sex, you or I.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: By marrying her, I suppose! Capable of friend∣ship, love, and tenderness, ha, ha, ha! That a man of your sense should talk so. If she be capable of love 'tis all I require of my mistress; and as every woman, who is young, is capable of love, I am very reasonably in love with every young woman I meet.—My Lord Coke, in a case I read this very morning, speaks my very sense.

SP.SPEAKER: Both.
SP.P: My Lord Coke!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord Coke! What he says of one woman, I say of the whole sex. I take their bodies, you their minds; which has the better bargain?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: There is no arguing with so great a lawyer. Suppose therefore we adjourn the debate to some other time. I have some serious business with Mr. Bellamy, and you want sleep I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Sleep! mere loss of time, and hindrance of business—We men of spirit, sir, are above it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Whither shall we go?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Into the Park. My chariot is at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Then if my servant calls, you'll send him after us. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P:
I will. [Looking on the card.] Clarinda's
compliments—a pox of this head of mine! Never once to ask where she was to be found. It's plain she is not one of us, or should not have been so remiss in my inquiries.—No matter—I shall meet her in my walks.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: There is no letter nor message, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Then my things, to dress Exeunt

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. A CHAMBER.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Strictland and Jacintha, meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Good-morrow my dear Jacintha.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Good-morrow to you, madam. I have brought my work, and intend to sit with you this morning. I hope you have got the better of your fa∣tigue. Where is Clarinda? I should be glad if she would come and work with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: She work! she is too fine a lady to do any thing. She is not stirring yet—we must let her have her rest. People of her waste of spirits require more time to recruit again.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: It is pity she should be ever tired with what is so agreeable to every body else. I am prodigiously pleased with her company.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: And when you are better acquainted, you will be still more pleased with her. You must ral∣ly her upon her partner at Bath: for, I fancy, part of her rest has been disturbed on his account.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Was he really a pretty fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: That I can't tell. I did not dance my∣self, and so did not much mind him. You must have the whole story from herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Oh! I warrant ye, I get it all out. None are so proper to make discoveries in love as those who are in the secret themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P:
Madam, Mr. Strictland is enquiring for you.
Here has been Mr. Buckle with a letter from his master, which has made him very angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Mr. Bellamy, said indeed he would try him once more, but I fear it will prove in vain. Tell your master I am here. [Exit Lucetta] What signifies for∣tune, when it only makes us slaves to other people?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Do not be uneasy, my Jacintha You shall always find a friend in me: but as for Mr. Strict∣land, I know not what ill temper hangs about him lately. Nothing satisfies him. You saw how he receiv∣ed us when we came off our journey; tho' Clarinda was so good company. He was barely civil to her, and downright rude to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I cannot help saying I did observe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I saw you did. Hush! he's here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Oh, your servant, madam! here I have received a letter from Mr Bellamy, wherein he desires I would once more hear what he has to say—You know my sentiments — Nay, so does he.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake consider, sir. This is no new affair, no sudden start of passion—We have known each other long. My father valued and loved him; and I am sure were he alive, I should have his consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Don't tell me. Your father would not have you marry against his will; neither will I, against mine; I am your father now.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: And you take a fatherly care of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I wish I had never had any thing to do with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: You may easily get rid of the trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: By listening, I suppose, to the young gentleman's proposals.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Which are very reasonable, in my opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P:
Oh, very modest ones, truly; and a very modest gentleman it is that proposes them! a fool, to expect a lady of thirty thousand pounds fortune should, by the care and prudence of her guardian, be thrown away upon a young fellow not worth three hundred a year. He thinks being in love is an excuse
for all this; but I am not in love. What does he think will excuse me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Well, but Mr. Strictland, I think the gentleman should be heard.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Well, well! Seven o'clock is the time if the man has the good fortune, since I saw him last, to persuade somebody or other to give him a better estate, I give him my consent not else. His servant waits below. You may tell him, I shall be at home. [Exit Jacin.] But where is your friend, your other half, all this while? I thought you could not have breath'd a minute without your Clarinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Why, the truth is, I was going to see what makes her keep her chamber so long.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Look ye Mrs. Strictland, you have been asking me for money this morning. In plain terms, not one shilling shall pass through these fingers, till you have cleared my house of this Clarinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: How can her innocent gaiety have of∣fended you? She is a woman of honor, and has as ma∣ny good qualities—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: As women of honor generally have. I know it and therefore am uneasy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: But, sir,—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: But madam,—Clarinda, nor e'er a rake of fashion in England, shall live in my family to debauch it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Sir, she treated me with so much civi∣lity in the country, that I thought I could not do less than invite her to spend as much time with me in town, as her engagements would permit. I little imagined you could have been displeased at my having so agreea∣ble a companion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: There was a time when I was company enough for leisure hours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: There was a time when every word of mine was sure of meeting with a smile: but those hap∣py days, I know not why, have long been over.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I cannot bear a rival, even of your own sex. I hate the very name of female friends. No two of you can ever be an hour by yourselves, but one or both are the worse for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Dear Mr. Strictland.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: This I know,—and will not suffer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: It grieves me, sir, to see you so much in earnest: but to convince you how willing I am to make you easy in every thing, it shall be my request to her to remove immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict
SP.P: Do it then—hark ye?—your request, why your's? it's mine.—My command—tell her so— I will be master in my own family, and I care not who knows it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: You fright me, sir —but it shall be as you please. [In tears.] Goes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ha! have I not gone too far? I am not maer of myself—Mrs. Strictland.— [she returns.] Understand me right. I do not mean by what I have said, that I suspect your innocence: but by crushing this growing friendship all at once, I may prevent a train of mischief which you do not foresee. I was perhaps too harsh, therefore do it in your own way. But let me see the house fairly rid of her. Exit. Mr. Strictland.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: His earnestness in this affair amazes me. I am sorry I made this visit to Clarinda— and yet I'll an∣swer for her honor—what can I say to her? Necessity must plead in my excuse—for at all events, Mr. Strict∣land must be obeyed.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. St. JAMES'S PARK.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Now, Bellamy, I may unfold the secret of my heart to you with greater freedom; for though Ran∣ger has honor, I am not in a humour to be laughed at. I must have one, that will bear with my impertinence, sooth me into hope, and like a friend indeed, with ten∣derness advise me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I thought you appeared more grave than usual.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P:
Oh! Bellamy, my soul is so full of joy, of
pain, hope, despair and extasy, that no word but love is capable of expressing what I feel.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Is love the secret Ranger is not fit to hear? In my mind, he wou'd prove the more able counsellor. And is all the gay indifference of my friend at last re∣duced to love?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Even so—Never was prude more esolute in chastity and ill-nature, than I was fixed in indifference: but love has rais'd me from that inactive state above the being of a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Faith, Charles, I begin to think it has—but pray bring this rapture into order a little, and tell me regularly, how, where, and when?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: If I was not most unreasonably in love, those horrid questions would stop my mouth at once. But as I am arm'd against reason—I answer—at Bath—on Tuesday, she danced and caught me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Danced?—and was that all? But who is she? What is her name? her fortune? where does she live?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Hold! hold! not so many hard questions. Have a little mercy. I know but little of her, thats certain. But all I do know you shall have. That even∣ing was the first of her appearing at Bath. The moment I saw her I resolved to ask the favour of her hand. But the easy freedom with which she gave it, and her unaf∣fected good-humour during the whole night, gaind such a power over my heart, as none of her sex could ever boast before. I waited on her home, and the next morn∣ing, when I went to make the usual compliments, the bird was flown. She had set out for London two hours before; and in a chariot and six—you rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: But was it her own, Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: That I don't know; but it looks better than being drag'd to own in the stage. That day and the next I spent in enquiries. I waited on the ladies who came with her. They knew nothing of her. So, with∣out learning either her name or fortune, I e'en call'd for my boots, and rode post after her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: And how do you find yourself after your journey?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P:
Why, as yet, I own, I am but upon a cold
scent. But a woman of her sprightliness and gentility cannot but frequent all public places; and when once she is found, the pleasure of the chase will over-pay the pains of rousing her. Oh! Bellamy, there was some∣thing peculiarly charming in her, that seemed to claim my farther acquaintance: and if in the other more fa∣miliar parts of life she shines with that superior lustre, and at last I win her to my arms, how shall I bless my resolution in pursuing her!

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: But if, at last she should prove unworthy—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I would endeavour to forget her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Promise me that, Charles, [Takes his hand.] and I allow—but we are interrupted.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Whom have we here? my old friend Frankly? Thou art grown a meer antique since I saw thee: how hast thou done these five hundred years?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Even as you see me; well, and at your ser∣vice, ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Ha! who's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: A friend of mine. Mr. Bellamy, this is Jacky Meggot, sir, as honest a fellow as any in life.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Pho! prithee! pox! Charles—Don't be silly—Sir, I am your humble—Any one who is a friend of my Frankly's I am proud of embracing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Sir, I shall endeavour to deserve your civility.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Oh! sir,—Well! Charles, what?—dumb? Come, come; you may talk tho' you have nothing to say, as I do—Let us hear, where have you been?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why, for this last week, Jack, I have been at Bath?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Bath! the most ridiculous place in life! —amongst tradesmens wives that hate their husbands, and people of quality that had rather go to the devil than stay at home. People of no taste—no gost— and for divertimenti; if it were not for the puppet-show, la vertu would be dead amongst them.—But the news, Charles?—the ladies,—I fear your time hung heavy on your hands, by the small slay you made there.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P:
Faith and so it did Jack. The ladies are grown such idiots in love—the cards have so debauch'd
their five senses, that Love, almighty Love himself, is utterly neglected.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: It is the strangest thing in life, but it is just so with us abroad. Faith! Charles! to tell you a secret, which I don't care, if all the world knows, I am almost surfeited with the services of the ladies; she modest ones I mean. The vast variety of duties they expect—a dressing up to the fashion, losing fashionably, keeping fshionable hours, drinking fashionable liquors, and fifty other such irregular niceties, so ruin a man's pocket and constitution, that foregad! he must have the estate of a duke, and the strength of a gondolier, who would list himself into their servie!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: A free confession truly, Jack, for one of your coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: The ladies are oblig'd to you.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Buckle, with a ltter to Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Oh lard! Charles! I have had the greatest misfortune in life, since I saw you—poor Otho! that I brought from Rome with me, is dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Well! well! get you another, and all will be well again.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: No! the rogue broke me so much china, and gnaw'd my Spanish eaher shoes so filthily, that when he was dead, I begn not to endure him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Exactly at seven! run back, and assure him I will not fal. [Exit Buckle.] Dead! pray, who was the gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: This gentleman was my monkey, sir,— an odd sort of a feow that used to divert me,—and pleased every body so at Rome, that he always made o n our conversazioni. But Mr. Bellamy, I saw a servant, I hope no engagement. For you two positively shall dine with me. I have the finest macaroni in life. Oblige me so far.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella,
SP.P: Sir,— your servant! what say you, Frankly?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Pho! pox! Charles! you shall go. My aunts think you begin to neglect them; and old maids, you know, are the most jealous creatures in life.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ranger swears they can't be maids, they are so good naturd! Well! I agree, on condition I may eat what I please, and go away just when I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Ay! ay! you shall do just what you will. But how shall we do? my post-chaise won't carry us all.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My chariot is here; and I will conduct Mr. Bellamy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Mr. Meggot,—I beg pardon, I can't possibly dine out of town! I have an engagement early in the evening.—

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Out of town! no, my dear! I live just by. I see one of the Dilettanti, I would not miss speaking to for the universe. And so I expect you at three. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! and so you thought you had at least fifty miles to go post for a spoonful of macaroni.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I suppose then he is just come out of the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Nor that neither. I would venture a wager, from his own house hither; or to an auction or two of old dirty pictures, is the utmost of his travels to-day: or he may have been in pursuit, perhaps, of a new cargo of Venetian tooth-picks.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: A special acquaintance I have made to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: For all this, Bellamy, he has a heart worthy your friendship. He spends his estate freely, and you cannot oblige him more, than by showing him how he can be of service to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Now you say something. It is the heart, Frankly, I value in a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Right!—and there is a heart even in a wo∣man's breast that is worth the purchase, or my judg∣ment has deceived me. Dear Bellamy, I know your concern for me. See her first, and then blame me, if you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: So far from blaming you, Charles, that if my endeavours can be serviceable, I will beat the bushes with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: That I am afraid will not do. For you know less of her than I. But if in your walks you meet a finer woman than ordinary, let her not escape till I have seen her.—Wheresoe'er she is, she cannot long lie hid. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Clarinda, Jacintha and Mrs. Strictland.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: AY! ay! we both stand condemn'd out of our own mouths.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Why I cannot but own—I never had a thought of any man that troubled me, but of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Then I dare swear, by this time, you heartily repent your leaving Bath so soon.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Indeed you are mistaken. I have not had one scruple since.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Why, what one inducement can he have ever to think of you again?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Oh! the greatest of all inducements, curiosity. Let me assure you, a woman's surest hold over a man is to keep him in uncertainty. As soon as ever you put him out of doubt, you put him out of your power: but when once a woman has awak'd his curiosity, she may lead him a dance of many a troublesome mile without the least fear of losing him at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Now do I heartily wish he may have spirit enough to follow and use you as you deserve. Such a spirit, with but a little knowledge of our sex, might put that heart of yours into a strange flutter.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I care not how soon. I long to meet with such a fellow. Our modern beaux are such jointed babies in love, they have no feeling. They are entirely insen∣sible either of pain or pleasure, but from their own dear persons: and according as we flatter, or affront their beauty, they admire or forsake ours. They are not worthy even our displeasure; and, in short, abusing them is but so much ill-nature merely thrown away. But the man of sense, who values himself upon his high abilities: or the man of wit, who thinks a woman be∣neath his conversation—to see such the subjects of our power, the slaves of our frowns and smiles is glo∣rious indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: No men of sense, or wit either, if they be truly so, ever did, or ever can think a woman of me∣rit beneath their wisdom to converse with.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Nor will such a woman value herself upon making such a lover uneasy.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Amazing! why, every woman can give ease; you cannot be in earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I can assure you she is, and has put in practice the doctrine she has been teaching.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Impossible! who ever heard the name of love mention'd without an idea of torment? But pray let us hear.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Nay, there is nothing to hear that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: So I suspected, indeed! the novel is not likely to be long, when the lady is so well prepared for the denouement.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: The novel, as you call it, is not so short as you may imagine. I and my spark have been long acquainted. As he was continually with my father, I soon perceived that he loved me, and the manner of his expressing that love was what pleas'd and won me most.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Well! and how was it? the old bait! Flattery, dear Flattery, I warrant ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: No indeed,—I had not the pleasure of hearing my person, wit and beauty painted out with forced praises; but I had a more sensible delight in perceiving the drift of his whole behaviour was to make every hour of my time pass-away agreeably.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: The rustic! what, did he never say a hand∣some thing of your person?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: He did, it seems what pleas'd her bet∣ter. He flatter'd her good sense as much as a less cun∣ning lover would have done her beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: On my conscience you are well match'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: So well, that if my guardian denies me hap∣piness, (and this evening he is to pass his final sentence) nothing is left but to break my prison, and fly into my lover's arms for safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Hey day! O my conscience, thou art a brave girl. Thou art the very first prude that ever had ho∣nesty enough to avow her passion for a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: And thou art the first finish'd coquet who ever had any honesty at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Come, come! you are both too good for either of those characters.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: And my dear Mrs. Strictland here, is the first young married woman of spirit, who has an ill-natur'd fellow for a husband, and never once thinks of using him as he deserves.—Good heaven, if I had such a hus∣band—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: You would be just as unhappy as I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: But come now—confess—do not you long to be a widow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Would I were any thing but what I am!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Then go the nearest way about it. I'd break that stout heart of his in less than a fortnight. I'd make him know—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Pray be silent. You know my resolu∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I know you have no resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: You are a mad creature, but I forgive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: It is all meant kindly, I assure you. But since you won't be persuaded to your good; I will think of making you easy in your submission as soon as ever I can. I dare say, I may have the same lodging I had last year. I can know immediately—I see my chair: and so ladies both, adieu! Exit Clarinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Come, Mrs. Strictland, we shall but just have time to get home before Mr. Bellamy comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Let us return then to our common prison. You must forgive my ill-nature, Jacintha, if I almost wish Mr. Strictland may refuse to join your hand where your heart is given.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Lord! madam, what do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Self-interest only, child! methinks your company in the country would soften all my sorrows, and I could bear them patiently.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Dear Mrs. Strictland—I am so confus'd, and so out of breath—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Why, why what is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I protest you fright me.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P:
Oh! I have no time to recover myself, I am
so frighten'd and so pleas'd. In short then, the dear man is here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Here—lord—where?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I met him this instant. I saw him at a distance, turn'd short; and ran hither directly. Let us go home, I tell you he follows me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Why, had you not better stay, and let him speak to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Ay! but—then—he won't know where I live without telling him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Come, the Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Ah! poor Clarinda!—Allons don. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Sure that must be she! her shape and easy air cannot be so exactly copied by another.—Now, you young rogue, Cupid, guide me directly to her, as you would the surest arrow in your quiver. Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. Changes to the street before Mr. Strictland's door.
DIV3.STAGE: Re-enter Clarinda, Jacintha, and Mrs. Strictland.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Lord!—dear Jacintha—for heaven's sake make haste. He'll overtake us before we get in.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Overtake us? Why, he is not in sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Is not he? Ha! sure I have not dropped my twee—I would not have him lose sight of me neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Here he is—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: In—in— in then.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: [Laughing.] What, without your twee?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Pshah! I have lost nothing—In—I'll follow you. Exeunt into the house. Clarinda last.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: It is impossible I should be deceived: my eyes and the quick pulses at my heart assure me it is she. Ha! 'tis she, by heaven! and the door left open too— a fair invitation, by all the rules of Love— Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. Changes to an apartment in Mr. Strictland's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I hope, madam, you will excuse the boldness of this intrusion, since it is owing to your own behavi∣our that I am forc'd to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: To my behaviour, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: You cannot but remember me at Bath, ma∣dam, where I so lately had the favour of your hand—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I do remember, sir; but I little expected any wrong interpretation of my behaviour, from one, who had so much the appearance of a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: What I saw of your behaviour was so just, it would admit of no misinterpretation. I only fear'd, whatever reason you had to conceal your name from me at Bath, you might have the same to do it now; and tho' my happiness was so nearly concerned, I rather chose to venture thus abruptly after you, than be im∣pertinently inquisitive.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Sir, there seems to be so much civility in your rudeness, that I can easily forgive it; tho' I don't see how your happiness is at all concerned.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No, madam! I believe you are the only lady, who could with the qualifications you are mistress of, be insensible of the power they give you over the hap∣piness of our sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: How vain should we women be, if you gen∣tlemen were but wise! if you did not all of you say the same things to every woman, we should certainly be foolish enough to believe some of you were in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Could you have the least sense of what I feel whilst I am speaking, you would know me to be in earnest, and what I say to be the dictates of a heart that admires you. May I not say—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Sir, this is carrying the—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P:
When I danced with you at Bath, I was charmed with your whole behaviour, and felt the same tender admiration: but my hope of seeing you after∣wards kept in my passion till a more proper time should
offer. You cannot therefore blame me now, if after having lost you once, I do not suffer an inexcusable mo∣desty to prevent my making use of this second oppor∣tunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: This behaviour, sir, is so different from the gaiety of your conversation then, that I am at a loss how to answer you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: There is nothing, madam, which could take off from the gaiety with which your presence inspires every heart, but the fear of losing you. How can I be otherwise than as I am, when I know not, but you may leave London as abruptly as you did Bath?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Madam, the tea is ready, and my mistress waits for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Very well, I come— [Exit Lucetta.] You see, sir, I am called away; but I hope you will excuse it, when I leave you with an assurance, that the business which brings me to town will keep me here some time.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: How generous it is in you thus to ease the heart, that knew not how to ask for such a favour—I fear to offend— but this house, I suppose is yours?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: You will hear of me, if not find me here.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I then take my leave. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I'm undone! he has me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Well! How do you find yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I do find—that if he goes on, as he has begun, I shall certainly have him without giving him the least uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: A very terrible prospect, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: But I must teize him a little.—Where is Ja∣cintha? How she will laugh at me, if I become a pu∣pil of hers, and learn to give ease. No! positively I shall never do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Poor Jacintha has met with what I fear∣ed, from Mr. Strictland's temper—an utter denial. I know not why, but he really grows more and more ill-natured.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P:
Well! now do I heartily wish my affairs were
in his power a little, that I might have a few difficulties to surmount.—I love difficulties—and yet, I don't know, it is as well as it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! Come the tea waits.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: These doings in my house distract me! I met a fine gentleman—when I enquired who he was; why he came to Clarinda. I met a footman too, and he came to Clarinda. I shall not be easy till she is de∣camped. My wife had the character of a virtuous wo∣man—and they have not been long acquainted. But then they were by themselves at Bath! that hurts— that hurts— they must be watched— they must—I know them, I know all their wiles, and the best of them are but hypocrites. Ha!— [Lucetta passes over the stage.] Suppose I bribe the maid—she is of their counsel—the manager of their secrets—It shall be so— money will do it, and I shall know all that passes. Lu∣cetta!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Sir. If he should suspect, and search me now I'm undone. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: She is a sly girl, and may be serviceable. [Aside.] Lucetta, you are a good girl, and have an ho∣nest face. I like it. It looks as if it carried no deceit in it.—Yet if she should be false, she can do me no harm.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Pray sir, speak out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [Aside.] No! she is a woman, and it is the highest imprudence to trust her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I am not able to understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I am glad of it. I would not have you understand me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Then what did you call me for? If he should be in love with my face, it would be rare sport. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [Aside.] Tster, ay, Tester is the proper person—Lucetta, tell Tester I want him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P:
Yes, sir.— [Aside.] mighty odd, this! it
gives me time however to send Buckle with this letter to his master. Exit Lucetta.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Could I but be once well satisfied that my wife had really finished me, I believe I should be as quiet, as if I were sure of the contrary.—But whilst I am in doubt, I am miserable.

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: Does your honor please to want me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ay, Tester.—I need not fear. The ho∣nesty of his service, and the goodness of his look make me secure. I will trust him. [Aside.] —Tester, I think I have been a tolerable good master to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: Yes, sir,— very tolerable.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [Aside.] I like his simplicity well. It promises honesty—I have a secret to impart to you— a thing of the greatest importance. Look upon me, and don't stand picking your fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: Yes, sir,—no, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: But will not his simplicity expose him the more to Lucetta's cunning? Yes, yes! she will worm the secret out of him. I had better trust her with it at once.—So—I will. [Aside.] Tester, go send Lucetta hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: Yes, sir, here she is. Re-enter Lucetta. Lucetta, my master wants you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Get you down, Tester.

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: Yes, sir. Exit Tester.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: If you want me, sir, I beg you would make haste, for I have a thousand things to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Well! well! what I have to say will not take up much time, could I but persuade you to be honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Why, sir, I hope you don't suspect my ho∣nesty?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Well! well! I believe you honest.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: What can be at the bottom of all this? Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: So! we cannot be too private. Come hither hussy! nearer yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Laud! sir! you are not going to be rude? I vow, I will call out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Hold your tongue. Does the baggage laugh at me? [Aside.] She does—she mocks me, and will reveal it to my wife; and her insolence upon it will be more insupportable to me than cuckoldom it∣self I have not leisure now, Lucetta—some other time—hush! did not the bell ring? Yes, yes; my wife wants you. Go, go, go to her. [Pushes her out.] There is no hell on earth like being a slave to suspicion

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Nay, nay, I would not put your family into any confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: None in life, my dear, I assure you. I will go and order every thing this instant for her recep∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: You are too obliging, sir; but you need not be in this hurry, for I am in no certainty when I shall trouble you: I only know that my Jacintha has taken such a resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Therefore we should be prepared; for when once a lady has such a resolution in her head, she is upon the rack till she executes it, foregad! Mr. Bellamy, this must be a girl of fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Buxom and lively as the bounding doe.—Fair a painting can express, or youthful poets fancy when they love. Tol de rol, lol! Singing and dancing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Who is this you talk thus rapturously of?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Who should it be, but—I shall know her name to-morrow. Sings and dances.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: What is the matter, ho! Is the man mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Even so, gentlemen, as mad as love and joy can make me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: But inform us whence this joy proceeds?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Joy! joy! my lads! she's found! My Per∣dita! my charmer!

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Egad! her charms have bewitched the man I think—but who is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Come, come, tell us who is this wonder?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: But will you say nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Nothing, as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Nor you?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: I'll be as silent as the grave—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: With a tombstone upon it, to tell every one whose dust you carry.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: I'll be as secret as a debauch'd prude—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Whose sanctity every one suspects. Jack, Jack, 'tis not in thy nature. Keeping a secret is worse to thee than keeping thy accounts. But to leave fool∣ing, listen to me, both, that I may whisper it into your ears, that Echo may not catch the sinking sound—I cannot tell who she is, 'faith—Tol de rol, lol—

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Mad! mad! very mad!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: All I know of her is, that she is a charming woman, and has given me liberty to visit her again— Bellamy, 'tis she, the lovely she. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: So I did suppose. To Frankly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Poor Charles! for heaven's sake, Mr. Bellamy, persuade him home to his chamber.—Whilst I prepare every thing for you at home. [Aside.] Adieu! —b'ye Charles! ha, ha, ha! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: O, Love! thou art a gift worthy of a god indeed! dear Bellamy, nothing now could add to my pleasure, but to see my friend as deep in love as I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I show my heart is capable of love, by the friendship it bears to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: The light of friendship looks but dim be∣fore the brighter flame of love. Love is the spring of chearfulness and joy. Why, how dull and phleg∣matic do you show to me now? whilst I am all life; light as feather'd Mercury.—You dull, and cold as earth and water; I light and warm as air and fire.— Those are the only elements in Love's world! why, Bellamy, for shame! get thee a mistress, and be so∣ciable.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Frankly, I am now going to—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why, that face now? your humble servant, sir. My flood of joy shall not be stopt by your melan∣choly fits, I assure you. Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Stay, Frankly, I beg you stay. What would you say now, if I really were in love?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why, faith, thou hast such romantic notions of sense and honor, that I know not what to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: To confess the truth then, I am in love.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And do you confess it as if it were a sin? proclaim it loud—glory in it—boast of it as your greatest virtue—swear it with a lover's oath, and I will believe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Why then, by the bright eyes of her I love!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Well said!

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: By all that's tender, amiable, and soft in wo∣man—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Bravo!

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I swear I am as true an enamorato as ever tagg'd a rhyme!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And art thou then thoroughly in love? Come to my arms, thou dear companion of my joys—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why—hey!—Is there never a wench to be got for love or money?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Pshah! Ranger here!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Yes, Ranger is here, and perhaps does not come so impertinently as you may imagine. Faith! I think I have the knack of finding out secrets. Nay, never look so queer.—Here is a letter Mr. Bellamy, that seems to promise you better diversion than your hugging one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Do you deal much in these paper tokens?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Oh! the dear kind creature! It is from her herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: What! is it a pair of lac'd shoes she wants? or have the boys broke her windows?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Hold your prophane tongue!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Nay, prithee Bellamy, don't keep it to yourself, as if her whole affections were contained in these few lines.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Prithee let him alone to his silent raptures: but it is, as I always said—your grave men ever are the greatest whore-masters.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I cannot be disoblig'd now, say what you will. But how came this into your hands?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Your servant Buckle and I chang'd commissions. He went on my errand, and I came on his.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: S'death! I want him this very instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: He will be here presently! but I demand to know what I have brought you?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ay! ay! out with it! you know we never blab, and may be of service.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Twelve o'clock! oh! the dear hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why, it is a pretty convenient time, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: By all that's happy, she promises in this letter here—to leave her guardian this very night—and run away with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: How is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Nay, I know not how myself— she says at the bottom—Your servant has full instructions from Lucetta, how to equip me for my expedition—I will not trust myself home with you to-night, because I know it is inconvenient; therefore I beg you would procure me a lodging; it is no matter how far off my guardian's.—Yours, Jacintha.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Carry her to a bagnio, and there you may lodge with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why this must be a girl of spirit, faith!

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: And beauty equal to her sprightliness. I love her, and she loves me—she has thirty thousand to her fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: The devil she has!

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: And never plays at cards—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Nor does any one thing like any one other wo∣man I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Not so, I hope, neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Oh! Frankly, Ranger. I never felt such ease before. The secret's out, and you don't laugh at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Laugh at thee?—for loving a woman with thirty thousand pounds! thou art a most unaccountable fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: How the devil could he work her up to this? I never could have had the face to have done it. But— I know not how—there is a degree of assurance in you modest gentlemen, which we impudent fellows can ne∣ver come up to—

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Oh! your servant, good sir; you should not abuse me now, Ranger, but do all you can to assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why, look ye, Bellamy, I am a damnable unlucky fellow—and so will have nothing to do in this affair. I'll take care to be out of the way, so as to do you no harm. This is all I can answer for, and so success attend you. [Going.] I cannot leave you quite to yourself neither, for if this should prove a round∣house affair, as I make no doubt it will, I believe I may have more interest there than you; and so, sir, you may hear of me at— Whispers.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: For shame, Ranger, the most noted gaming-house in town.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Forgive me this once, my boy. I must go, faith, to pay a debt of honor to some of the greatest ras∣cals in the nation. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: But where do you design to lodge her?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: At Mr. Meggot's—he is already gone to pre∣pare for her reception.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: The properest place in the world. His aunts will entertain her with honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: And the newness of our acquaintance will pre∣vent its being suspected.—Frankly, give me your hand. This is a very critical time—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Pho! none of your musty reflections now! when a man is in love to the very brink of matrimony, what the devil has he to do with Plutarch and Seneca? Here is your servant with a face full of business—I'll leave you together— I shall be at the King's Arms, where, if you want my assistance, you may find me. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: So—Buckle—you seem to have your hands full.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Not fuller than my head, sir, I promise you. You have had your letter, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Yes, and in it she refers me to you for my in∣structions.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: Why, the affair stands thus—as Mr. Strictland sees the doors lock'd and barr'd every night himself, and takes the keys up with him; it is impossible for us to escape any way but thro' the window: for which pur∣pose I have a ladder of ropes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Good—

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: And because a hoop, as the ladies wear them now, is not the most decent dress to come down a lad∣der in—I have in this other bundle a suit of boy's cloaths, which I believe will fit her. At least, it will serve the time she will want it—you will soon be for pulling them off, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella
SP.P: Why, you are in spirits, you rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Buck.
SP.P: These I am now to convey to Lucetta—have you any thing to say, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Nothing, but that I will not fail at the hour appointed—bring me word to Mr. Meggot's how you go on. Succeed in this, and it shall make your fortune.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. The street before Mr. Strictland's house.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Bellamy in a chairman's coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: HOW tediously have the minutes past these last few hours! and the envious rogues will fly, no lightning quicker, when we would have them stay.—Hold! let me not mistake.—This is the house. [Pulls out his watch.] By heaven! it is not yet the hour— I hear somebody coming. The moon's so bright—I had better not be here, 'till the happy in∣stant comes. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Wine is no antidote to love, but rather feeds the flame. Now am I such an amorous puppy, that I cannot walk straight home, but must come out of my way to take a view of my queen's palace by moon-light. Ay, here stands the temple where my goddess is ador∣ed! The door opens. Retires.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: [Under the window.] Madam, madam, hist! madam.—How shall I make her hear?

DIV3.STAGE: Jacintha in boys clothes at the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Who is there? —what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P:
It is I, madam. You must not pretend to
stir till I give the word—you will be discovered if you do.—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: [Aside.] What do I see! a man. My heart misgives me!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: My master is below fitting up for Mrs. Cla∣rinda. He aves as if he was mad about her being out so late.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: [Aside.] Here is some intrigue or other. I must see more of this, before I give further way to love.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: One minute he is in the street—the next he is in the kitchen. Now he will lock her out, and then he will wait himself and see what figure she makes when she vouchsafes to venture home.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I long to have it over. Get me but once out of this house!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: [Aside.] Cowardly rascal! would I were in his place.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: If I can but fix him any where, I can let you out myself—you have the ladder ready in case of ne∣cessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Yes! yes! Exit Lucetta.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: [Aside.] The ladder! This must lead to some discovery. I shall watch you my young gentle∣man, I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: This whift is a most enticing devil. I am afraid I am too late for Mr. Strictland's sober hours.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Ha! I hear a noise!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: No! I see a light in Jacintha's widow. You may go home. [Giving the servant money.] I am safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Sure it must be he! Mr. Bellamy.—Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: [Aside.] Does not he call to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: [Aside.] Ha! who's that? I am frighted out of my wits.—A man!—

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Is it you?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Yes! yes! 'tis I! tis I!

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Listen at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I will, 'tis open—there is no noise—all's quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Sure it is my spark—and talking to Jacintha.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: You may come down the ladder—quick.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Catch it then and hold it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I have it. Now I shall see what sort of met∣tle my young spark is made of. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: With a ladder too! I'll assure you. But I must see the end of it. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Hark! did not some body speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No! no! be not fearful—'sdeath! we are discovered. Frankly and Clarinda retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Hist! hist! are you ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Yes, may I venture?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Now is your time. He is in high conference with his privy counsellor Mr. Tester. You may come down the back stairs, and I'll let you out. Exit. Lucet.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I will, I will, and am heartily glad of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: [Advancing.] May be so—but you and I shall have a few words before you get off so cleanly.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: [Advancing.] How lucky it was I came home at this instant. I shall spoil his sport, I believe. Do you know me, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I am amazed! you here! This was unex∣pected indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Why, I believe I do come a little unexpected∣ly; but I shall amaze you more—I know the whole course of your amour; all the process of your mighty passion from its first rise—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: What is all this!—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: To the very conclusion, which you vainly hope to effect this night.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: By heaven, madam, I know not what you mean. I came hither purely to contemplate on your beauties.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Any beauties, sir, I find will serve your turn. Did I not hear you talk to her at the window?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Her!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Blush, blush for shame; but be assured you have seen the last both of Jacintha and me. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Jacintha! hear me, madam—she is gone. This must certainly be Bellamy's mistress, and I have fairly ruin'd all his scheme. This it is to be in luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Ha! a man under the window!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No, here she comes, and I may convey her to him.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Jacintha, and runs to Frankly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I have at last got to you: let's haste away —oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Be not frighten'd, lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Oh! I am abus'd, betray'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Betray'd! Frankly!

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I can scarce believe it, tho' I see it. Draw—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Hear me, Bellamy— lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Stay—do not fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I am innocent; it is all a mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: For my sake be quiet—we shall be discover∣ed. The family is alarmed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: You are obeyed—Mr. Frankly, there is but one way—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I understand you. Any time but now. You will certainly be discovered. To morrow—at your chambers.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: 'Till then, farewell. Exeunt Bella. and Jacin.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Then, when he is cool, I may be heard; and the real, tho' suspicious account of this matter may be believed. Yet amidst all this perplexity, it pleases me to find my fair incognita is jealous of my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [Within.] Where's Lucetta? Search every place.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Hark! the cry is up.—I must be gone.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. Strictland, Tester, and servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: She's gone! she's lost! I am cheated! pursue her! seek her!

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: Sir, all her cloaths are in her chamber.
