SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, Mrs. Clarinda said she was in boy's cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ay, ay! I know it—Bellamy has her— come along—pursue her. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P:
Hark!—was not the noise this way— no—there is no game stirring. This same goddess Diana, shines so bright with her chastity, that egad! I
believe the wenches are asham'd to look her in the face. Now am I in an admirable mood for a frolic! I have wine in my head, and money in my pocket, and am so furnish'd out for the cannonading any countess in Chris∣tendom! ha! what have we here! a ladder! this can∣not be placed here for nothing—and a window open! —Is it love, or mischief now that is going on within? —I care not which—I am in a right cue for either. Up I go—Stay,—do I not run a greater chance of spoiling sport than I do of making any? that I hate as much as I love the other—There can be no harm in seeing how the laud lies—I'll up. [Goes up softly.] —All is hush!— ha! a light! and a woman, by all that's lucky, nei∣ther old, nor crooked—I'll in—ha! she is gone again! I will after her. [Gets in at the window.] And for fear of the squawls of virtue, and the pursuit of the family, I will make sure of the ladder. Now, fortune be my guide. Exit with the ladder.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. Mrs. Strictland's Dressing-Room.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Strictland, follow'd by Lucetta.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Well! I am in great hopes she will escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Never fear, madam. The lovers have the start of him, and I warrant, they keep it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Were Mr. Strictland ever to suspect my being privy to her flight, I know not what might be the consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Then you had better be undressing—He may return immediately—

DIV3.STAGE: As she is sitting down to the toilet, Ranger enters behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Young and beautiful.— Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I have watched him pretty narrowly of late, and never once suspected till this morning—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: And who gave you authority to watch his actions, or pry into his secrets?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I hope madam, you are not angry? I thought it might have been of service to you to know my mas∣ter was jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: And her husband jealous! if she does but send away the maid, I am happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: [Angrily.] Leave me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: This it is to meddle with other peoples affairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: What a lucky dog I am! I never made a gentlemen a cuckold before. Now, Impudence assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: [Rising.] Provoking! I am sure I never have deserved it of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Oh cuckold him by all means, madam, I am your man! [She shieks.] Oh, fy, madam! if you squawl so cursedly, you will be discovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Discovered! What mean you, sir? Do you come to abuse me?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: I'll do my endeavours, madam: you can have no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Whence came you? How got you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Dear madam, so long as I am here, what sig∣nifies how I got here, or whence I came? But that I may satisfy your curiosity. First, as to your whence came you? I answer, out of the street: and to your how got you here? I say, in at the window. It stood so invitingly open, it was irresistible. But, madam,— you was going to undress. I beg I may not incom∣mode you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: This is the most consummate piece of impudence!—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, have one drop of pity for a poor young fellow, who long has lov'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: What would the fellow have?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Your husband's usage will excuse you to the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I cannot bear this insolence, help! help!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Oh! hold that clamorous tongue! madam, speak one word more, and I am gone, positively gone!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Gone! so I would have you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Lord! madam, you are so hasty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict
SP.P: Shall I not speak, when a thief, a robber breaks into my house at midnight? help! help!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ha! no one hears. Now, Cupid, assist me! look ye, madam, I never could make fine speeches, and and cringe, and bow, and fawn, and flatter, and lye, I have said more to you already, than I ever said to a woman in such circumstances in all my life. But since I find you will yield to no persuasion to your good— I will gently force you to be grateful. [throws down his hat, and seizes her.] Come, come! unbend that brow, and look more kindly on me!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: For shame, sir—thus on my knees, let me beg for mercy. Kneeling.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: And thus, on mine, let me beg the same.

DIV3.STAGE: He kneels, catches and kisses her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [within.] Take away her sword! she'll hurt herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Oh! heavens! that is my husband's voice!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: [Rising.] The devil it is!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [within.] Take away her sword, I say, and then I can close with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: He is upon the stairs, now coming up. I am undone, if he sees you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Pox on him! I must decamp then. Which way?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Thro' this passage into the next cham∣ber.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: And so into the street. With all my heart. You may be perfectly easy, madam. Mum's the word. I never blab— [Aside.] I shall never leave off so, but wait till the last moment. Exit Ranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: So, he is gone! What could I have said, if he had been discovered!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. Strictland, driving in Jacintha, Lucetta following.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Once more, my pretty masculine madam, you are welcome home. And I hope to keep you some∣what closer than I have done: for to-morow morning, eight o'clock, is the latest hour you shall stay in this lewd town.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P:
Oh, sir! when once a girl is equipped with a hearty resolution, it is not your worship's sagacity, nor
the great chain at your gate can hinder her from doing what she has a mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Oh, lord! lord! how this love improves a young lady's modesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Am I to blame to seek for happiness any where, when you are resolved to make me miserable here!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I have this night prevented your making yourself so; and will endeavour to do it for the future. I have you safe now, and the devil shall not get you out of my clutches again. I have lock'd the doors and barr'd them, I warrant you. So, here— [giving her a candle.] Troop to your chamber, and to bed, whilst you are well, go— [He treads on Ranger's hat.] What's here? a hat! a man's hat in my wife's dressing-room!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: [Aside.] What shall I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [Taking up the hat, and looking at Mrs. Strictland.] Ha! by hell! I see 'tis true.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: My fears confound me. I dare not tell the truth, and know not how to frame a lye!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Mrs. Strictland! Mrs. Strictland! how came this hat into your chamber!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: [Aside.] Are you that way dispos'd, my fine lady, and will not trust me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Speak, wretch, speak.—

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I could not have suspected this. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Why dost thou not speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Guilt—'tis guilt that ties your tongue!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I must bring her off, however—no chamber-maid can help it.— Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: My fears are just, and I am miserable— thou worst of women!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I know my innocence, and can bear this no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I know you are false,—and 'tis I who will bear my injuries no longer.

DIV3.STAGE: Both walk about in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: [To Jacintha aside.] Is not the hat yours? own it, madam.

DIV3.STAGE: Takes away Jacintha's hat, and Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P:
What ground? what cause have you
for jealousy, when you yourself can witness, your leav∣ing me was accidental; your return uncertain; and ex∣pected even sooner than it happen'd? the abuse is gross and palpable.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Why, this is true!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Indeed, Jacintha, I am innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: And yet this hat must belong to some∣body.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Dear, Mrs. Strictland, be not concern'd when he has diverted himself a little longer with it—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I suppose he will give me my hat again?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Your hat?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Yes, my hat. You brush'd it from my side yourself, and then trod upon it; whether on purpose to abuse this lady or no, you best know yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: It cannot be.—It's all a lye.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Believe so still—with all my heart—but the hat is mine. Snatches it and puts it on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Why did she look so?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Your violence of temper is too much for her. You use her ill, and then suspect her for that confusion which you yourself occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Why did not you set me right at first?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Your hard usage of me, sir, is a sufficient rea∣son why I should not be much concern'd to undeceive you at all. 'Tis for your lady's sake, I do it now; who deserves much better of you than to be thus expos'd for every slight suspicion. See where she sits—go to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: [Rising.] Indeed, Mr. Strictland, I have a soul as much above—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Whew! now you have both found your tongues, and I must bear their eternal rattle!

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: For shame! sir, go to her, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Well! well! what shall I say? I forgive —all is over. I, I, I forgive!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Forgive! what do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Forgive her? is that all? consider, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P:
Hold —hold your confounded tongues, and I'll do any thing. I'll ask pardon—or forgive—or any thing. Good now, be quiet—I ask your pardon—
there— [Kisses her.] For you, madam—I am infinitely obligd to you, and I could find in my heart to make you a return in kind, by marrying you to a beggar,— but I have more conscience. Come, come; to your chamber.—Here take this candle—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Sir, if you please, I will light my young lady to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: No! no! no such thing, good madam. She shall have nothing but her pillow to consult this night, I assure you—so in, in. [The ladies take leave.] [Exit Jacintha.] Good night, kind madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Pox of the jealous fool! we might both have escaped out of the window purely. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Go, get you down and do you hear; or∣der the coach to be ready in the morning at eight exact∣ly. [Exit Lucetta.] [Locks the door after her.] So she is safe till to-morrow, and then for the country; and when she is there, I can manage as I think fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Dear Mr. Strictland—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I am not in a humour, Mrs. Strictland, fit to talk with you.—Go to bed, I will endeavour to get the better of my temper, if I can—I'll follow you! [Exit Mrs. Strictland.] How despicable have I made myself! Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. Another CHAMBER.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: All seems hush'd again, and I may venture out. I may as well sneak off whilst I am in a whole skin. And shall so much love and claret as I am in possession of, only lull me to sleep, when it might so much better keep me waking? forbid it, Fortune; and forbid it, Love. This is a chamber, perhaps of some bewitching female, and I may yet be happy. Ha! a light! the door opens. A boy! pox on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I have been listening at the door; and from their silence, I conclude they are peaceably gone to bed together.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: [Aside.] A pretty boy, faith! he seems un∣easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: [Sitting down.] What an unlucky night has this proved to me! every circumstance has fallen out unhappily.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: He talks aloud. I'll listen. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: But what most amazes me is, that Clarinda should betray me!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Clarinda? She must be a woman! well! what of her? Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: My guardian else would never have suspected my disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: [Aside.] Disguise! ha! it must be so. What eyes she has? What a dull rogue was I not to suspect this sooner?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Ha! I had forgot the ladder is at the win∣dow still, and I will boldly venture by myself. [Rising briskly, sees Ranger.] Ha! a man! and well drest! ha! Mrs. Strictland, are you then at last dishonest?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: [Aside.] By all my wishes she is a charming woman! lucky rascal!

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: But I will if possible, conceal her shame, and stand the brunt of his impertinence.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: What shall I say to her? no matter; any thing soft will do the business.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: A man, young gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: And what would you have?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: A woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: You are very free, sir. Here are none for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ay, but there is one, and a fair one too; the most charming creature Nature ever set her hand to; and you are the dear little pilot, that must direct me to her heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: What mean you, sir? It is an office I am not accustom'd to.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P:
You won't have far to go, however. I never
make my errands tedious! it is to your own heart. Dear madam, I would have you whisper in my behalf. Nay, never start. Think you such beauty could ever be conceal'd from eyes so well acquainted with its charms?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: What will become of me! if I cry out Mrs. Strictland is undone, that is my last resort.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Pardon, dear lady, the boldness of this visit, which your guardian's care has forced me to— but I long have lov'd you, long doated on that beauteous face, and follow'd you from place to place, tho' perhaps, un∣known and unregarded.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Here's a special fellow! Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Turn then an eye of pity on my sufferings; and by heaven—one tender look from those piercing eyes— one touch of this soft hand—

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Hold, sir—no nearer.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Would more than repay whole years of pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Hear me. But keep your distance, or I raise the family.—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Blessings on her tongue, only for prattling to me. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Oh! for a moment's courage, and I shall shame him from his purpose. [Aside.] If I were cer∣tain so much gallantry had been shown on my account only.—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: You wrong your beauty to think that any other could have power to draw me hither. By all the little loves that play about your lips I swear—

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: You came to me, and me alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: By all the thousand graces that inhabit there, you, and only you have drawn me hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Well said.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: By heaven she comes! ah! honest Ranger, I never knew thee fail!— Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Pray, sir, where did you leave this hat?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: That hat!—that hat—It's my hat. — I dropt it in the next chamber as I was looking for yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: How mean and despicable do you look now?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: So! so! I am in a pretty pickle! Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: You know by this, that I am acquainted with every thing that has passed within: and how ill it agrees with what you have profesed to me—let me advise you, sir, to be gone immediately. Thro' that window you may easily get into the street—one scream of mine; the least noise at that door will wake the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Say you so? Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Believe me, sir, an injud husband is not so easily appeas'd, and a suspected wife that is jealous of her honor—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Is the devil, and so let us hear no more of her. Look ye, madam, [Going between the door and her.] I have but one argument left, and that is a strong one. Look on me well, I am as handsome a strong well-made fellow as any about town, and since we are alone, as I take it, we can have no occasion to be more private.

DIV3.STAGE: Going to lay hold of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I have a reputation, sir, and will maintain it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: You have a bewitching pair of eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Consider my virtue. Struggling.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Consider your beauty and my desires.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: If I were a man, you dar'd not use me thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: I should not have had the same temptation.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Hear me, sir, I will be heard. [Breaks from him.] There is a man who will make you repent this usage of me.—Oh! Bellamy, where art thou now?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Were he here you durst not thus affront me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: His mistress on my soul! [Aside.] You can love madam; you can love, I find. Her tears affect me strangely. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I am not ashamed to own my passion for a man of virtue and honor.—I love and glory in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: O! brave! and you can write letters, you can. I will not trust myself home with you this evening, because I know it is inconvenient.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P:
Therefore I beg you would procure me a lodging;
it's no matter how far off my guardian's. Yours, Jacintha.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: The very words of my letter! I am amazed. Do you know Mr. Bellamy?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: There is not a man on earth I have so great a value for: and he must have some value for me too, or he would never have shown me your pretty epistle. Think of that, fair lady. The ladder is at the win∣dow. And so madam, I hope delivering you safe into his arms will, in some measure, expiate the crime I have been guilty of to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Good heaven, how fortunate is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: I believe I make myself appear more wicked than I really am. For, damn me, if I do not feel more satisfaction in the thoughts of restoring you to my friend, than I could have pleasure in any favour your bounty could have bestowed.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Your generosity transports me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Let us lose no time then, the ladder is ready. —Where was you to lodge?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: At Mr. Meggot's.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: At my friend Jacky's? better and better still.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Are you acquainted with him too?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ay, ay! why did I not tell you at first that I was one of your old acquaintance? I know all about you, you see; tho' the devil fetch me if ever I saw you before. Now Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: And now, sir,— have with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Then thou art a girl of spirit. And tho' I long to hug you for trusting yourself with me, I will not beg a single kiss, till Bellamy himself shall give me leave. He must fight well that takes you from me. Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: PSHA! what impertinent devil put it into your head to meddle with my affairs?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: You know I went thither in pursuit of ano∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I know nothing you had to do there at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I thought Mr. Bellamy you were a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella
SP.P: I am so; and therefore should be forgiven this sudden warmth.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And therefore should forgive the fond im∣pertinence of a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Jealousy, you know, is as natural an incident to love—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: As curiosity. By one piece of silly curiosity I have gone nigh to ruin both myself and you. Let not then your jealousy complete our misfortunes! I fear I have lost a mistress as well as you. Then let us not quarrel. All may come right again.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: It is impossible. She is gone, remov'd for ever from my sight. She is in the country by this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: How did you lose her after we parted?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: By too great confidence. When I got her to my chair, the chairmen were not to be found.—And safe, as I thought in our disguise, I actually put her into the chair, when Mr. Strictland and his servants were in sight; which I had no sooner done, than they sur∣rounded us, overpowered me, and carried her away.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Unfortunate indeed! could you not make a second attempt?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I had designed it. But when I came to the door, I found the ladder removed; and hearing no noise, seeing no lights, nor being able to make any body answer, I concluded all attempts as impractica∣ble as now I find them. Ha! I see Lucetta coming. Then they may be still in town. Enter Lucetta. Lucetta welcome! what news of Jacintha?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: News, sir! you fright me out of my senses! why is she not with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: What do you mean? With me! I have not seen her since I lost her last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Good heaven! then she is undone for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Speak out—I'm all amazement.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P:
She is escaped without any of us knowing how. Nobody miss'd her 'till morning. We all thought
she went away with you. But heaven knows now what may have happen'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Somebody must have accompanied her in her flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: We know of nobody. We are all in confu∣sion at home. My master swears revenge on you. My mistress says a stranger has her.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: A stranger!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: But Mrs. Clarinda—

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Clarinda! who is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: [To Frankly.] The lady, sir, you saw at our house last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ha! what of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: She says she is sure one Frankly, is the man. She saw them together, and knows it to be true.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Damn'd fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Sure this is not Mr. Frankly?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Nothing will convince him now. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: [looking at Frankly.] Ha! 'tis truth—I see it is true. [Aside.] Lucetta run up to Buckle, and take him with you to search wherever you can. [Puts her out.] Now, Mr. Frankly, I have found you.—You have used me so ill, that you force me to forget you are my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Draw.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Are you mad? By heavens! I am innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: I have heard you, and will no longer be im∣pos'd on.—Defend yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Nay, if you are so hot, I draw to defend my∣self, as I would against a madman.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: What the devil, swords at noonday! Have among you, faith! [parts them.] What's here, Bella∣my?—Yes, gad, you are Bellamy, and you are Frank∣ly. Put up, put up both of you—or else—I am a de∣vilish fellow when once my sword is out.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: We shall have a time—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: [Pushing Bellamy one way.] a time for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I shall be always as ready to defend my inno∣cence as now.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P:
[Pushing Frankly t'other way.] Innocence!
ay, to be sure!—at your age!—a mighty innocent fellow, no doubt. But what in the name of common sense is it that ails you both? Are you mad? The last time I saw you, you were hugging and kissing; and now you are cutting one another's throats—I never knew any good come of one fellow's be slavering another— But I shall put you into better humour, I warrant you. Bellamy, Frankly, listen both of you—such fortune— such a scheme—

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Pr'ythee, leave fooling! what, art drunk?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: He is always so, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: And who gave you the privilege of thinking? Drunk! no! I am not drunk—tipsy perhaps, with my good fortune—merry and in spirits—tho' I have not fire enough to run my friend thro' the body. Not drunk, tho' Jack Meggot and I have box'd it about —Champaign was the word for two whole hours, by Shrewsbury clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Jack Meggot! Why I left him at one going to bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: That may be, but I made a shift to rouse him and his family, by four this morning. Ounds! I pick'd up a wench and carried her to his house.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Such a variety of adventures—nay, you shall hear. But before I begin Bellamy, you shall promise me half a dozen kisses before hand, for the devil fetch me, if that little jade, Jacintha, would give me one, tho' I pressed hard.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Who, Jacintha? Press to kiss Jacintha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Kiss her! ay, why not? Is she not a woman, and made to be kissed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Kiss her!—I shall run distracted.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: How could I help it, when I had her alone, you rogue, in her bed-chamber at midnight? If I had been to be sacrificed, I should have done it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Bed-chamber at midnight? I can hold no longer.—Draw.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Be easy, Bellamy. Interposing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: He has been at some of his damn'd tricks with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Hear him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: 'Sdeath! how could I know she was his mis∣tress? But I tell this story most miserably. I should have told you first, I was in another lady's chamber. By the lord, I got in at the window by a ladder of ropes.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ha! another lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Another. And stole in upon her, whilst she was undressing; beautiful as an angel, blooming and young—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: What, in the same house?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: What is this to Jacintha? Ease me of my pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ay, ay, in the same house, on the same floor. The sweetest, little angel—but I design to have ano∣ther touch with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: 'Sdeath! but you shall have a touch with me first.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Stay, Frankly. Interposing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why, what strange madness has possess'd you both, that no-body must kiss a pretty wench but your∣selves.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: But what became of Jacintha?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ounds! what have you done that you must monopolize kissing?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Pr'ythee, honest Ranger, ease me of the pain I am in. Was her name Clarinda?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Speak, in plain words, where Jacintha is, where to be found—dear boy, tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ay, now it is, honest Ranger; and dear boy, tell me—and a minute ago, my throat was to be cut. —I could find in my heart not to open my lips. But here comes Jack Meggot, who will let you into all the secret, tho' he design'd to keep it from you, in half the time that I can, tho' I had ever so great a mind to tell it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: So, save ye! save ye, lads! we have been frighten'd out of our wits for you. Not hearing of Mr. Bellamy, poor Jacintha is ready to sink for fear of any accident.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Is she at your house?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Why, did you not know that? We dispatch'd master Ranger to you three hours ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ay, plague! but I had business of my own, and so I could not come. Hark ye, Frankly, is your girl maid, wife, or widow?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: A maid, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: The odds are against you, Charles.—But mine is married, you rogue, and her husband jealous. —The devil is in it, if I do not yet reap some reward for my last night's service.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: He has certainly been at Mrs. Strictland her∣self. But Frankly, I dare not look on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: This one embrace cancels all thoughts of en∣mity.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Thou generous man:—but I must haste to ease Jacintha of her fears. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And I to make up matters with Clarinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: And I to some kind wench or other, Jack. But where I shall find her, heaven knows. And so, my service to your monkey.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Adieu, rattle pate. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. The Hall of Mr. Strictland's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: But, why in such a hurry, my dear? stay till your servants can go along with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: O, no matter! they'll follow with my things. It is but a little way off, and my chair will guard me. After my staying out so late last night, I am sure Mr. Strictland will think every minute an age whilst I am in his house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I am as much amaz'd at his suspecting your innocence as my own: and every time I think of it, I blush at my present behaviour to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: No ceremony, dear child.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: No Clarinda, I am too well acquainted with your good humour. But I fear in the eye of a malicious world, it may look like a confirmation of his suspicion.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: My dear, if the world will speak ill of me, for the little innocent gaiety, which I think the peculiar happiness of my temper, I know no way to prevent it; and am only sorry the world is so ill-natur'd: but I shall not part with my mirth, I assure them, so long as I know it innocent. I wish, my dear, this may be the greatest uneasiness your husband's jealousy ever gives you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I hope he never again may have such occasion, as he had last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: You are so unfashionable a wife!—why, last night's accident would have made half the wives in London easy for life. Has not his jealousy discover'd itself openly? and are not you innocent? there is no∣thing but your foolish temper that prevents his being absolutely in your power.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Clarinda, this is too serious an affair to laugh at. Let me advise you, take care of Mr. Frankly, observe his temper well; and if he has the least taint of jealousy, cast him off, and never trust to keeping him in your power.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: You will hear little more of Frankly, I believe. Here is Mr. Strictland.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Lucetta says you want me, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I troubled you, sir, only that I might return you thanks for the civilities I have received in your fa∣mily, before I took my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Keep them to yourself, dear madam. As it is at my request that you leave my house, your thanks upon that occasion are not very desirable.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Oh, sir, you need not fear, my thanks were only for your civilities. They will not overburden you. But I'll conform to your humour, sir, and part with as little ceremony.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: As we met.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: The brute! [Aside.] My dear, good-b'ye, we may meet again. To Mrs. Strictland.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: If you dare trust me with your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Lucetta, remember my instructions. Now, sir, have with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Are her instructions cruel or kind, Lu∣cetta? for I suppose they relate to Mr. Frankly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: You have a mind to try, if I can keep a secret, as well as yourself, madam. But I will show you I am fit to be trusted by keeping this, tho' it signifies nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: This answer is not so civil, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I beg pardon, madam. I meant it not to offend.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Pray let us have no more such. I nei∣ther desire, nor want you assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: She is gone. I feel myself somewhat easier already. Since I have begun the day with gal∣lantry, madam, shall I conduct you up?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: There is something, sir, which gives you secret uneasiness. I wish—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Perhaps so, madam, and perhaps it may soon be no secret at all. Leads her out.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Would I were once well settled with my young lady; for at present, this is but an odd sort of a queer family. Last night's affair puzzles me. A hat there was that belong'd to none of us, that's certain. Madam was in a fright, that is as certain; and I brought all off. Jacintha escap'd, no one of us knows how. The good man's jealousy was yesterday groundless; yet to∣day, in my mind, he is very much in the right. Mighty odd, all this! Somebody knocks! If this should be Clarinda's spark, I have an odd message for him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: So, my pretty handmaid. Meeting with you gives me some hopes. May I speak with Clarinda?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Whom do you want, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Clarinda, child. The young lady I was ad∣mitted to yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Clarinda?—No such person lives here, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Where then?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I don't know, indeed, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Will you enquire within?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Nobody knows in this house, sir, you'll find.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P:
What do you mean? She is a friend of Ja∣cintha's
your lady. I will take my oath she was here last night; and you yourself spoke of her being here this morning—not know!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: No. None of us know. She went away of a sudden. No one of us can imagine whither.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why, faith, child, thou hast a tolerable face, and hast delivered this denial very handsomely. But let me tell you, your damned impertinence this morn∣ing had like to have cost me my life. Now, therefore, make me amends. I come from your young mistress, I come from Mr. Bellamy. I come with my purse full of gold (that persuasive rhetoric) to win you to let me see, and speak to this Clarinda once again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: She is not here, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Direct me to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: No! I can't do that neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I heard a knocking at the door, and a man's voice—ha! Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Deliver this letter to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: By all my fears; a letter! Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I don't know but I may be tempted to do that.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Take it then—and with it this.

DIV3.STAGE: Kisses her, and gives her money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Um! there are two bribes in a breath! What a jade she is?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Ay! this gentleman understands reason!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And be assured you oblige your mistress, while you are serving me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Her mistress?—Damn'd sex! and damn∣ed wife, thou art an epitome of that sex!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And if you can procure me an answer, your see shall be enlarged. Exit Frankly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: The next step is to get her to read this letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [Snatches the letter.] No noise—but stand silent there, whilst I read this.
SP.STAGE: Breaks it open, and drops the case.
SP.P:
Madam, the gaiety of a heart happy as mine was yes∣terday, may, I hope, easily excuse the unseasonable visit I made your house last night. — Death and the devil! con∣fusion, I shall run distracted. It is too much! there
was a man then to whom the hat belong'd; and I was gull'd, abus'd, cheated, impos'd on by a chit, a girl— oh woman! woman!—But I will be calm, search it cooly to the bottom, and have a full revenge.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: [Aside.] So here's a fine work! he'll make himself very ridiculous tho'!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [Reads on.] I know my innocence will appear so manifestly, that I need only appeal to the lady who accompanied you at Bath. Your very humble servant, good, innocent, fine madam Clarinda — And I do not doubt but her good-nature, [Bawd! bawd!] will not let you persist injuring your obedient humble servant, Charles Frankly.

Now, who can say my jealousy lack'd foundation, or my suspicion of sine madam's innocent gaiety was unjust—gaiety? why, ay! 'twas gaiety brought him hither. Gaiety makes her a bawd—my wife may be a whore in gaiety. What a number of sins become fashionable under the notion of gaiety — What! You received this epistle in gaiety too; and were to deliver it to my wife I suppose, when the gay fit came next upon her? Why▪ you impudent young strumpet, do you laugh at me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I would, if I dared, and heartily—be pleas'd, sir, only to look at that piece of paper that lies there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I have not touched it, sir. It is the case that letter came in, and the direction will inform you whom I was to deliver it to.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: This is directed to Clarinda?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Oh! is it so? Now read it over again, and all your foolish doubts will vanish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I have no doubts at all. I am satisfied that you, Jacintha, Clarinda, my wife, all are—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Lud! lud! you would make a body mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Hold your impertinent tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: You'll find the thing to be just as I say, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P:
egone. [Exit Lucetta.] They must be poor at the work, indeed, if they did not lend one another their names. 'Tis plain, 'tis evident: and I am miserable. But for my wife, she shall not stay one
night longer in my house. Separation, shame, con∣tempt shall be her portion. I am determined in the thing; and when once it is over, I may perhaps be easy. Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III. The STREET.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Clarinda, in a chair, Ranger following.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Hark ye, chairmen! Damn your confounded trot. Go slower.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Here, stop.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: By heavens the monsters hear reason, and obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: [Letting down the window.] What trouble∣some fellow was that?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Chairm.
SP.P: Some rake, I warrant, that cannot carry himself home, and wants us to do it for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: There— and pray do you take care I be not troubled with him. Goes in.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: That's as much as to say now, pray follow me. Madam, you are a charming woman, and I will do it—

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Chairm.
SP.P: Stand off, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Pr'ythee, honest fellow—what—what wri∣ting is that? Endeavouring to get in

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Chairm.
SP.P: You come not in here!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Lodgings to be let! a pretty convenient in∣scription, and the sign of a good modest family! There may be lodgings for gentlemen as well as ladies. Hark ye, rogues! I'll lay you all the silver I have in my pocket, there it is, I get in there in spight of your teeth, ye pimps? Throws down money and goes in.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Chairm.
SP.P: What, have you let the gentleman in?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Chairm.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, partner, he certainly slipt by whilst we were picking up the money. Come take up.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV. CLARINDA'S LODGINGS.
DIV3.STAGE: A noise without between Ranger and Landlady.
Clarinda enters laughing, a Maid following.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P:
My madcap cousin Ranger, as I live. I am
sure he does not know me.—If I could but hide my face now, what sport I should have! a mask, a mask! run and see if you can find a mask.

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: I believe there is one above.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.L: Run, run, and fetch it. Exit Maid.
Here he comes! Enter Ranger and Landlady.
How unlucky this is! Turning from 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Landl.
SP.P: What's your business here, unmannerly sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Well, let's see these lodgings that are to be let. —Gad, a very pretty neat tenement!—but hark ye, is it real and natural, all that, or only patch'd up and new-painted this summer-season against the town fills?

SP.SPEAKER: Landl.
SP.P: What does the saucy fellow mean with his double tenders here? get you down—

SP.SPEAKER: Maid.
SP.P: Here is a very dirty one. Aside to Clarinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: No matter—now we shall see a little what he would be at. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Landl.
SP.P: This is an honest house—for all your lac'd waistcoat, I'll have you thrown down neck and heels.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Phoh! not in such a hurry good old lady— a mask! — nay, with all my heart. It saves a world of blushing—have you ne'er a one for me?—I am apt to be asham'd myself, on these occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Landl.
SP.P: Get you down, I say—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P:
Not if I guess right, old lady. Madam, [To Clarinda, who makes signs to the Landlady.] Look ye there now! that a woman should live to your age, and know so little of the matter. Be gone. [Exit Landlady.] By her forwardness, this should be a whore of quality. My boy Ranger, thou art in luck to-day.—She won't speak, I find—then I will. [Aside.] Delicate lodgings truly, madam; and very neatly furnish'd.—A very convenient room this, I must needs own, to entertain a mix'd company— but my dear charming creature, does not that door open to a more commodious apartment for the happiness of a private friend, or so? the pret∣tiest brass lock.— Fast, um! that won't do. 'Sdeath, you are a beautiful woman! I am sure you are. Pr'y-thee let me see your face. It is your interest child.— The longer you delay, the more I shall expect. There∣fore, [taking her hand.] my dear, soft, kind, new ac∣quaintance,
thus let me take your hand, and whilst you gently with the other, let day-light in upon me: let me softly hold you to me, that with my longing lips I may receive the warmest, bes impression. [She unmasks.] Clarinda!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Ha! ha! your servant, cousin Ranger: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Oh! your humble servant, madam! you had liked to have been beholden to your mask, cousin! I must brazen it out. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! you were not so happy in your disguise, sir. The pretty stagger in your gate, that happy disposition of your hair, the genteel negligence of your whole person, and those pretty flowers of mo∣dish gallantry made it impossible to mistake you, my sweet cuz. Ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Oh! I knew you too, but I fancied you had taken a particular liking to my person, and had a mind to sink the relation under that little piece of black velvet! and, egad, you never find me behind hand in a frolic. But since it is otherwise, my merry-good-humoured cousin, I am as heartily glad to see you in town, as I should be to meet any of my old ttle acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: And on my side, I am as happy in meeting your worship, as I should be in a rencounter with e'er a pet∣ticoat in Christendom.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: And if you have any occasion for a dangling gallant to Vauxhall, Ranelagh, or even the poor ne∣glected Park, you are so unlike the rest of your virtuous sisters of the petticoat, that I will venture myself with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Take care what you promise; for who knows but this face you were pleas'd to say so many pretty things of, before you saw it, may raise so many rivals among your kept mistresses, and reps of quality.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Hold! hold! a truce with your satire, sweet cuz; or if scandal must be the topic of every virtuous woman's conversation— call for your tea-water—and let it be in its proper element. Come, your tea; your tea.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: With all my heart—who's there? Get tea upon condition that you stay till it comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: That is according as you behave, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Oh! sir, I am very sensible of the favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Nay! you may, I assure you; for there is but one woman of virtue besides yourself, I would stay with ten minutes, (and I have not known her above these twelves hours.) The insipidity, or the racour of their discourse, is insufferable. 'Sdeath! I had rather take the air with my grandmother!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! the ladies are highly obliged to you, I vow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: I tell you what. The lady I speak of was oblig'd to me, and the generous girl is ready to own it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: And pray when was it you did Virtue this con∣siderable service?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: But this last night, the devil fetch me! a romantic whim of mine conveyed me into her chamber, where I found her young and beautiful, alone at mid∣night, dress'd like a soft Adonis, her lovely hair all loose about her shoulders —

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: In boys' cloaths! (this is worth attending to.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Gad! I no more suspected her being a wo∣man, than I did your being my cater-cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: How did you discover it at last?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why, faith, she very modestly dropt me a hint of it herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Herself! (if this should be Jacintha.) Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ay, 'foregad, did she! which I imagined a good sign at midnight. Ha, cousin? so I e'en invented a long story of a passion I had for her, (tho' I had ne∣ver seen her before) you know my old way; and said so many such tender things—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: As you said to me just now?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Pshh! quite in an another style, I assure you. It was midnight, and then I was in a right cue.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Well! and what did she answer to all these protestaios?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why, instead of running into my arms at once, as I expected —.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: To be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: 'Gad! like a freehearted honest girl, she frankly told me, she lik'd another better than she lik'd me; that I had something in my face that show'd I was a gentleman: and she would e'en trust herself with me, if I would give her my word, I would convey her to her spark.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Oh, brave! and how did you bear this?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why, curse me, if I am ever angry with a woman for not having a passion for me; I only hate your sex's vain pretence of having no passion at all. 'Gad! I loved the good-natur'd girl for it; took her at her word; stole her out of the window: and this morning made a very honest fellow happy in the pos∣session of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: And her name is Jacintha.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Your amours are no secrets, sir. You see you might as well have told me all, the whole of last night's adventure; for you find, I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: All! why, what do you know?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Nay, nothing. I only know, that a gentleman's hat cannot be dropt in a lady's chamber.—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: The devil!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: But a husband is such an odd, impertinent, auk∣ward creature, that he will be stumbling over it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Here has been fine work. [Aside] But how, in the name of wonder should you know all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: By being in the same house.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: In the same house?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Ay, in the same house. A witness of the confusion you have made.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Frankly's Clarinda, by all that's fortunate. It must be so. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: And let me tell you, sir, that even the dull, low-spirited diversions you ridicule in us tame creatures, are preferable to the romantic exploits that only wine can raise you to.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Yes, cousin! but I'll be even with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P:
If you reflect, cousin, you will find a gre , in ockig a ly's mdey,
her quiet, tainting her reputation, and ruining the peace of a whole family.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: To be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: These your high-mettled pleasures of you men of spirit, that the insipidity of the virtuous can never arrive at. And can you in reality think your Burgundy, and your Bacchu, your Venus, and your Loves an excuse for all this? Fy, cousin, sy.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: No, cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: What, dumb? I am glad you have modesty enough left not to go about to excuse yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: It is as you say. When we are sober, and re∣flect but ever so little on the follies we commit, we are asham'd and sorry; and yet the very next minute, we run again into the ve sa dities.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: What! moraing, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: What you know is t half, nt a hundredth part of the mischief of my last night's folle. And yet, the very next petticoat I saw this morning, I must follow it, and be damn'd to me. Th for ought I know, poor Frankly's may dpend upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Whos ise, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: And here do I stand prating to you now.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Pray, good cousin, explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Good cousin! She has it. [Aside.] Why, whilst I was making off with the wench, Bellamy and he were quarreling about her: and tho' Jacintha and I made all the haste we could, we did not get to them before —

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Before what? (I'm frighten'd out of my wits.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Not that Frankly car'd three half-pence for the girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: But there was no mischief done, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Pho! a slight scratch. Nothing at all, as the surgeon said: tho' he was but a queer looking son of a bitch of a surgeon neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Good God! why, he should have the bt that can be found in London.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ay, indeed, so he should. That was what I was going for, when I saw you. [Sits down.] They are all at Jack Meggol's hard by, and you will keep me here.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I keep you here! for heaven's sake begone.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Your is a damn'd while a coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: You shall have no tea now, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Nay! one dish.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: No, positively, you shall not stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Your commands are absolute, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Then Frankly is true, and I am only to blame.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: [Returns.] But I beg ten thousand pardons, cousin, that I should forget to salute you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Pshah! how can you trifle at such a time as this?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: A trifle! wrong not your beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Lord! how teizing you are? There.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: [Kisses her.] Poor thing! how uneasy she is! nay, no ceremony. You shall not stir a step with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I do not intend it. This is downright provoking. Who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: Landla.
SP.P: Madam, did your ladyship call?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Does one Mr. Meggot live in this neighbour∣hood?

SP.SPEAKER: Landla.
SP.P: Yes, madam, a fine gentleman, and keeps a noble house, and a world of company.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Very well. I don't want his history. I won∣der my servants are not come yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Landla.
SP.P: Lack-a-day, madam, they are all below.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Send up one then with a card to me. I must know the truth of this affair immediately.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. A room in Mr. Strictland's house. Mr. and Mrs. Strictland discover'd; she weeping and he writing at a table.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. STRICTLAND.
SP.P: HEIGH! ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: What can possibly be the occasion of that sigh, madam? You have yourself agreed to a maintenance, and a maintenance no dutchess need be asham'd of.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: But the extremities of provocation that drove me to that agreement—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Were the effect of your own follies. Why do you disturb me? Writes on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I would not willingly give you a mo∣ment's uneasiness. I but desire a fair and equal hear∣ing: and if I satisfy you not in every point, then a∣bandon me, discard me to the world, and its malicious tongues.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: What was it you said? — Damn this pen.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I say Mr. Strictland, I would only—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: You would only!—you would only re∣peat what you have been saying this hour, I am inno∣cent; and when I showed you the letter I had taken from your maid, what was then your poor evasion? but that it was to Clarinda, and you were innocent!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Heaven knows I am innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: But I know your Clarinda, your woman of honor is your blind, your cover, your—but why do I distract myself about a woman I have no longer any concerns with? Here, madam, is your fate. A letter to your brother in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Sir—.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I have told him what a sister he is to re∣ceive, and how bid her welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Then my ruin is complete. My Bro∣ther!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I must vindicate my own honor; else what will the world say?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: That brother was my only hope, my only ground of patience. In his retirement I hoped my name might have been safe, and slept, till by some happy means you might at length have known me inno∣cent, and pitied me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Retirement! pretty soul! no, no! that face was never made for retirement. It is another sort of retiring you are fittest for.—Ha! hark! what's that. [A knocking at the door.] Two gentle taps—and why but two? Was that the signal, madam? Stir not on your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Give me resolution, heaven, to bear this usage, and keep it secret from the world. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I will have no signs, no items. No hem, to tell him I am here! Ha! another tap. The gen∣tleman is in haste I find. [Opens the door, and enters Tester.] Tester! why did not you come in, rascal! [Beats him] all vexations meet to cross me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: Lard, sir! what do you strike me for? My mistress ordered me never to come in where she was, without first knocking at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Oh! cunning devil! Tester is too honest to be trusted!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Unhappy man! will nothing undeceive him? Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: Sir, here is a letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: To my wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: No sir, to you. The servant waits below.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Art sure it is a servant?

SP.SPEAKER: Tester.
SP.P: Sir! [staring.] It is Mr. Buckle, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P:
I am mad. I know not what I say or do, or think. But let's read. Reads to himself.
Sir, we cannot bear to reflect that Mrs. Strictland may possibly be ruin'd in your esteem, and in the voice of the world, only by the confusion which our af∣fair has made in your family, without offering all within our power to clear the misunderstanding be∣tween you. If you will give yourself the trouble but to step to Mr. Meggot's, where all the parties will be; we doubt not but we can entirely satisfy your most flagrant suspicions, to the honor of Mrs. Strictland, and the quiet of your lives. Jacintha, John Bellamy.
Hey! here's the whole gang witnessing for one ano∣ther. They think I am an ass, and will be led by the nose, to believe every thing. Call me a chair. [Exit Tester.] Yes I will go to this rendezvous of enemies —I will—and find out all her plots, her artifices, and contrivances. It will clear my conduct to her bro∣ther and all her friends. Exit. Mr. Strictland.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Gone, so abruptly! what can that let∣ter be about! no matter. There is no way left to make us easy but by my disgrace, and I must learn to suffer. Time and innocence will teach me to bear it patiently.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P:
Mrs. Bellamy, madam (for my young lady is
married,) begs you will follow Mr. Strictland to Mr. Meggot's. She makes no doubt, but she shall be able to make you and my master easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: But how came she to know any thing of the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: I have been with them, madam. I could not bear to see so good a lady so ill-treated.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I am indeed Lucetta, ill-treated. But I hope this day will be the last of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Madam Clarinda, and Mr. Frankly will be there: and the young gentleman, madam, who was with you in this room last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Ha! if he is there there may be hopes; and it is worth the trying.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucet.
SP.P: Dear lady—let me call a chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I go with you. I cannot be more wretch∣ed than I am. Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. A room in Meggot's house.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Frankly, Ranger, Bellamy, Jacintha, and Meggot.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Oh, Ranger! this is news indeed. Your cousin, and a lady of such fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: I have done the business for you. I tell you; she's your own: she loves you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Words are too faint to tell the joy I feel.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: I have put that heart of hers into such a flut∣ter, that I'll lay a hundred guineas, with the assistance which this lady has promised me, I fix her yours di∣rectly.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Ay, ay, Mr. Frankly, we have a design upon her which cannot fail. But you must obey orders.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Most willingly. But remember, dear lady I have more than life at stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Away then into the next room; for she is this instant coming hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Hither? you surprize me more and more.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Here is a message from her, by which she de∣sires leave to wait on me this afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Only for the chance of seeing you here, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: L thee, tho' I know not how to believe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: P pr'ythee, do not stifle me! it is a busy day, a very busy day.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Thou art the most unaccountable creature in life.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: But the most lucky one, Jack, if I succeed for Frankly, as I have for Bllamy; and my heart whispers me I shall. Come in, most noble Mr. Buckle; and what have you to propose?

SP.SPEAKER: Buckle.
SP.P: A lady, madam, in a chair, says her name is Clarinda.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Desire her to walk up.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: How could you let her wait? Exit Buckle. You must excuse him, madam. Buckle is a true batche∣lor's servant, and knows no manners.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Away, away, Mr. Frankly, and stay till I call you. A rap with my fan shall be the signal. [Exit Frankly.] We make very free with your house, Mr. Meggot.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Oh! You could not oblige me more!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Dear Mrs. Bellamy, pity my confusion. I am to wish you joy, and ask your pardon all in a breath. I know not what to say. I am quite ashamed of my last night's behaviour.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Come, come, Clarinda, it is all well! all is over and forgot. Mr. Bellamy. Salutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I wish you joy, sir, with all my heart, and should have been very sorry if any folly of mine had prevented it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Madam, I am obliged to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: [Aside.] I see nothing of Mr. Frankly! my heart misgives me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: And so: you came hither purely out of friend∣ship, good-nature, and humility.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Purely.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: To confess your offences, to beg pardon, and to make reparation.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Purely. Is this any thing so extraordinary?

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: The most so of any thing in life, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: A very whimsical business for so sine a lady, and an errand you seldom went on before, I fancy, my dear cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Never, I dare swear, if I may judge by the aukward concern she shows in delivering it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Concern? lard! well! I protest, you are all exceeding pretty company! Being settled for life, Ja∣cintha, gives an ease to the mind, that brightens con∣versation strangely.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I am sorry, with all my heart, you are not in the same condition; for as you are, my dear, you are horridly chagrine.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: But with a little of our help, madam, the lady may recover, and be very good company.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Hum! what does he mean, Mr. Bellamy?

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Ask him, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Indeed I shall not give myself the trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Then you know what he means.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Something impertinent, I suppose, not worth explaining.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: It is something you won't let him explain I find.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter a servant, and whispers Meggot.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Very well! desire him to walk into the parlour. Madam, the gentleman is below.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Then every one to your posts. You know your cues.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: I warrant ye. Exeunt gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: All gone! I am glad of it, for I want to speak to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: And I, my dear Clarinda, have something which I do not know how to tell you. But it must be know sooner or later.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Poor Mr. Frankly—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: You fright me out of my senses!

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Has no wounds, but what you can cure! ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Pshah! I am angry!

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Pshah! you are pleas'd! and will be more so, when I tell you this man, whom fortune has thrown in your way, is, in rank and temper, the man in the world, who suits you best for a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Husband! I say, husband indeed! where will this end? Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: His very soul is yours, and he only waits an opportunity of telling you so. He is in the next room. Shall I call him in?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: My dear girl, hold!

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: How foolish is this coyness now, Clarinda? if the men were here indeed, something might be said. —And so, Mr. Frankly!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: How can you be so teazing?

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Nay, I am in downright earnest; and to show you how particular I have been in my enquiries, tho' I know you have a spirit above regarding the mo∣dish, paltry way of a Smithfield bargain—his fortune—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I don't care what his fortune is.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Don't ye so? then you are farther gone than I thought you were.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: No, psha! pr'ythee! I don't mean so neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: I don't care what you mean. But you won't like him e worse, I hope, for having a fortune su∣perior to our own. Now, shall I call him in?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Pho! dear girl—some other time.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: [raps with her fan.] That's the signal, and here he is. You shall not stir. I positively will leave you together. Exit Jacintha.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: I tremble all over.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Pardon this freedom, madam,—but I hope our having so luckily met with a common friend in Mrs. Bellamy—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Makes any farther apology for my behaviour last night absolutely unnecessary.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: So far, Mr. Frankly, that I think the apology should be rather on my side, for the impertinent bustle I made about her.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: This behaviour gives me hopes, madam. Pardon the construction—but from the little bustle you made about the lady, may I not hope, you was not quite indifferent about the gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P:
Have a care of being too sanguine in your hopes. Might not a love of power, or the satisfaction
of showing that power, or the dear pleasure of abusing that power; might not these have been foundation enough for more than what I did?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Charming woman!—with most of your sex, I grant, they might, but not with you. Whatever power your beauty gives, your good-nature will alow you no other use of it, than to oblige.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: This is the height of compliment, Mr. Frankly.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Not in my opinion, I assure you, madam; and I am now going to put it to the trial.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: [Aside.] What is he going to say now?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: [Aside.] What is it that ails me, that I can∣not speak? psha! he here!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Interrupted! impertinent!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: There is no sight so ridiculous as a pair of your true lovers. Here are you two now, bowing and cringing, and keeping a passion secret from one another, that is no secret to all the house beside. And if you don't make the matter up immediately, it will be all over the town within these two hours.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Do you be quiet, can't ye! [Aside.] But it is over, I suppose, cousin, and you have given him your consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Sir, the liberties you are pleas'd to take with me—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Oh! in your airs still, are you? Why then Mr. Frankly, there is a certain letter of yours, sir, to this lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: A letter to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ay! to you, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ha! what of that letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: It is only fallen into Mr. Strictland's hands, that is all; and he has read it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Read it!

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Ay! read it to all his family at home, and to all the company below: and if some stop be not put to it, it will be read in all the-coffee-houses in town.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: A stop! this sword shall put a stop to it, or I will perish in the attempt.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: But will that sword put a stop to the talk of the town—only make it talk the faster, take my word for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: This is all a trick.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Is it so? you shall soon see that my sine cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: It is but too true, I fear. There is such a let∣ter which I gave Lucetta. Can you forgive me? Was I much to blame, when I could neither see nor hear of you?

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: [Tenderly]. You give yourself, Mr. Frankly, a thousand more uneasinesses than you need about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: If this uneasiness but convinces you how much I love you—interrupted again!

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: [Aside.] This is downright malice.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Ranger, followed by Jacintha, Mr. Strictland, Bellamy, and Meggot.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Enter, enter, gentlemen and lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Mr. Strictland here! what is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Now you shall see whether this is a trick or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Do not be uneasy, my dear; we will explain it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I cannot bear this trifling, Ranger, when my heart is on the rack.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Come this way then, and learn.

DIV3.STAGE: Jacintha, Clarinda, Frankly, and Ranger retire.
Mr. Strictland, Bellamy, and Meggot advance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Why, I know not well what to say. This has a face. This letter may as well agree with Clarinda as with my wife, as you have told the story; and Lucetta explain'd it so—but she for a sixpenny piece would have constru'd it the other way.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: But, sir, if we produce this Mr. Frankly to you, and he owns himself the author of this letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: And if Clarinda likewise be brought before your face to encourage his addresses, there can be no farther room for doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: No! let that appear, and I shall—I think I shall be satisfied—but, yet it cannot be—

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: Why not? Hear me, sir. They talk.

DIV3.STAGE: Jacintha, Clarinda, Frankly and Ranger advance.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P:
In short, Clarinda, unless the affair is made
up directly; a separation, with all the obloquy on her side, must be the consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Poor Mrs. Strictland, I pity her; but for him, he deserves all he feels were it ten times what it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: It is for her sake only that we beg of you both to bear with his impertinence.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: With all my heart. You will do what you please with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Generous creature?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ha! here she is, and with her the very man I saw deliver the letter to Lucetta—I do begin to fear I have made myself a fool—now for the proof— here is a letter, sir, which has given me great distur∣bance, and these gentlemen assure me it was writ by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: That letter, sir, upon my honor, I left this morning with Lucetta, for this lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: For that lady! and Frankly, the name at the bottom is not feigned, but your real name.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Frankly is my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I see, I feel myself ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Now Mr. Strictland—I hope—

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: Ay! ay! a clear case.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I am satisfied, and will go this instant to Mrs. Strictland.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why then the devil fetch me, if this would sa∣tisfy me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Nay, nothing. It is no affair of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bella.
SP.P: What do you mean, Ranger?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ay! what do you mean? I will know be∣fore I stir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: With all my heart, sir. Cannot you see that all this may be a concerted matter between them?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ranger, you know I can resent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Go on—I will defend you, let who will resent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why then, sir, I declare myself your friend; and were I as you—nothing but their immediate mar∣riage should convince me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Sir, you're right, and are my friend, in∣deed. Give me your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P:
Nay, were I to hear her say, I, Clarinda,
take thee Charles, I would not believe them 'till I saw them a-bed together. Now esent it as you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ay, sir, as you will. But nothing less shall convince me; and so, my fine lady, if you are in earnest—

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Sure, Mr. Strictland—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Nay, no flouncing! you cannot escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why, Frankly has't no soul?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I pity her confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Pity her confusion!—the man's a fool—here, take her hand—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Thus on my knees then, let me ravish with your hand, your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: Ravish it you cannot; for it is with all my heart I give it you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I am satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Clar.
SP.P: And so am I, now it once is over.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang
SP.P: And so am I, my dainty cousin—and I wish you joy of a man, your whole sex would go to cuffs for, if they knew him but half so well as I do—ha! she here! this is more than I bargained for. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: [Embracing Mrs Strictland.] Madam, re∣proach me not with my folly, and you shall never hear of it again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Reproach you! No! if ever you hear the least reflection pass my lips, forsake me in that in∣stant. Or, what would yet be worse, suspect me again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: It is enough. I am ashamed to talk to thee. This letter which I wrote your brother, thus I tear in pieces, and with it part forever with my jealousy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: This is a joy indeed! as great as unex∣pected. Yet there is one thing wanting to make it lasting.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: What the devil is coming now? Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Be assur'd, every other suspicion of me was as unjust as your last; though perhaps you had more foundations for your fears.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: She won't tell sure, for her own sake. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: All must be cleared before my heart will be at ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: It looks plaguy like it, tho'! Aside

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: What mean you? I am all attention.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: There was a man, as you suspected, in my chamber last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ha! take care, I shall relapse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: That gentleman was—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Here is a devil for you! Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: Let him explain the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: A frolic! a meer frolic! on my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: A frolic! Ounds! They interpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Nay don't let us quarrel the very moment you declar'd yourself my friend. There was no harm done, I promise you. Nay, never frown. After I have told my story: any satisfaction you are pleased to ask, I shall be ready to give.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Be quick then and ease me of my pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why then, as I was strolling about last night, —upon the look out, I must confess—Chance, and chance only, convey'd me to your house: where I espied a ladder of ropes most invitingly fasten'd to the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Which ladder I had fastened for my escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Up mounted I, and up I should have gone, if it had been into the garret. I opened one door, then another, and to my great surprise, the whole house was silent. At last, I stole into a room where this lady was undressing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: 'Sdeath and the devil! you did not dare sure—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: I don't know whether I had dared, or no: if I had not heard the maid say something of her master's being jealous. O! damn me, thought I, then the work is half done to my hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Jacin.
SP.P: Do you mind that Mr. Strictland?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I do — I do most feelingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: The maid grew saucy, and most conveniently to my wishes, was turned out of the room; and if you had not the best wife in the world —

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: Ounds! sir, but what right have you—

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: What right sir? if you will be jealous of your wife without a cause; if you will be out at that time of night, when you might have been so much better employed at home: we young fellows think we have a right—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: No joking, I beseech you. You know not what I feel.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Then seriously, I was mad, or drunk enough, call it which you will, to be very rude to this lady; for which I ask both her pardon and yours! I am an odd sort of a fellow, perhaps: but I am above telling you or any man, a lye▪—damn me if I am not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I must, I cannot but believe you; and for the future, madam, you shall find here a heart ready to love and trust you. No tears, I beg; I cannot bear them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Strict.
SP.P: I cannot speak; and yet there is a fa∣vour, sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: I understand you—and as a proof of the sincerity with which I speak, I beg it as a favour, of this lady, in particular [to Clarinda], and of all the company in general, to return to my house immediate∣ly; where every thing, Mr. Bellamy, shall be settled to your entire satisfaction—no thanks; I have not deserved them.

SP.SPEAKER: Jack Meg.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, sir: the fiddles are ready; Mrs. Bellamy has promised me her hand; and I won't part with one of you till midnight; and if you are as well satisfied as you pretend to be, let our friend Rattle here begin the ball with Mrs. Strictland; for he seems to be the hero of the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Strict.
SP.P: As you and the company please.

SP.SPEAKER: Rang.
SP.P: Why this is honest. Continue but in this humour, and faith, sir, you may trust me to run about your house like a spaniel.— I cannot sufficiently admire at the whimsicalness of my good fortune, in being so instrumental to this general happiness.—Bellamy, Frankly, I wish you joy with all my heart! (tho' I had rather you should be married than I, for all that.) Never did matrimony appear to me with a smile upon her face, till this instant.

LG.L: Sure joys for ever wait each happy pair,
When sense the man, and virtue crowns the fair;
And kind compliance proves their mutual care.
